PETITION.TITLE: Marriage
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Marriage

To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of Australia concerned about the high and increasing rate of divorce and family breakdown, convinced that the Family Law Act has weakened marriage by making divorce a trivial matter, the present Act paying scant regard to its own definition of marriage as a life-long union; and believing that the legal bond of marriage should be strengthened humbly petition for the Family Law Act and the Marriage Act to be amended in order to:
1. reject any moves towards divorce by post;
2. restore the former prohibition of marriages between close relatives by blood or marriage;
3. protect the rights and welfare of aggrieved partners of a marriage who are threatened with being divorced against their will;
4. ensure that in divorce judgments paramount attention be given to whatever course will best serve the welfare of dependent children of the marriage;
5. encourage counselling towards reconciliation;
6. restore objective tests to irretrievable breakdown of marriage in terms of:
(i) intolerable behaviour;
(ii) desertion for two years;
(iii) separation for three years.
And we pray that you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our Nation .
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that:

The Universal Declaration of Human Rights affirms the principle of the inadmissibility of discrimination and proclaims that all human beings are born free and equal in dignity and rights and that everyone is entitled to all the rights and freedoms set forth therein, without distinction of any kind including distinction based on sex.

However extensive discrimination against women continues to exist. It is an obstacle to the participation of women on equal terms with men, in the political , social, economic and cultural life of this country. It hampers the growth of the prosperity of society and the family and makes more difficult the full development of the potentialities of women in the service of this country and of humanity.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government will act to ratify the convention on the elimination of all forms of discrimination against women.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: BAUME; BJELKE-PETERSEN; BUTTON; DURACK; LAJOVIC; ROBERTSON; WATSON
PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas the Government of Australia has signed the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which in Article 23 (1) states that ''The family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to the protection by society and the State''. And whereas the terms of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women would violate the above Article 23 (1).
We humbly pray the Government to refrain from ratifying the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women; Believing that its implementation would result in:
(1) Undue cost to the nation at this time.

(2) ''The elimination of any stereotyped concept of roles of men and women at all levels'' as described in Part 3 Article 10 (c), being a disruption of traditional parental roles, is likely to result in emotional disturbances of childhood.

(3) The strong encouragements to mothers to join the workforce, with the provision of networks of creches and child care centres as outlined in Article 11 of the convention is likely to result in maternal deprivation and psychological disturbances among children with an increase in childhood psychiatric illnesses.
(4) The sexual role changing as recommended in Part 3 Article 10 (c) is likely to contribute to further marriage insecurity and breakdown.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our Nation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fixed Term Parliaments
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of NSW respectfully showeth:-
That a fixed term period of Parliament places the security of executive government above the common good of the people.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate opposes legislation to facilitate the introduction of a fixed term period of Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask whether the attention of the Leader of the Government in the Senate has been drawn to the Prime Minister's statement in the House of Representatives last Tuesday, 24 May, in which, when talking about the Opposition, he said:

QUESTION.PARA: It can take bus loads of decimated Liberals to Bruce; it can take them where it likes. But the people of Australia will say: 'Do not knock this Government; do not criticise this Government because we know that it is honest and fair dinkum' .
Does the Leader of the Government believe that that is what the people of Bruce said last Saturday?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister's statement has been drawn to my attention. It is a reasonable interpretation that something less than one per cent of the electors of Bruce disagreed with the Prime Minister's view.

—Can the Attorney-General indicate whether the decision of the High Court of Australia in relation to the validity of the World Heritage Conservation Act 1983 will be accepted as ultimate and binding on the Federal Government? In particular, will he indicate whether, in the event of a decision by the court against the validity of the Act, the Government intends using other constitutional powers which may be thought to be available to it to prevent the construction of the Franklin Dam should the State Government still wish to pursue that project?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am now in a position, following full Cabinet consideration of this matter yesterday, to give a clear statement of the Government's position in the hypothetical event that the Commonwealth's regulations or legislation or both should be held invalid in the present High Court case and that this legislation, as a result, is unable to be used in defence of the Tasmanian wilderness.

ANSWER.PARA: In stating the Government's position on this issue I make two points: Firstly, if the cause of the invalidity is some easily remediable, technical defect identified by the court, we would reserve the right to act accordingly to correct that defect. Secondly, and more importantly in terms of the substance of Senator Tate's question, if, however, the legislation or regulations were to be held invalid for some more fundamental reason and accordingly it became a question of whether we would seek to employ additional or alternative legislative or executive measures to stop the construction of the dam-for example, the use by the Commonwealth of its grants or loans power or its power to control overseas borrowing-we would not. In this situation we would treat the High Court decision as being in every respect the end of the matter.

As I have said on a number of previous occasions, speaking in a personal capacity, the financial powers in particular are a very blunt instrument of uncertain effect and utility. It is the Government's view that they would be inappropriate for use for this purpose. I make only the following point: The legislation now before the court is of great complexity. Its passage and the preparation of the current litigation which commenced today have involved an enormous investment by the Commonwealth Government of time, energy and expertise , not to mention political commitment.

In the event, which, I repeat, is an unlikely event, I believe, that the Commonwealth's action fails in this respect to stop the construction of the dam, I think it will be concluded by most reasonable Australians that we will have done our best.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Attorney- General recall writing a letter dated 12 May 1983 to a constituent who had written to him expressing his concern at media reports about future Government policies on the taxation of lump sum superannuation payments? I ask him whether he recalls saying in reply to the constituent, in particular:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . the new Labor Government has not taken any decision-
I am referring to his letter dated 12 May-
in this regard and any consideration of the matter could only take place in the Budget context when all areas of Government income and expenditure are announced .
If the Attorney-General recalls that letter was he then misleading his constituent or was he kept in the dark about this policy which has shocked so many thousands of Australians?

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that during Senator Durack's administration of his department and ministerial office the existence of word processors and the managerial techniques of correspondence answering that go with them were not recognised. I am afraid that in this particular instance, as I recall it, something has obviously beaten the system. It was a standard form letter by which I replied. It was written to a very large number of constituents over a long period. I regret that it appears essentially that a form letter response sneaked out. I congratulate the shadow Attorney-General on the triumph of investigative technique which he brought to the asking of his question.

—I direct a question to the Attorney-General. Has the Government received from Mr David Combe an application for a grant of legal assistance for representation before the Hope Royal Commission on Australian Security and Intelligence Agencies? If so, is such assistance being provided to Mr Combe?

—Mr Combe's solicitors have requested that a special grant of legal assistance be made to Mr Combe to be represented at the royal commission so far as its proceedings relate to him. That application was not for legal assistance in the ordinary legal aid sense but, rather, an application for special assistance before an inquiry conducted by the Government. There are precedents for such payments, and the Government has now decided to pay the reasonable legal expenses of Mr Combe. Having regard to the level of legal representation that could be appropriate in the proceedings as they affect him, and the legal representation being made available to other parties to the commission, maximum figures of the order of $2,500 per sitting day and $2,000 per preparatory working day have been approved by the Cabinet. This should enable Mr Combe to employ very high quality legal advice indeed.

—My question is addressed to the Attorney-General and it follows that asked by the shadow Attorney-General a moment ago. I refer to the answer, in which it is clear that the Attorney-General claimed that he merely sent out a form letter which had come off a word processor, and that that excuses him. I ask the Attorney-General: Is he following the practice which caused so much difficulty to Dr Cairns, when he was in office, of signing letters without reading them?

—It is not my practice to sign letters without reading them. It certainly is my practice to sign letters without there being a date stamp on them and without further investigation as to their passage in and out of my office-whether in Melbourne or in Canberra: I have a word processor in both places-I cannot say when the letter was signed. Senator Chaney is very welcome to table the letter. I congratulate him also on his triumph of investigative technique in this matter of manifestly momentous importance.

—Is the Attorney-General aware of the proposals, released last Friday by the New South Wales Law Reform Commission, for a new transport accident compensation scheme for New South Wales? What are the financial implications for the Commonwealth of the proposed scheme? What steps can now be expected to fulfil the Government's election promise to proceed in co-operation with the States to the establishment of an integrated Commonwealth-State compensation scheme which ensures speedy compensation at reasonable levels for accident victims?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure whether I can answer all parts of the question but I will answer as far as I can. I am aware of the Sackville report. It has been the subject of Press reports. I have received copies of the working paper in the last day or so from the Commission. I have been in close consultation with the New South Wales Law Reform Commission over the last 18 months to ensure that, so far as possible, there is co-operation between the new Commonwealth Government, as it was anticipated, and the State governments in the working out of a comprehensive policy approach to no-fault accident compensation , it being the belief of this Government that a unilateral Commonwealth approach to this matter of the kind recommended the last time around in the Woodhouse inquiry is not appropriate in this area, and that we need to adopt a rather different co-ordinated and integrated approach to the change of law and practice in this area. I very much welcome the appearance of the New South Wales Law Reform Commission paper. The importance of accident compensation law can hardly be overstated. It is of the utmost social and economic significance and it is apparent to anyone who scrutinises the present system that it urgently requires reform.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the particular features of the scheme-as I understand it-proposed by Professor Sackville's Commission, it provides for compensation of all victims of transport accidents, regardless of whether fault can be shown, by means of weekly payments for loss of earning capacity to a level of 80 per cent of gross pre-accident earnings up to a maximum earnings level of 125 per cent of average weekly earnings. It provides for payments to be indexed in line with increases in average weekly earnings. The scheme provides for all medical, hospital and rehabilitation expenses to be met. It provides for additional compensation to a maximum of about $50,000 to be available for permanent physical disability such as loss of a limb and it provides for the abolition of common law negligence actions which at present, of course, require the injured person to prove that someone else was at fault for the accident.

The cost of the scheme as estimated by the Commission would be, on a fully funded basis, $112 per vehicle per annum instead of the present third party premium which averages $154 per vehicle. If those figures prove to withstand close scrutiny they will amount to a very substantial improvement in the position of the ordinary vehicle owner in this area as well as supply what is lacking at the moment-a universal compensation coverage for traffic accidents. I am unable to give a detailed response on the financial implications of the proposed scheme for the Commonwealth. I know there are some. They would certainly need to be worked out in co-operation with the States. I will give the honourable senator a further and better answer in that respect.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Attorney-General aware of recent statements by the Victorian Chief Commissioner of Police that 550 crimes a day are being committed in Melbourne alone, the majority of them being very serious? Is the Attorney aware that Mr Miller stated that the only feasible solution in combating organised crime is to give selected officers of law enforcement agencies access to taxation files? Is the Attorney aware of the comments of Mr Douglas Meagher Q .C. that Australia cannot afford years of debate on these issues because we have only a year or so if we are to fight organised crime effectively and that to do so will require a 'fundamental change in law enforcement procedures'? Will the Government, in establishing the national crimes commission, consider giving such a body the power to see tax files which until now have been the sole province of the Australian Taxation Office which willingly collects money from illegal activities yet refuses, even to royal commissioners, to disclose its sources so that crime can be controlled?

—I am aware of the various statements to which the honourable senator has referred. As to the very sensitive question of whether a crimes commission or some similar agency should be given access to taxation records, I simply make the point that this is one of the matters that will be addressed, in terms of the arguments pro and con, in the Green Paper which is currently under preparation in my Department in consultation with the Special Minister of State and which it is intended to have publicly available within a matter of weeks with a view to being debated at a national seminar of all relevant interests towards the end of July. It is one of the issues which we regard as certainly needing to be resolved in this respect. I might also mention that a number of aspects of the policy question to which Senator Chipp has referred are also addressed in the report of the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking which will be tabled in this place later this afternoon.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I draw Senator Button's attention to the problems being faced by Queensland primary producers in relation to the drought and flood losses which are possibly as high as $440m. Has the Government received any requests for assistance from the Queensland Government for natural disaster relief? If so, what action is the Government considering at this juncture? Is the Government considering the establishment of a natural disaster relief fund?

—The Commonwealth Government has received at least one request from Queensland for assistance of the kind mentioned in the honourable senator's question. Special assistance has been sought from Queensland in respect of fodder and that request is being examined urgently by the Government. The honourable senator referred to the question of flood relief. I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that the armed forces have already been made available and have been helping magnificently during the emergency phase of the flood situation. As a general matter, the Commonwealth stands ready to offer assistance to the Queensland Government for flood relief. Of course, natural disaster relief arrangements are already in place under which the Commonwealth Government reimburses the States on a three to one basis for a number of expenditures. Examples are immediate relief in respect of personal hardship and distress, grants for restoration of public assets and emergency protection and repair works by government authorities, concessional loans to small business, concessional loans to church and voluntary non-profit organisations, freight subsidies for primary producers and assistance to government authorities for disposal of helpless and unsaleable stock. They are some examples of the current natural disaster relief available. As I said at the beginning of my answer, at this stage there has been only one request for relief from Queensland. That related to fodder and it is being examined as a matter of urgency.
—Mr President, we ask that the paper that the Minister quoted from be tabled.
—A request has been made that the paper be tabled.
—I table the paper.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF FOREIGN AFFAIRS: ALLEGATIONS AGAINST OFFICERS

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Attorney-General agree with the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden, who said last Thursday that the campaign by Senator Primmer against officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs amounted to 'trial by Hansard, conviction by innuendo and, I believe, an inexcusable smudging of the character of the people to whom I have referred'? If so, why could he not find it within himself to deplore the allegations in such a forthright manner when he responded on behalf of Mr Hayden earlier on the same day? Does this reluctance to endorse wholeheartedly his colleague's approach reflect concern about antagonising the Victorian Left, or is it simply an example of the Attorney- General's lack of support for the former leader of the Australian Labor Party-a man in whose downfall he is said to have played a major role?

—I decline to comment on the latter matters raised in Senator Jessop's question. As to the former matters and the substance of his question, I have nothing to add to what I said on this matter in the adjournment debate. I said then, and I repeat now if it needs to be repeated, that I believe that Senator Primmer's allegations have been made with a spirit of great sincerity and in a fierce belief as to the rightness of what he is alleging. As a result I will not do anything which might be construed as imputing ill motives or any other lapse on the part of Senator Primmer or any other of my colleagues to whom the same evidence was available. Equally, however, I repeat now, as I said on that occasion, that I do not believe that the evidence which has emerged from the series of inquiries that has so far taken place in relation to this matter substantiates the allegations in question but it may be, given that both the Ombudsman and the Public Service Board are still inquiring into aspects of the matter, that such substantiation will appear, in which case I do not think it would be appropriate to state any concluded view as to the allegations in question.
—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I ask Senator Evans whether he agrees with Mr Hayden's remark.
—I have nothing to add to my previous answer.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Finance aware of the extent of tax dodging that went on in Darwin through so-called bottom-of- the-harbour schemes? Is he also aware that some companies use the Northern Territory to conduct their share transfer business, therefore depriving the States of stamp duty revenue as Territory stamp duty rates are considerably lower? As the Territory is heavily dependent on the Australian taxpayer's support, will the Northern Territory Government be encouraged in future to desist from these operations as they reduce Commonwealth, State and Territory government fund raising?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was aware of the fact that the Northern Territory is heavily dependent upon Commonwealth revenue, as Senator Robertson mentioned in the latter part of his question. Indeed, I have noted from time to time that nobody has a more voracious appetite for Commonwealth money than the present Northern Territory Chief Minister, although incongruously nobody is a more vocal critic of the Commonwealth taxes which raise the revenue which he so voraciously consumes. For example, he has a proposal now, in a time of alleged financial stringency, to increase the size of the Northern Territory Parliament by six members to the point where there will be one member of parliament, plus lavish staff provisions, for every 2,000 people.

ANSWER.PARA: I am also aware of the other matter to which Senator Robertson drew attention- that is, that the offices of accounting firms in Darwin have been used on a very wide scale to assist tax avoidance and evasion-and presumably that matter must have been known to the Northern Territory Government and the Northern Territory Chief Minister. Indeed, one may even wonder whether it was done with that deliberate intent. Although the Northern Territory Chief Minister has a heavy demand for Commonwealth revenue, he has simultaneously, through the provision of charges and stamp duties which facilitate tax evasion, been helping over many years to erode the Commonwealth's taxation base.

When searching documents in the Perth Corporate Affairs Office with respect to a former Minister in a Liberal government, Sir Victor Garland, I noted from the transactions documented there that the shuffle of assets and ownerships over two States and one Territory was facilitated by the office of Peat, Marwick, Mitchell and Co. in Darwin and that that firm of accountants and many other firms of accountants in Darwin have facilitated tax avoidance and evasion for a vast number of transactions. I also understand, of course, that certainly not all, but nearly all, the members of the Darwin accountancy firms which facilitated those activities are deeply involved in the Country Liberal Party of the Northern Territory.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, relates to Australia's responsibilities to its citizens overseas who have contravened the laws of another country. First, does the Government believe that it has a special obligation to Australians in trouble overseas and in some cases a duty to intervene in foreign legal systems to ensure that Australians receive a fair trial? Secondly, what action will be taken by the Government to ensure that the rule of law is applied as far as possible to all Australian nationals detained abroad, especially in those nations operating under systems of law which do not accord with standards that would ordinarily be observed by civilised communities? Thirdly, will the Government present to the Parliament a statement outlining its attitude on these issues generally and the duties required of our representatives overseas, along the lines I requested of the previous Government in my Senate speech of 27 May 1982 my question without notice of 16 November 1982 and correspondence with the previous Foreign Minister?

—The detailed matters, and in particular the question of a statement, I will refer to the Minister for Foreign Affairs for a detailed reply as soon as possible. As to the earlier parts of the question, it is in fact the case, as the honourable senator will be well aware, that Australian consular posts overseas do their best to ensure that Australians in trouble with criminal authorities in other countries are given access to lawyers and are otherwise enabled to take advantage of such protections as the legal systems of those countries give them. There are limitations of resources and otherwise to the kind of commitment that Australia can afford in this respect, and it is very much part of the business of Foreign Affairs to try to warn Australians travelling overseas that they do so at peril of criminal punishment if they offend against the laws of other countries, however draconian the substantive laws or the criminal procedures of those countries may appear to us to be in some cases. It may be that more can be done in this respect. I will draw the honourable senator's question to the attention of the Minister in the hope that that will produce a satisfactory reply.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs whether she is aware that the Tasmanian Government has frozen the distribution of a booklet called The Forgotten People, which depicts the history and culture of the Tasmanian Aboriginals. Does the Minister realise that this booklet was intended to be the first of a series produced with Commonwealth funds by the Curriculum Branch of the Tasmanian Education Department, the material therein being aimed at increasing the understanding of Aboriginals and improving race relations in Tasmania? Does the Minister not agree that this action by the Tasmanian Government is an example of extraordinary sensitivity and censorship by a government that is more at home with nineteenth century thinking and shows an irresponsible attitude to Commonwealth-funded projects? In view of the fact that the project is Commonwealth-funded, what action can be taken by the Minister whom she represents?

—The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs informs me that he has received representations on this matter from the Tasmanian Aboriginal Education Consultative Committee and has taken it up with Mr Gray, whose Government is to consider, at Cabinet level, the introduction of the booklet. I must say that I am alarmed to hear that the Tasmanian Government has at least acquiesced in this course of action with regard to information of this kind. I would have thought that in Tasmania, of all States or Territories of Australia, the need for curriculum designed to inform children about the real history of the Aboriginal people of the State was overwhelming. I find it very disappointing that when socially useful material of this kind is developed with Commonwealth money the Tasmanian Government can, for reasons that it has not yet explained, decide not to proceed with it. So, as well as conveying to the honourable senator and to the Senate the information received from my colleague, Mr Holding, I will undertake to investigate the matter myself and to provide Senator Coates with more information.
—I ask that the document from which the Minister quoted be tabled, in accordance with Standing Order 363.
—I table the document.

—I ask the Attorney-General: When Mr David Combe was taken through and agreed to Mr Hawke's statement line by line, in relation to the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation-Combe-Ivanov affair, were any threats or inducements of any sort made or held out by the Attorney-General or by anyone else to influence the acceptance or otherwise of that statement by Mr Combe? In other words, was it the case that he was 'verballed' by the Attorney- General himself?

If the honourable senator has any skerrick of evidence to substantiate the kinds of allegations that he now makes to me under cover of privilege in this place he will have his opportunity to do so before that royal commission of inquiry.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs in her capacity as Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Is the Minister aware that in South Australia the Housing Trust contributes $1.4m per annum towards the 11 women's refuge shelters; that the Department of Community Welfare contributes around $750,000 towards the cost of shelter staff; that Crisis Care estimates that 40 per cent of its time goes on domestic violence disputes; that the police estimate that 25 per cent of their time goes on domestic violence disputes; that the Family Court of Australia estimates that 80 per cent of the counselling cases in Melbourne concern break- up of marriage due to domestic violence; and that a considerable percentage of social security costs, in terms of supporting parent benefit and unemployment payments, results from breakdown of marriage due to domestic violence? Given this rough estimate of the considerable cost to our society of domestic violence in dollars alone and not taking into account the human cost, can the Minister say what research, if any, is currently being conducted into ways of coping with or preventing domestic violence in our society?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not aware of the detailed amounts of money that are being spent by the South Australian Government on problems associated with domestic violence but I certainly am aware of the growing burden that this form of anti- social activity imposes on the community and on taxpayers in general, not only in South Australia but also in all States and Territories of Australia. It is also a sad fact, but one that we have to acknowledge, that in the last seven years of the Fraser Government's mismanagement of the economy, with the concomitant increasing levels of unemployment, domestic violence increased. Any person who is in contact with the work being done by women's refuges in this regard will be aware that as unemployment rises so does the rate of domestic violence and so, of course, does the call on the emergency services that women's refuges and similar crisis services are able to operate. The Commonwealth Government is very well aware of the problem and is very concerned about it.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator asked me about research being done into this problem. In answer to that part of her question I am able to tell her that in Victoria, South Australia and New South Wales State government task forces have looked into and produced reports on domestic violence. In New South Wales a report containing wide-ranging recommendations including legislative reform and reforms in the area--

TALK.START.PARA: —You are reading your speech.
—Mr President, I believe that some members of this chamber are interested in what steps are being taken to investigate and overcome this problem. Probably Senator Withers is not one of them.
—The Minister is reading her answer.
—Mr President--
—Senator Ryan, I suggest that you answer the question that has been directed to you by Senator Crowley.

—The New South Wales Government has before it a report which has made a number of wide-ranging recommendations concerning changes to the law and reforms in the housing area. In South Australia and New South Wales legislation is being introduced to allow courts to attach powers of arrest without warrant to orders for the prevention of violence. A similar provision is included in the Family Law Amendment Bill soon to be introduced into this Senate. Perhaps on the occasion of the debate on that legislation honourable senators who are interested and concerned and anxious to be constructive in this regard will be able to have a constructive debate.
—Mr President, under Standing Order 363 I ask that the document quoted from by the Minister be tabled.
—What is all this about?
—Order! A request has been made that the document be tabled.
—I table the document.

—Does the Minister representing the Treasurer accept the proposition put forward in a document presented to the National Economic Summit Conference and entitled 'Projections of the Australian Economy to 1985-86', which suggests that variations in the level of the consumer price index and the growth rate of the gross domestic product may affect the size of a deficit? Can the Minister inform the Senate of the assumed rate of these two variables at the time Treasury calculated next year's deficit at $9.6 billion? What are those estimates at present?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that this is the latest of the gee-whiz explanations of the discredited former Treasurer for his failure to tell the public the truth about the advice which had been given to him in the week before the election concerning the projected level of the deficit for the next financial year, to get him out of the hole into which that deception of the Australian people had landed him, to the permanent damage of his reputation.
—Wasn't it also given to Mr Hawke before the election?

—Of course it was not. It was given to Mr Hawke on the day after the election, with the further information that the discredited former Treasurer , who was then and still is the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party, was told on the day before the election that the projected deficit for next year was nearly $10 billion. Four days before the election he was told that the projected deficit would be something between $9 billion and $10 billion.

ANSWER.PARA: On both of those occasions he went to the then Prime Minister and said: 'Will we tell the public about this horrendous deficit forecast of which Treasury has notified us?' Mr Fraser said: 'No, don't tell them that; give them the mushroom treatment'. That is exactly what the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party did.

I cannot remember off the top of my head what real gross domestic product growth rate was assumed in any of the scenarios that the Treasurer put before the Summit Conference last month, nor do I know what the latest Treasury projection is. I will ask the Treasurer for information on that. As a matter of common sense, other things being equal-the drought having broken-the projected growth rate would have increased over that which was previously forecast.

I might add, since Senator Messner is one of the few people in the Opposition who have sufficient interest in this subject actually to understand the significance of this point, that there is a difference between June-on-June forecasts-I hope Senator Messner is listening-and year-on-year forecasts. They are not necessarily the same thing. Indeed there can be wide divergences between the two.

TALK.START.PARA: —We do understand that.

—I gave Senator Messner the credit of actually understanding that and taking a serious interest in the subject-a degree of diligence and application which I commend to some of his colleagues. For the purposes of the likely size of the deficit, it is the year-on-year growth factor, in comparison with the previous year, which is the more important.

—I address my question to the Minister representing both the Minister for Trade and the Minister for Primary Industry. According to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, potato imports into Australia for home consumption in 1981-82 were 700 per cent above the 1980-81 level. What research is being done to assess the effect of these imports on Australian growers?

—I must confess that I was not aware of the statistics which Senator Hearn has just cited, nor do I have any advice from the Minister for Trade on that subject. I will refer her request to the Minister for Trade and pass on the reply at the earliest opportunity.

— Is the Minister representing the Minister for Finance aware that according to the document 'Projections of the Australian Economy to 1985-86', which the Government presented at the National Economic Summit Conference-I recognise that the Minister was not present as a representative-an increase of some one per cent of gross domestic product would result in a deficit decrease of some $480m? Given that the Treasurer's senior adviser, Dr Barry Hughes, has indicated to journalists that revised estimates suggest that gross domestic product will rise to 4 per cent and that the original estimate of next year's deficit was based on an assumed rate of growth in GDP of 0.5 of one per cent, can we expect a $1,600m reduction in the original estimate to be announced very shortly?

—As Senator Lewis suggested, I do not recall off the top of my head the precise figures detailed in any of the scenarios, but the figure he gave seems to me to be a credible figure. I do not dispute it. As to whether Dr Hughes told journalists that a revised forecast of growth was 4 per cent, I do not know; I would have to ask Dr Hughes. I have no official capacity in which I can ask him, although I could ask him privately. If he did say that, a matter which needs to be further refined, as I pointed out to Senator Messner, is whether he was talking about June-on-June growth forecasts or year-on-year growth forecasts. That is an important point which would have a major influence, of course, on both government revenue collections and government expenditures with regard to unemployment benefits. The very last part of Senator Lewis's question seemed to me to be identical with the question asked by Senator Messner , and I will refer it to the Treasurer, too.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations aware that the costs associated with the Builders Labourers Federation deregistration case this financial year increased by approximately $ 700,000 over and above the amount originally appropriated? Does the Minister agree that these excessive cost rises are a direct result of the previous Government's preoccupation with union bashing and, indeed, its confrontationist approach to industrial relations generally? Is the Minister of the opinion that the additional funds required, and in fact the total cost of the case to date, which is about $1.8m, could have been avoided if the agreement and discussions as outlined in the Minister's Press release of 16 May had taken place before the commencement of the deregistration proceedings?

—There have been long and complicated matters before various tribunals and the court relating to the situation of the Australian Builders Labourers Federation in the last year or two. On 16 May the Minister issued a statement in relation to the discussions then taking place before the Federal Court of Australia in Melbourne. In that statement he indicated that all parties to the proceedings for deregistration of the Builders Labourers Federation, including the employers, the Federal Government and the BLF, were in agreement and had the concurrence of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. The agreement arrived at on that occasion was that the BLF would give certain undertakings to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, as it had in 1976, regarding its obligations under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act and the use of the dispute settlement procedure of the Act rather than resorting to industrial action. That agreement formed the basis of a further undertaking as to negotiations between the parties to achieve a lasting settlement in the building industry and, indeed, in the role of the Builders Labourers Federation in that industry. In those circumstances I agree that the prolongation-if that is the appropriate word-of the Builders Labourers Federation deregistration case was a waste of money, and if a different approach had been adopted by the previous Government the situation which the honourable senator asked about could have been rectified much earlier.
—Mr President, I ask that the paper from which the Minister quoted be tabled.
—The paper is tabled.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer whether he is aware of the following statement by his colleague in another place last Thursday :

QUESTION.PARA: At the time the Government was presented with that figure--
That is $9.6 billion-
the prospects for growth in 1983-84 were, in actuality, far less than they are now, given that the farm sector is likely to be a lot stronger.

Does this statement represent a retreat from the Government's former ploy of presenting next year's deficit as a finite and fixed amount, and does it represent a recognition that this figure has always been flexible? If so, why have the Government and the Minister persistently talked up the amount of next year's assumed deficit? Can the Minister confirm that this talking-up was simply an attempt to keep in check calls from Government back benchers that the Government's election promises be implemented?

TALK.START.PARA: —Apparently Senator Teague thinks that if the projected $9.6 billion deficit, of which the Treasury notified the former Treasurer on the day before the election, had been published it would have been a matter of no consequence. The honourable senator may believe that, but I can say that the former Prime Minister certainly did not, and nor did the former Treasurer, because they decided not to release the information. Mr Fraser said: 'No, don't tell them. Give them the mushroom treatment'.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Chaney

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order. Standing Order 100 provides:

INTERJECT.PARA: In answering any such Question, a Senator shall not debate the matter to which the same refers.
Senator Walsh has answered a number of questions in a way which I am sure fits within the provisions of that Standing Order. I ask that you require him to answer the question and not debate it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Opposition would know that Ministers are entitled to answer questions in the way in which they think fit. But I ask Senator Walsh, in answering the question, to bear in mind the Standing Order to which the honourable senator has drawn attention.

—The deficit projected by the Treasury at that time was based on the on- going programs of the Fraser Government and, of course, on certain assumptions about factors which would either assist or impede economic growth. Since the election there have been significant changes, at least two of which affect the prospects for economic growth. I told the Senate that I would seek from the Treasurer the latest growth forecast. But I will name at least two factors which will have significant and positive effects on the likely growth rate in the next financial year. They are equally obvious. The first is the fact that the drought has broken. If other things had remained equal, that would have increased the reasonable expectation of growth in the next financial year. But other things have not remained equal. Since then we have had a change of government. Because of that, the expectations of growth would very reasonably have been revised upwards. Australia, instead of having a cowardly and fiscally irresponsible government, now has a courageous and fiscally responsible government which everybody appreciates will do a much better job of managing the economy than did the discredited Liberal-National Party Fraser Government which it replaced.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Finance. What restitution does the Government intend to offer temporary government employees who are dismissed after they contract tenosynovitis-commonly called the rapid movement disease-whilst in government employment?
—Not seen on your side.

—Senator Messner finds the whole thing funny; it is not. I refer to a dispute currently occurring in the Australian Taxation Office in Melbourne, in which I believe two temporary keyboard operators have been dismissed by senior management of the Taxation Office after contracting tenosynovitis from rapid finger movements involved in their work. Does the Minister agree that it is manifestly unfair to offer six months employment to those keyboard operators on the basis that they will be offered permanent employment on the completion of that service, but then to dismiss them because of a disability caused during that six month period? Arising out of this question, can the unions representing the two keyboard operators-that is, the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association, the Australian Public Service Association and the Federated Clerks Union-expect some reasoned negotiations by Taxation Office management over the fate of the two employees, rather than its current blanket refusal to reinstate them?

—I have located a note on this subject which has been provided for me by the Minister for Finance. I am told that, following discussions last week with the unions involved and the Public Service Board, the Minister for Finance, who is, of course, also responsible for the Australian Taxation Office, will be meeting tomorrow with officials of the Taxation Office branch of the Federated Clerks Union. The union will be represented by its National President, the Victorian Secretary and probably by one of the affected keyboard operators. The Federated Clerks Union has been asked by the other two unions-that is, the ACOA and the Australian Public Service Association-to represent them at the meeting.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Resources and Energy been drawn to yesterday's editorial in the Australian Financial Review which stated that next year's projected Budget deficit figure of $9.6 billion was now inoperative; that that figure was calculated on an assumption of a gross domestic product rate of only 0.5 per cent; that now, as a result of the wages pause and an easing of the drought, that rate is likely to be around 4 per cent; and that the real projected deficit figure is in fact far lower? Does this indicate that the Government and the Minister have misled the public and Parliament by continually referring to rubbery projected deficit estimates?
—We have heard this question three times already.
—It has to be pursued.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Scott asked whether the Government and, I think, I have misled the Senate and/or the Parliament. The answer to that is no. What I have stated on numerous occasions-apparently members of the Opposition like to hear me say it on numerous occasions because they keep asking questions about it-is that the projection handed to the discredited former Treasurer on the day before the last election was that the deficit in 1983-84, based on no changes from present conditions, would be $9.6 billion. I have stated that in this chamber many times and it is absolutely true. It has been confirmed in writing by the Secretary to the Treasury himself.

ANSWER.PARA: The answer to the question is no. Neither this Government nor I, nor Mr Dawkins , Mr Keating, Mr Hawke, Senator Button or anyone else who has made a comment on this subject has misled either the public or the Parliament. The person who misled the public-the only reason he did not mislead the Parliament, I suggest, is that it was not sitting at the time-is the discredited former Treasurer who was told that the projected deficit was $9.6 billion. At the same time as he was told that, he was telling the public that the deficit projection was $6 billion. I suggest that if Senator Scott wants to chastise people who have been misleading the public, and they would have misled the Parliament if they had had the chance, he should seek them in the ranks of his coalition partner party rather than among the members of this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Social Security whether his attention has been drawn to an article in the Brisbane Daily Sun within the last two weeks . The report stated that a former officer of the Department of Social Security has appeared in court after allegedly receiving almost $700 from a Brisbane company for providing it with official information which he was not authorised to give. In view of the seriousness of this incident, what action is being contemplated to prevent similar occurrences in the future?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, my attention was drawn to the article in the Brisbane Daily Sun and has been drawn to other instances whereby officers of the Department of Social Security have been offered bribes and, unfortunately, in a couple of cases, have received bribes by debt collecting agencies seeking information from files held by the Department of Social Security. I can assure the Parliament and the public that this Government takes very seriously the provisions of the legislation aimed at preventing such occurrences in the future. We will pursue very vigorously any prosecutions in any case of this type which comes to our notice.

ANSWER.PARA: It is unfortunate that debt collection companies feel that they must conduct their affairs in this way. Officers of the Department of Social Security have been notified that this sort of thing has been going on. They have been notified that they are at risk of being approached by companies of this type. They are also being notified of the consequences of any actions by them in contravention of the privacy legislation concerning the Department of Social Security. I assure the honourable senator that, although unfortunately there are people in the community like this who will offer bribes and very occasionally people who will accept them, we will do all in our power to prevent such occurrences in the future.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NORTH WEST CAPE NAVAL COMMUNICATIONS STATION

TALK.START.PARA: —Did the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs tell a seminar at the Australian National University yesterday that the North West Cape Naval Communications Station in Western Australia is a prime nuclear target? Is this an official Government view? Was the Minister's speech, as reported, cleared by the office of the Minister for Foreign Affairs?
—The answer to each of the three questions asked by the honourable senator is yes. I simply repeat that the Government recognises that the existence of Pine Gap is a nuclear target.
—He hasn't asked about Pine Gap.
—North West Cape. All the facilities of the United States of America in Australia are accepted by us as a part of a deterrent strategy.

—What is the view of the Leader of the Government in the Senate of the Opposition's criticisms of the May economic statement? Is it not the case that the Opposition is simply adopting a mindlessly negative approach to measures which the former Government had neither the will nor the political purpose to implement?
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The honourable senator is asking for an opinion.
—Order! I will allow the Leader of the Government to answer the question in the way in which he desires.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate will get an opinion too, Mr President. I agree with the honourable senator's criticism of the Opposition's attitude to the May economic statement, which was a necessary and valuable first step towards restoring the balance of the economy. I am not alone in expressing that view. That view is shared, for example, by a former member of this Parliament, Mr John Hyde. He expressed a view in last Friday's Australian Financial Review in these terms:

QUESTION.PARA: For the main part the mini-Budget was a catalogue of things that the Liberals should have done long ago, yet every time he-
That is, Mr Keating-
announced a sensible expenditure cut or elimination of a tax privilege, he was greeted with catcalls from the Opposition.

Mr Hyde went on to say that the Labor Party is being 'far more far-sighted than the Government it replaced'. In my view the Opposition would do well to look at Mr Hyde's comments and take them into account. The Opposition should retreat from the mindless attitude that it has adopted to date.

During Question Time today there have been a number of interjections from Senator Withers and Senator Walters about somebody called Bruce. I do not know which of them has a strange relationship with somebody of that name. Whichever it is, let me remind the Senate that the Government took courageous decisions, which it knew would be unpopular, before the Bruce by-election. At that by- election, those unpopular decisions having been taken, only one per cent of the electorate were prepared to shift their confidence to the mealy-mouthed Opposition which has devoted its energies to defending entrenched privilege in this country. Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on notice.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I draw your attention to the fact that the hour has not yet expired and the Leader of the Government in the Senate has asked for questions to be put on notice.
—Order! The Leader of the Government has asked for further questions to be placed on notice; it is a matter for the Senate. I understand that Senator Gareth Evans has an answer to a question.
—That is a change.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL AUSTRALIAN AIR FORCE FLIGHTS OVER TASMANIA

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a change in this case because I am finally giving an answer to a question asked on numerous occasions by Senator Walters, who has sought for strange and exotic reasons known only to herself to have tabled in this place aircraft movement records relating to certain flights which took place over Tasmania. I am able to inform the honourable senator that that material is now available, and I table it accordingly. I take the opportunity, in giving a further answer to this question, of saying that Senator Walters, I am afraid, waxed indignant in the adjournment debate last Thursday night on the basis of a perceived breach of undertaking on my part to table these papers before the Senate rose that day. I inform her that that was a misunderstanding. I was giving no such undertaking. I was indicating that I would ensure that she had the papers before the Senate rose for the session, and the context in which I gave that answer would make that perfectly clear.

—Whilst I am on my feet, perhaps you will permit me, Mr President, to give further and better particulars on the question raised by Senator Elstob about the potential financial implications to the Commonwealth of the New South Wales proposal for a no-fault accident compensation scheme. The answer to that part of the honourable senator's question is essentially this: The key feature of long term reform in this area will be the financial involvement of the Commonwealth. As the New South Wales paper makes clear, the proposed scheme would produce significant financial advantage for the Commonwealth by, first of all, reducing social security benefit payments to those who do not at present get compensation, and, secondly, by increasing revenue by providing periodic payments which are subject to taxation. The financial advantage of the scheme and the fact that it would provide compensation for the estimated one-third of traffic accident victims who currently get no compensation make the Government optimistic that real reform can at last be achieved in this area.

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. While the Attorney- General is in the mood for answering questions, I wonder whether he would reconsider his refusal to answer a question of mine earlier at Question Time.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—Mr President, last week Senator Robertson asked me a supplementary question without notice concerning the building of railways by the Commonwealth since 1911. I am now able to provide the following information on the major new railways whose building was initiated by Commonwealth governments. Those commenced by Labor governments were the Kalgoorlie to Port Augusta railway in 1911 and the Tarcoola to Alice Springs railway in 1974. Those commenced by Conservative governments were the Pine Creek to Katherine River railway in 1913, the Katherine to Birdum railway in 1923 and the Oodnadatta to Alice Springs railway in 1926. Since 1911 a number of standardisations of existing railways have been commenced by Commonwealth governments of both political persuasions. A Labor government commenced the Adelaide-Crystal Brook project in 1974. Those of significance commenced by Conservative governments were: Grafton to South Brisbane in 1924; Albury to Melbourne in 1958; Kalgoorlie to Perth in 1961; and Port Pirie to Broken Hill in 1963.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The continuing confusion and distress caused by the Government's hastily conceived and ill-explained changes to lump-sum superannuation.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition brings forward this matter of public importance because it believes there is just criticism of the Government for its continuing confusion and the distress that has been caused by the changes that were made to lump sum superannuation payments in the mini-Budget announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on 19 May. We have brought this forward in the terms that it was a hastily conceived change and that it has also been ill-explained. I think that both of those statements lead me to suggest that its hastily conceived nature can be verified by the statements that have been made by members of the Government and by those who support them. Although the Treasurer stated on 19 May in his economic statement-I refer to page 18 of it-that it was a policy change that had had considerable consultation and a comprehensive review, I think that we must agree that it could hardly have had that comprehensive review considering the statements that have been made by the numbers of people who are interested in the decision that was taken and by the numbers of people who are affected by it.

SPEECH.PARA: If the decision had not been hastily conceived and had been the subject of comprehensive review, as stated by the Treasurer in his statement to the Parliament, we would need to wonder why the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was able to be reported in the Australian of 22 April as saying words to the effect that the worry about superannuation tax changes was unfounded. I am not aware of any withdrawal of that statement by the Prime Minister. He led the people of Australia to believe that it was an unfounded worry and that there were not to be changes to the methods of taxing superannuation payments. I would go further and say that if it had been the subject of comprehensive review, as stated by the Treasurer, it is of concern to see the letter signed by the Attorney-General on 12 May which was sent to a constituent and which was the subject of a question addressed to him today. In that letter he stated:

I can advise that the new Labor Government has not taken any decision in this regard and any consideration of the matter could only take place in the budget context when all areas of government income and expenditure are announced.

That letter was signed by the Attorney-General on 12 May. If we accept the Treasurer's statement to the Parliament that there was a comprehensive review we would need to ask whether there was any advice by the Attorney-General as to the nature of the legislation required for the changes that were envisaged in the statement. We would need to ask why the Attorney-General, on 12 May, chose to sign a letter-regardless of whether it was produced by a word processor-to a constituent in those terms. If it were a policy on which a comprehensive review had been undertaken one would wonder why someone such as the Honourable Paul Landa, the Acting Treasurer of New South Wales, could write to a member of the New South Wales Parliament on 24 April and state:

The matter raised was only speculation at that stage and I understand that the Federal Government has now announced that it does not intend to increase the tax rate on lump sum superannuation payments.

That statement by the Acting Treasurer of New South Wales was made as a result of the statement by the Prime Minister I quoted earlier which was printed in the Australian of that earlier date and in which he said that any worry was unfounded and that there was to be no change made to the arrangements. These statements by members of the Australian Labor Party make us wonder whether this matter was subject to comprehensive review. If that were so one would need to question the understanding of the Australian Council of Trade Unions executive. Mr Kelty, in an interview reported in the Sydney Morning Herald on 26 May, said that his meeting with the Prime Minister last month-that was April-had led him to believe 'that wage and salary earners' lump sum benefits would not be affected by any Government decisions'.

There is a further question as to whether the decision had been ill-conceived or hastily conceived and whether it had been the subject of the consultation that we had been led to expect would automatically occur under a prices and incomes arrangement which was to solve all problems between the incoming Government and the trade union movement. I would have to suggest that it would have been expected that changes to superannuation payments would have been the subject of consultation in view of the arrangements in the prices and incomes policy. Yet Mr Kelty has said that, according to his understanding with the Prime Minister in April, there was to be no change. One would also need to ask whether there had been consultation on any of the factors related to the policy change when we now know that there is a government and ACTU working party to study the lump sum taxation proposals in order to sort out exactly what is to be envisaged in the various facets of the scheme. This working party will need to address itself to a number of the arrangements the Government undoubtedly has in its mind as it has moved into this area of taxing the lump sum payments of people who receive them through the superannuation schemes of this country.

In looking at the ill-conceived nature of the change we probably do need to go back to the philosophy of the mini-Budget, of the economic statement of the Treasurer last week, because the philosopy in that statement penalises those in the community who have tried to provide for their own superannuation, who have been thrifty enough to get themselves involved in superannuation policies. That economic policy statement is certainly an attack on the thrifty because if we were to broaden the degree of effect that it has we would find that people who had saved their money to invest it in retirement through superannuation, had invested in health care, in sending children to private schools or in the jobs of others by investing in Australian industry or by being small shareholders in companies, or had worked hard to increase their income and saved for a home, would be penalised by an economic statement such as that of 19 May. That gets to the philosophy of the changes to the superannuation scheme that were announced by the Treasurer at that time.

As I understand it, there were no consultations with the life assurers or the superannuation funds prior to the policy change. Since the announcement of the change a number of statements have been made by those concerned with superannuation arrangements. I understand some consultation has taken place since that announcement was made. It would have to be described as an ill- explained change because I doubt whether anyone yet knows the full implications of the Government's proposals. We were told yesterday by the media announcements which followed some Cabinet decisions that there were to be some slight changes at the margins with regard to what had been announced on 19 May. The Treasurer was able to assure us that those changes made no difference to the revenue proposals. So they are changes at the margins. In fact, some of the changes that he announced yesterday were changes that were understood to be part of the original arrangement.

Perhaps when considering the arrangements with regard to superannuation lump sum payments we ought to go back to the scheme that previously existed. The old arrangement, which had existed for many years, had the effect in regard to taxable income that a person receiving a lump sum had 5 per cent of that lump sum included in his assessable income for the year of receipt. That arrangement was made in that way because it was accepted that as that lump sum was received there would be an earning rate on it, and the rate of 5 per cent was the rate agreed to at that time. It is true that since the time of that arrangement there may have been a greater earning rate on the lump sum than 5 per cent, and if the Government had wished to review that part of the arrangement there may not have been the concern, alarm and distress that was caused by the change which was announced.

People accepted that there was some earning rate and 5 per cent was imputed as an earning in the year in which that lump sum was received. Then each year, as that lump sum was invested, they were assessed on the income which was earned from those funds which they had invested for the future. That rate might have been somewhere around 5 per cent, or it might have been greater if they were able to make advantageous arrangements. I do not think anyone argued that the principle that in the year a person received a lump sum it was imputed that he had some earnings on it was not sound. It was certainly not imputed that a person had earnings at the marginal tax rate. That is the big difference in the philosophy between what was the original arrangement and what is now envisaged by the Government.

The change which I understand the Treasurer has now announced, which seems to placate some sections of the community but not all, is that employee contributions received as a lump sum or converted into an annuity will now not be taxable. That is probably fair enough, but that was almost implied in what was said by the Treasurer in his earlier announcement. I do not think that made any concession at all to what had been announced earlier or what was at least some people's understanding of it.

He has also announced that the proportion of the lump sum which will be taxable will be based on the period of service to the changeover date and its relationship to the total service of the employee concerned. I would have thought that could have been almost implied in what he said earlier about work done after the date of the announcement on 19 May. From the wording with regard to services rendered or work done after that date, one could have been looking at a period of time and not at an actuarial assessment from one period to another. So I do not know that the changes have alleviated in any way a policy which has vastly changed superannuation arrangements in this country.

The Treasurer in his announcement has shown the Government's philosophy with regard to capital gains or the holding of capital. Perhaps that is what ought to be looked at as we review what the Government is doing in this policy. To suggest that under this economic arrangement the only part of a sum paid to a person after his working lifetime which can be non-taxable is the part that he contributed himself shows that there is very little conscious desire on the part of the Government to see Australians emerge from their working lifetime with any form of capital accretion or capital improvement in their circumstances. This is why so many members of the trade union movement, in particular Barrie Unsworth of the Labor Council of New South Wales, have been so assertive in the things they have said about this change in people's expectations for their retirement.

The Treasurer, at the same time as announcing these changes to the superannuation arrangements, announced the introduction of income testing for the age pension for persons of 70 years of age and over. I believe that in linking those two changes we see the philosophy of the Labor Government with regard to Australians holding any sort of capital: If they do, there will be a punitive tax on it. In this policy we see the beginnings of the capital gains tax which the Government would dearly love to introduce and which quite obviously it has in its sights as a means of raising revenue in the future. That is why alarm is being expressed. The consultations we might have expected on the prices and income accord arranged with the trade unions apparently did not occur . Over 80 per cent of participants in private superannuation schemes take their benefits in a lump sum. It seems to me that consultation with those who may have been able to give that information to the Government would have been very profitable. It seems to me that the sorts of things that have alarmed people with regard to the treatment of the payment of a lump sum on death or on forced retirement through invalidity-the sorts of things that perhaps will need to be worked out through the working party-could have been thought through before the Government embarked on its change to the superannuation entitlements of Australian people.
The Treasurer said in the introductory remarks in his economic statement that he wanted to see that those who received occupational superannuation were those more in need. He said:
. . . occupational superannuation goes mostly to people who are neither needy nor poor . . .

That is not what we are hearing from the trade union movement. If one looks at the opportunities which a working family man has to accumulate any sort of capital through his working life, one can hardly come to the conclusion that he will be able to do more than provide for his own needs and those of his family. Therefore, at time of retirement he would expect, as the result of making contributions to a superannuation scheme, to have some sort of entitlement, one that, according to trade union leaders, would enable him to perhaps pay off his home or improve his position in whatever way he chooses. In regard to the proposed change, I say that the choice to improve one's circumstances as a result of having contributed to a superannuation fund will be removed.

The Opposition has brought forward this matter of public importance because it believes that the alarm that was caused by this ill-conceived and ill-explained proposal, which was announced on 19 May without any preliminary understanding on the part of the Treaserur (Mr Keating) and despite the assurances that had been given by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in April, has caused many people to be very deeply concerned about future arrangements, as they will be personally affected. To proceed with these sorts of economic policies without first looking completely at the effect that they will have is not the right way to deal with them. When I was the Minister for Social Security I always found that it was a matter of concern and resentment if benefits enjoyed were withdrawn. Unless an equitable reason for so doing can be given, there will indeed be resentment. In this case, the combined effect of taxing the entitlement to lump sum superannuation and of withdrawing the income test free pension at the age of 70 has vastly changed the expectations of the great bulk of the Australian work force.

It is argued that benefits accrued until 30 June of this year will not be changed, but that is of little consequence to those who find that, in respect of the next 15 or 20 years, vast changes are to be made which will affect the amount of superannuation to which they will be entitled upon retirement. For all these reasons the Opposition has brought forward this matter of public importance. My colleagues have matters of detail to which they wish to address themselves. I wish simply to refer to the hastily conceived and ill-explained policy of the Government and to the concern that quite justifiably has been generated in the Australian community because of this precipitant change to superannuation entitlements and to age pensions for people over 70.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can well understand Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle's pique. After all, in 1980 she was a member of the razor gang which procrastinated for eight months and finally claimed ultimate savings of $560m, many of which were one-off savings and most of which were never achieved. By contrast with that dismal record, the expenditure review committee of this Government produced, in a very much shorter time, projected savings of almost $1 billion in the next financial year, more than $2 billion in the year after and, beyond that period, savings at a very slightly greater rate. It is no surprise to find that the Liberal Party and Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, in particular, as one who was directly involved in the last exercise, feel some pique that this Government has been so much more successful than was the discredited government which it replaced. I observe in passing that it is no surprise either to find the Liberal Party defending tax rorts which imposed penalties on the great bulk of the Australian population-tax rorts, most of which the Liberal Party initiated or exacerbated.

SPEECH.PARA: In the 19 May statement the essential changes to the taxation of superannuation lump sum payments were announced. I wish to deal first with another matter raised by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle. It concerns a statement of the Prime Minister which was reported in the Press on 22 April. I have in front of me a copy of the Australian of that day. It quotes the Prime Minister directly, as stating:
. . . there has been some concern about accelerated resignations. I think I can say I will have the matter before Cabinet so it can be decided.
The article goes on to quote the Prime Minister as having said:
Without pre-empting the decisions that have to be made in the Cabinet procedures, I think you will find there has been no basis for the speculation . . .

I stress that the speculation, in the Prime Minister's words, was 'concern about accelerated resignations'. The only reason for accelerated resignations would be a fear that lump sum entitlements already accrued would be subject to different taxation arrangements; in other words, they would be taxed retrospectively. It was clearly in that frame of reference that the Prime Minister spoke. The Prime Minister guaranteed that there would be no retrospective element, and there is no retrospective element.

I return to the statement of 19 May. The essential features of the changes were as follows: Firstly, lump sum entitlements accrued to that time would be taxed at the previous rate; that is, only 5 per cent of the lump sum would be included , as Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle said, as assessable income in a tax return. Secondly, entitlements accrued after that date would be taxed at a rate of 30 per cent or perhaps higher, with two exceptions, both of which were clearly spelt out in the statement by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on that night-firstly, a partial exception that a person's own contributions, whether made before or after 19 May, would continue to be taken tax free as a lump sum; and, secondly, that a 100 per cent lump sum payment would not be subject to tax at all, provided it was used to purchase an annuity to produce a lifetime income for the superannuitant. As I said, a person's own contributions before that date would be taxed at the old rate and such contributions after that date would be completely exempt from tax.

The basis upon which entitlements or accruals would be determined was clarified by the Treasurer yesterday after discussion with the superannuation funds. The Treasurer announced that the basis of accrual would be period of service. An alternative, which I think Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle also mentioned, would be an actuarial calculation of the amount which was actually available to be withdrawn on that date if the superannuitant chose to withdraw it. If the actuarial choice were taken by the Government it was essential that an immediate cut-off point accompany it. If that basis of assessment had been chosen it would have been possible to amend the rules of funds before 30 June if that was to be stated as the changeover date. Since the former option, that is, a proportional accrual, was chosen by the Government there was no need for an immediate 19 May cut-off date. For that reason and for reasons of accountancy convenience, the Treasurer announced that the changeover date would be 30 June next.

The Treasurer also gave more details yesterday on roll-over provisions. There are two important matters yet to be settled-first, the portability of superannuation entitlements and, secondly, the details of the proposed annuity scheme. Discussions on both of those matters are proceeding with the funds, the Australian Council of Trade Unions and other interested bodies. I stress that by the very nature of these changes they could not be discussed prior to essential announcement by the Government. They could not be discussed for the very reasons that prompted the Prime Minister on 22 April to make his statement.
