He said that there would be concern about accelerated resignations from people who feared that there would be retrospective changes. I ask the Senate to visualise the following situation: Supposing the Government had announced at the beginning of April that it was reviewing taxation arrangements of lump sum payments. We have already seen from the Liberal Party when it was still in government how irresponsible it can be in promoting speculation and panic about financial matters. The former Prime Minister tried to start a run on the banks; he failed. The present leader of the Liberal Party tried to start a run on the dollar and, to the great cost of the Australian nation, he succeeded.

If this Government had announced in April that it was reviewing and holding discussions with the life offices regarding annuity payments and the taxation of lump sum entitlements there is absolutely no doubt that the present irresponsible Leader of the Liberal Party would have followed the example he set in February and would have started a run on the funds. There was an unsuccessful attempt to start a run on the banks; a successful attempt to start a run on the dollar and he would have started a run on the funds. I observe in passing that the behaviour of the Liberal Party and of its present leader in particular, both before and since the election, is reminiscent of Adolf Hitler telling Speer to destroy Germany in the dying days of the Third Reich.

The situation with respect to the taxation of lump sum entitlements prior to 19 May was this: Contributions made to funds by employers, and in some cases by employees, were deductible from the taxable income of the employer and of the employee where the employee's contribution qualified. The income received on those contributions in the funds was exempt from taxation. This was in contrast of course to alternative forms of savings. The interest earned on deposits in savings banks and government bonds is fully taxable. The income on deposits and investments made with superannuation funds was exempt from tax. At the end of a period of contribution, which in most instances was very short-I will return to that later-95 per cent of the sum taken out of the fund was exempt from taxation . Let us remember that almost all of the money paid in was claimed as a tax deduction and the interest earned on the payments in was tax exempt throughout the period the amounts were in the fund. When the amount was finally withdrawn 95 per cent of it was exempt from tax.

The annual cost to revenue of all of those positively discriminatory conditions was estimated to be nearly $2 billion and rapidly escalating. The person who had prior to 19 May claimed a tax deduction through the employer, and in some instances from his own income, received the benefits of tax-free income in the funds. Under the previous arrangements that person could take a lump sum payment , 95 per cent of which was exempt from tax, and then-thanks to Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, who presided over this change in 1976 when she changed the basis of testing for the age pension from a means test to an income test-

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to change that?

—It is very complicated to change it back now. The matter has been investigated. It is another legacy with which this Government has to cope and which was inherited from the irresponsible Government which this Government has replaced. I simply state the fact that thanks to the changes made by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle in 1976 the people who had obtained all of those benefits that I have stipulated could then invest the lump sum, 95 per cent of which was tax free, in an investment which received capital appreciation rather than income and were then entitled to receive an age pension as well. This is an example of the double-dipping syndrome.

SPEECH.PARA: For all of those concessions, in excess of $2 billion, most of the working age population of Australia, and the 58 per cent who have never had the opportunity to be in a superannuation fund, paid the penalty. The Australian Bureau of Statistics survey of 1979 showed that only 42 per cent of employees working more than 20 hours a week were in superannuation funds. I might add that slightly over 20 per cent of women were in superannuation funds. The women were in a position to take substantially less advantage of the concessions than were men, a matter which I might have thought would be of some interest to Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle and some of the other women senators on the other side. The concession was predominately one for the higher income groups, and the lump sums , when taken, were even more heavily skewed towards the rich. A good example, I suppose, of that and of the feather bedded groups which will be affected ultimately by these changes is the airline pilots who were threatening to go on strike a week ago. Let us look at Boeing 727 airline pilots. They receive salaries of up to $60,000 and work a 74-hour month. Their salaries have increased by 42 per cent since July 1980 and their lump sum entitlements after--

TALK.START.PARA: —Almost as much as a Minister.

—I will refer to politicians in a minute. I thank Senator Sir John Carrick for reminding me. Lump sum entitlements after a period of 25 to 30 years are between $350,000 and $400,000. The class of people for which this Opposition is fighting today has salaries of $60,000 for a 74-hour month, and lump sum entitlements, tax free after 24 or 30 years, of $350,000 to $400,000.
—Not many women amongst them, either.
—No women, I believe, fly 727s.
—Tell us about the Federated Ironworkers Association of Australia-all the members in it.

—There is a misconception, I fear, among some people who purport to speak for blue collar workers about this matter, and that is unfortunate. I say 'purport to speak for blue collar workers', and I make no further comment except to say that the facts speak for themselves. Fifty-eight per cent of the employed population has no superannuation. Those who do have superannuation are heavily concentrated in the higher paid occupations. Those who take advantage of the lump sum tax provisions are even more heavily concentrated in the upper income ranges. The equity facts speak for themselves.

SPEECH.PARA: We are alleged, according to the terms of this matter of public importance, to have hastily conceived this idea. I suppose compared to the pusillanimity and prevarication which were the hallmarks of the previous Government the action was hasty, and it needed to be. We had to do something about the $9.6 billion projected deficit which we inherited from the discredited previous Government. We did not prevaricate for eight months, as did the razor gang, of which Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle was a member, to produce meagre, inconsequential projected savings, most of which were never realised. Our action was perhaps hasty in its execution but it was not hasty in its conception. The report of the Asprey Taxation Review Committee and the report of the Hancock National Superannuation Committee of Inquiry which lay on the table throughout the seven dark years of Fraserism, both recommended that this system had to be changed. The Hancock Committee said:

The investigations and discussion underlying this report . . . have made it clear to us that to design a rational and equitable superannuation system embodying lump sums which are nearly tax-free is an impossibility.
The Asprey Committee stated:
If a person is entitled to a lump sum he should be quite free to receive it, but he should not gain an unwarranted tax advantage in doing so.

Throughout the seven dark years of the Fraser Government those reports lay on the table. No action was taken because of the cowardice and irresponsibility which were the hallmarks of that Government. On this subject, the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) has stated:
We were in government for decades and we never did this.

That was to their eternal shame. Senator Button earlier today quoted from an article by the former honourable member for Moore, but it bears repeating because it is very important. I commend it to those members of the Opposition, if there are any, who want to take a serious and responsible interest in the government of this country. The former honourable member for Moore, Mr Hyde, in an article in the Australian Financial Review last week, stated:
I listened to Mr Keating's mini-Budget speech with interest and discomfort. For the main part the mini-Budget was a catalogue of things that the Liberals should have done lone ago . . .
. . . to start to take away the tax privileges of occupational superannuants who get two bites at the cherry, are policy changes with long-term fiscal benefit.

I do not know whether the commendable honesty displayed in that article by the former honourable member for Moore is a cause or an effect of losing his seat. But we have seen precious little evidence of honesty and responsibility from the previous Government, the present Opposition.

I make one final point. Anyone who listened to Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle and was unaware of the facts may have gained the impression that superannuation policies which are finalised as lump sums are, in the main, taken out by people and contributed to for the greater part of their working lives. A survey by the Australian Bureau of Statistics in May 1979, which, I understand, is the latest available evidence, shows that 61 per cent of the schemes from which lump sum payments were taken had contribution periods of 10 years or less, and 34 per cent had contribution periods of five years or less. Finally, Commonwealth public servants-and State public servants in the majority of States-were never entitled to withdraw as a lump sum of contributions made by the employer. That situation will continue. For the benefit of the Opposition, I again quote the former honourable member for Moore:
The opposition must build its reputation and it should resist any temptation to score cheap political points.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating today a matter of public importance in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The continuing confusion and distress caused by the Government's hastily conceived and ill-explained changes to lump-sum superannuation.

The projected changes in the basis of assessment of lump sum payments, when considered in conjunction with the implications of the introduction of taxation on capital gains in the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill, which is now in this House, mark a new era of an attack by this new Government on capital structures that could fundamentally change the whole nature of the ownership of property in Australia. The company tax Bill provides that realised capital profits from assets that were held for generations will now, artificially, by an absurd hypothetical assumption, be subject to tax if realised under certain conditions since 1972. This is the beginning of a fundamental attack on all of those people who seek to acquire or build capital. What sort of society will we have in future? Why is this Government against capital formations? I suggest that it is a manifestation very early in the period of this Parliament of its implementation of socialist ideals of the very worst kind.

Many people in society seek an early retirement for a number of reasons-stress, business pressures, sickness and so on. The taking of a lump sum as a consequence enables such people to set up an alternative career or to buy into a new business. In future that opportunity will be denied to them. That option will be taken away by this regressive legislation. Other people, because of the nature of their occupation, retire somewhat early in life. People from the defence forces-the Australian Army, the Australian Navy and the Royal Australian Air Force-are typical of people who retire in their 40s or 50s. They take a lump sum and they have the opportunity nowadays to move into a new occupation, a new vocation. If they are locked into a superannuation-type scheme they are locked into dependence on government for a long time.

What about the cost? It is far cheaper for the Government to pay a lump sum than to pay the continuing cost of an annuity or a pension. The cost benefits to a nation certainly favour a lump sum payment compared with a pension paid over eight years. Look at the cost and the equity at the same time. We are tending to force people more and more on to government handouts, government pensions. A lump sum often allows people for the first time in their life to pay off their home-to get out of the hands of insurers, money lenders.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the contrary.

—I ask Senator Tate to think of a person who, for example, moves from Tasmania to Sydney and who wants to buy a house of comparable standard. He has to mortgage himself to the hilt, perhaps to the extent of $80,000. A lump sum payment on retirement gives him the opportunity, for the first time, to pay off that house. What does the Government expect him to do? Does it expect him to seek alternative accommodation away from his friends, to go back into the bush or somewhere else, into less expensive accommodation while continuing to receive a pension? The Government is seeking to force people out of their chosen way of life. It is trying to force people, I suggest, to stay in employment against their will. It is attempting to limit the choice of people who, for example, want to move from one vocation to another. I suggest again that this is the thin edge of the wedge of an attack on capital formation.

SPEECH.PARA: Section 26 (d) of the Income Tax Assessment Act which has been there for years provides that only 5 per cent of a lump sum payment received as a consequence of retirement is subject to inclusion in taxable income. Service after 30 June 1983 will be subject to tax, if received in a lump sum, at rates which are pretty savage. Tax payable will be 30 per cent on all amounts up to $125,000, 46 per cent on the next $100,000 and 60 per cent on amounts over $225,0000. Not much after tax lump sums will be left for these people who receive lump sum payments. The Government appears to be deliberately forcing people not to take lump sum payments. It will not pay people to take lump sum payments.

TALK.START.PARA: —They can take an annuity.

—That is true. There is an opportunity for a taxpayer, within 90 days, to convert his lump sum payment into an annuity. What great changes have been made in exempting employee contributions? The present legislation before the projected changes provides that the annuity will be taxable and the undeducted purchase price may be taken as a legitimate deduction to get the net taxable amount. Because the Government has lifted the threshold of the concessional rebate from $1,590 to $2,000, few ordinary workers-I think the iron workers were mentioned-will benefit from that concessional rebate. The concession of not taxing the employee's contribution is a lot of hot air when one examines the full extent of it and compares it with the existing legislation now on the statute books-it has been there for ages-under section 26AA. Tremendous confusion exists in the community as this matter of public importance states.

SPEECH.PARA: Shortly after the election of the Labor Government there were threatened wholesale resignations from industry because people feared that they would have to pay full tax on their lump sum payment. Later it was rumoured that the first $100,000 would be exempt from tax. Still the uncertainty continued. Treasurer Keating was understood to have warned his Cabinet colleagues of the dangers of introducing a mini-Budget. He said that there were dangers to this new Government in implementing hastily, ill-conceived measures. He was overruled. As a result, we have chaos. Who are the sufferers? The ordinary working men of Australia.
In the Australian of 22 April 1983 Bob Hawke sought to allay a lot of the fears of the people. An article in the Australian stated:
The Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, will seek Cabinet agreement to hold the tax on lump-sum superannuation payments at 5 per cent.
Mr Hawke's move is in reaction to rumours in the superannuation industry that tax on lump-sum payments is about to rise.
The rumours have led to several resignations to take advantage of the present very low tax.

This is another example of the confusion and the inability of people to deal with the situation. Taking into account the reversal in policy by Messrs Keating and Hawke one may well ask: Who is really running this country and who is making the decisions? The only major change in yesterday's announcement was in the implementation date, from 19 May to 30 June. I think everybody agrees that that change makes sense because the original date was a stupid date in the first place.

Let us look at some outside comments. An editorial in the Examiner stated that the nature of the reform was such that the Government may come to regret it. The editorial believed that it was a crude solution to the abuse of lump sum schemes and the main victims were the hard working, provident middle class. They were the people who are the main victims. A senior superannuation expert said that the scheme obviously was hastily put together and the details were not thought through.

What about Mr Keating's statement? It failed to deal with the issue of lump sum payments to spouses and children of people who die. This raises important questions. The fear is that the benefit will be taxed in full. In other words, it is another form of death duty. All those people should take note of the potential of this legislation.

During the election campaign former Prime Minister Fraser warned that people may have to put some of their savings under the bed. He was turned upon in a most vicious manner and with derision by Mr Hawke. In retrospect, looking at this decision and other decisions, how prophetic the remarks of former Prime Minister Fraser were.

The Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) raised the question of the Asprey Taxation Review Committee, particularly in relation to this area. Why did not this Government, at the first opportunity, implement the recommendations of that Committee? This Government has mucked it up. It has failed to follow the recommendations of the Asprey Committee. In fact, it has gone much further than any of the recommendations of the Asprey Committee. Asprey acknowledged that there was some need to remove a disparity between pensions and lump sum payments . The Asprey Committee gave the formula to neutralise the traditional differences between pensions and lump sum payments. Its recommendation was based on a percentage which effectively brought a commutation of a lump sum back to a pension equivalent. The Hawke Government has gone far beyond that recommendation . Look at the rates that will apply. Why have people in the past shied away from pensions towards lump sum payments? They have done so because of inflation. Private sector employers, unlike public sector employers, are unable to provide all their employees with indexed pensions.

Are we witnessing the beginning of a national superannuation scheme? If it is, how will the Government finance such a scheme? The Government has talked about inheriting a deficit this year of $4.6 billion and of inheriting a deficit next year, if the projected figures are correct, of over $9 billion. Despite the size of the deficits it does not take adequate steps to try to reduce it. Major questions have to be answered. What about all those people who have life assurance policies that will mature upon their retirement at 65 years of age? Will such policies be subject to tax? What about whole of life policies? A whole area of uncertainty exists in relation to lump sum payments. When the Australian Labor Party talks about lump sum payments it is not talking in the restricted sense about lump sum payments on retirement; it is talking about lump sum payments per se. As such, it opens up a very wide ambit of uncertainty.

Young people, for example those in their early 20s, who are single, move from job to job just to get experience. They will find on leaving their jobs that at least 30 per cent of their lump sum superannuation payment will be taxable. People leaving employment after only a few years in a job will find that the net amount that they will receive for a lump sum will not even be equal to their own contributions. Blue collar workers and young people seeking experience frequently move from job to job. These are some of the people who will be the main victims of this vicious change. It is about time that the people of Australia knew the full extent of how this will hurt the ordinary young person trying to make a start in life, changing from one job to another. Such a person will not get the benefit of a concessional rebate now with the threshold now raised to $2,000.

No wonder storms of protest are coming from the union movement and middle Australia. Is it any wonder that we saw a swing of 4 per cent against the Government in the Bruce by-election? Australians are beginning to wake up to the wide impact of some of these changes. The rhetoric of 'trying to bring Australia together' is quite good. But the legislation and the specifics are so broad that they will cut across this whole idea of consensus.

I believe that the ineptitude that has been shown with lump sum changes raises serious questions about the Government's ability to handle matters in the forthcoming August Budget. Further, one wonders whether we will see widespread introduction of capital gains tax. Individuals-middle Australians-through the direct taxation system, pay the bulk of tax in Australia. Through these sorts of measures they will continue to pay a proportionately higher amount of tax. The only way to get Australia operating in a viable way again and to eliminate the Budget deficit is to get the economy moving. None of these measures will achieve this purpose. These measures will lead people away from superannuation towards trying to accumulate savings through unit trusts and other devices. I think such a trend would be regrettable and regressive. Therefore, I support the matter of public importance. There is continuing confusion. I call upon the Government to clarify its position urgently and immediately to remove this distress from the ordinary working people of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would not deny that there has been some confusion and anxiety in the community in relation to the Labor Government's announcements concerning superannuation entitlements and their taxing. If there is anything we as a Government have learned it is that, in conjunction with acting courageously, it is necessary to make very clear explanations of that action. We are now some days on from the announcement of the mini-Budget. Much has been clarified, yet the Liberal and National Parties continue to try to maintain a level of hysteria in the community which is only unsettling to superannuitants and those facing retirement. As one commentator has said, an incredible rash of bloody-mindedness seems to have seized the Opposition. It is trying to score every political point that it can.

SPEECH.PARA: I can assure honourable senators and those listening to the debate that the Government will not be bowed by the Opposition's incredibly selfish attitude in trying to muddy the waters. The Government will remain firm and committed to the basic principles and the tough decision which it announced. If that decision were fundamentally denied it would bring back the memories of the seven years of opportunistic politics of the Fraser Government. We will stand firmly by that decision. I, for one, am very proud to be part of a Government which has as its Treasurer a man who has taken a tough decision and will not back away. What makes all the humbug and bluster from honourable senators on the other side of the chamber all that harder to bear is that they know that the decision is the correct and necessary one. All the committees which have looked at this matter over the years have reported and recommended to that effect. So much so is this the correct decision that David Potts, the economics editor for the Australian newspaper, had this to say in his article entitled 'At least Labor has some guts ':
The reforms were well overdue, and for the most part more equitable.

Claude Forell of the Melbourne Age wrote an article headed 'Courage in the mini- Budget'. That is the type of response from those who are recognised as being amongst the most respected commentators in Australia. As I have said, that makes all the humbug and bluster all the harder to listen to.

What are these Government changes all about? We as a nation are concerned with ensuring that retirement incomes are available to the elderly in our community. Our concern as Australians in a civilised and decent society is to ensure that those who reach a stage in their lives where they are no longer contributing paid labour to the work force are able to live at an assured level of dignity, as is their due. An income to achieve that can be derived from superannuation funds to which a person, as an employee, has contributed over a number of years, or it can be derived from the Department of the Treasury, which of course is supported by the working taxpayers of this country, as a pension under the social security system.

If people can make self-provision through a superannuation scheme that should occur. That should provide the means of income in retirement. A person ought not to be able to take the superannuation as a capital lump sum and deal with it in a way which does not attract or generate any great income and in addition take a pension from the public purse. The extremely generous taxing of the lump sum- only 5 per cent of it was taxed-reflected recognition that the community, the taxpayers and the Federal revenue should forgo ordinary taxing of that amount in order to encourage people to make provision for their retirement through superannuation funds. In fact it has been estimated that some $2 billion is forgone by the Treasury in dealing so generously with those lump sums. That would not be so bad if the lump sums were converted into an annual income which was then used to sustain the persons concerned-the superannuitants-through their retired years.

Taxpayers have to find money for a social security pension to support those people with a lump sum stashed away in a non-income bearing manner. So we have a form of double dipping into the public purse. That double dipping causes great hardship for the great majority of people still in the work force sustaining those who have retired. Quite simply, that sort of rort had to be stopped. As I have said, that was generally acknowledged by all commentators and all committees who reported and recommended courses of action to the Government. The Government's purpose is to try to restore a situation where self-provision for the years of retirement is encouraged and works so that one has an annual income generated by the suitable investment of the moneys that have accrued in a superannuation arrangement. That seems to me to be perfectly sensible.

Events over the last few days have further clarified the situation. A non- retrospective taxing arrangement has been put forward to the Australian people. There is no panic whatsoever. Senator Watson spoke about people taking early retirement on the basis of rumours before the mini-Budget. There is no need for people to retire early to escape some punitive retrospective measure in these arrangements. All entitlements which accrue until 30 June this year will be dealt with under the old tax laws. The change will come into operation on 1 July ; nothing could be clearer than that. It will come into effect next financial year. That is a perfectly well understood concept.

An employee usually contributes to a superannuation fund which is supplemented by the employer. The employee's contributions taken as a lump sum at retirement will not be taxable at all. On the other hand, a person who provides for his or her own superannuation by paying, say, $1,200 a year without the benefit of employer contributions to the scheme, of course receives a deduction for that payment under our present tax laws. That is, that person gets a tax concession along the way. So if that person takes a lump sum at the end, that is subject to the standard rate of tax, usually 30 per cent. But even then, that whole lump sum can be rolled over into an annual income within 90 days and it does not then attract the lump sum tax.

That is the next point and the crucial point: That a lump sum that relates to service after 1 July this year will be subject to the new tax rules. However, that lump sum will be wholly exempt if converted to a pension or other annuity within a specified period-normally, 90 days. In other words, an employee, after retirement, has three months during which to assess the situation, and to discuss it with his bank manager or insurance fund adviser. Of course, if prudent, he will have undertaken discussions before he retired, and the retired person can roll over that lump sum into an annual income rather than pay the 30 per cent tax on the lump sum. Of course even there, I repeat, in relation to the employee's own contributions over the years, after 1 July, he can take that as a lump sum on retirement and no tax is payable. So there is a provision for some lump sum moneys which are not taxable, which provide for that expenditure on retirement which might add a holiday or some purchase of a household item, or help to pay off a mortagage or whatever, and then the rest of the money is rolled over into an annual income.

That is really the point: We have here devised what is acknowledged by all commentators to be a fair and equitable scheme. After all, where does the burden now most heavily fall in relation to the provision of revenue to sustain the present system and the payments of pensions to those who really ought to make self-provision for their retirement? This matter was completely misinterpreted by Senator Watson. It is the ordinary taxpayer who presently bears the heaviest burden in relation to our present arrangements, and most of those ordinary taxpayers do not belong to a superannuation scheme. Most low income earners within the private sector do not belong to a superannuation scheme at all. Only 45 per cent of the work force are members of a superannuation scheme anyway, and many of those are in the public sector. So, let us hear no more of the claim that this proposal will have a disastrous impact on the little man. The fact is that the little man, as I say, rarely has the benefit of such a scheme, yet he pays taxes now which are higher than they ought to be on two counts: First, revenue is forgone by the Government in that it taxes only 5 per cent of the lump sum and the revenue has to be made up in some other way; and insofar as many more pensions are paid to the elderly than needs to be the case, he is also making a greater contribution to the Government's taxation coffers than need be the case. So the ordinary working taxpayer of Australia is paying much more tax than he ought to pay under the present arrangements and that will not be so under the arrangements announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating).

The fact is that this measure will relieve some pressure on the ordinary taxpayer who is being asked to assist an elderly population which is growing as a segment of the general population. From looking at statistics based on a net intake by migration of 75,000 a year, one finds that in Australia the population of those over the age of 65 was about 14.9 per cent at 30 June 1981, but in only 10 years it will grow to 17.2 per cent. That is a difference of about 500,000 people. So one can see that the number of the elderly, the retired, who will be dependent on assistance from the community in one way or another will grow, and therefore this sort of arrangement needed to be brought into operation now.

This measure does nothing to impair the ability of Australians to ensure a steady and adequate income during retirement. In fact, it will inevitably encourage more planning by individuals and more competition between investment funds for their business. That is another point which was not properly addressed by Senator Watson. It is my belief that this arrangement will lead to a far better mobilisation and utilisation of our limited domestic savings, of the capital available in Australia. It will be directed more into the investment funds of the major insurance companies or into government bonds, which probably should have some factor built into them to protect their real value, and will thus allow major national expenditure to be financed.

Finally, this measure will allow governments and the electors to choose between lower taxes, as I have explained, as double dipping is done away with, or directing the equivalent tax moneys into other more needy forms of job creation and social welfare. That is the real point. This measure will provide greater tax moneys for other, more necessary, more urgent needs in our social and economic situation.
As Claude Forell in the final paragraph of his analysis of this proposal in the Age of 25 May said:

But the Government's priority must be to help those who cannot help themselves, and of these, the growing legion of the jobless are bearing a disproportionately heavy burden of a depressed economy. They are the forgotten people who deserve our first concern.

This measure will enable resources to be directed to their plight. Perhaps I may also quote the final paragraph of an article in the Australian Financial Review. That is not the most radical paper in Australia nor the most socialist or demonic. It had this to say:

What has happened to all the back slapping and goodwill of the Summit? At a time when one-third of our young people are unemployed, when we are in the worst economic situation since the 1930s, when our economy is slipping further and further in the international economic race, and when our medium term future is still far from bright, good old Aussie bloodymindedness prevails. Sadly, the phony heat generated over this issue encourages feelings of black despair for our longer term future as a nation.

I believe that we may feel the same despair about the present Opposition, the Liberal Party and the National Party, as they try, as I say, to muddy the waters , to keep an unsettled, confused state of mind among those who are about to retire, rather than acknowledging the very real benefits to the national economy , to ordinary Australian taxpayers and to the great proportion of the population which is aging, and which this measure represents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion consists of two basic statements. One is a statement relating to the confusion and distress caused by the Government's changes to the superannuation plan, and the other relates to the benefits or otherwise that will result from those changes. I do not think that there is an honourable senator in this place who is not aware and whose staff members are not aware that a great deal of confusion and distress in the community generally has resulted from the Government's proposals as put down by last week's mini-Budget. The calls that have been coming into my office-I am sure that they are much the same as the calls that have been coming into the offices of other honourable senators-show two basic things. One is a misunderstanding of the proposals-which I thought, as far as they went, were fairly clearly explained in the mini-Budget last week-and the second is a concern that there is no lump sum ceiling or threshold being provided in these superannuation changes.

SPEECH.PARA: The first point is covered by the fact that there is a consistent lack of understanding in the community about the changes which were proposed to occur on 19 May and which will now occur on 30 June; that is, the 5 per cent rule will continue for lump sums to which an entitlement has accrued prior to 30 June, and the new system will come into operation only for those amounts which accrue after that date-not for the amounts which are actually received, but for the portion which accrues. That has not been particularly well explained, and it has certainly not been particularly well understood by the majority of people in the electorate.

The second problem, the concern that there is no lump sum amount which does not attract punitive taxation measures, is a major one for those who are in receipt of only small superannuation payments, and that, of course, is the majority. These people have written to me and telephoned me expressing a need for, say, a $50,000 lump sum entitlement which will not be hit hard by taxation measures. These people argue-I think with some justification-that they have paid into a superannuation scheme all their lives or will continue to do so in the future with the intention of getting back on their retirement a lump sum with which they can do a number of things. The most favoured of those is to pay off their mortgage. I would point out at this stage that for every mortgage which is paid off, one more can be taken up by somebody else. The other point that concerns these people is that they have worked hard all their lives and they see their retirement as an opportunity for indulging in some luxuries such as a little travel, upgrading their home, a new car, a new washing machine, a new refrigerator or whatever turns them on. The third thing people like to do when they retire, particularly those who retire earlier than 65 years, is to buy into a small business. They like to use part of their lump sum payment as equity for that small business.

Of course, the concern, confusion and distress in the community over these matters are not helped by some rather misleading media reports which occurred early in April prior to the mini-Budget proposals being announced and which, for all I know, may have been due to misleading Government leaks. Two of these reports to which I would like to refer today appeared in the Australian Financial Review of 12 April and in the Sydney Morning Herald of 9 April. Both of these reports, regardless of whether they intended to, implied that some form of retrospectivity was going to be applied. The Australian Financial Review article headed 'Lump sum rumours send execs scuttling' made these points:
Rumours that the Federal Government intends to tax lump sum retirement benefits have led to a spate of early retirements by senior executives from Melbourne- based mining companies.

I interpolate at this point that I do not have a great deal of sympathy for these people who are leaping out of their employment and taking the lump sum payment simply on a rumour since it raises the question, in my mind at least, of what other rumours these people have operated on during their working lives. The article goes on to state:
A director of CRA Ltd, Mr L. J. Carden, said yesterday that 17 senior employees of CRA had opted last week for early retirement.

Questioned on rumours circulating in Melbourne that up to 60 executives had retired last week, Mr Carden said no more than 30 people throughout CRA and its associate companies had decided to take early retirement.
The article further states:

The rumours are unusually definite, suggesting that the Government intends to retain 5 per cent tax on lump sum benefits under $100,000 but to tax benefits of between $100,000 and $200,000 at 35 per cent and benefits over $200,000 at 60 per cent.

There certainly is an implication in that statement that the measures would apply retrospectively. An article appearing in the Sydney Morning Herald headed 'Tax rumours prompt early retirements' stated:
Contributors to some superannuation funds are rushing into early retirement to avoid an increase in the tax on lump-sum payments.
The company secretary of a large Australian group said yesterday: 'For the past three days we have had people coming through the door and taking their money and leaving the company.
. . . these people who have worked for us for 30 years or more are gambling with the balance of their careers and retiring on the basis of a rumour.'
. . . the Government should move quickly to make its intentions clear.

Much of the concern expressed in those lemming-like activities of certain executives and by people telephoning my office is, of course, groundless but there is no doubt that the quality and availability of information to set them straight is totally inadequate. My staff have been reduced to photocopying the paper handed out the night the mini-Budget was brought down and sending it to people, scribbled over as it is with comments I made at the time, because the White Paper is in short supply, newspaper reports show huge gaps and too many details are as yet undecided. Indeed, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has made additional statements in the last day or so after consultation with various groups that have been upset by the proposed changes. Even the Commonwealth superannuation fund counselling service was unable to give much information when contacted by my office yesterday at the request of a Commonwealth car driver who had me as a sort of captive audience when travelling between the airport and my home. He expressed some concern-justifiably so-over what will happen to him in 12 years when he retires. The problem is that most people seem to think that all past contributions will be taxed and that this will cut into the $30,000 to $50, 000 they plan to use on retirement to buy a house or the other things I mentioned. I give as an example a letter received recently which states:
I am writing to you . . . in the hope that your party will oppose most vigorously the 30 per cent tax on superannuation payments.

I am an invalid pensioner who could be classed as a 'battler' who was hurt whilst working as a coal miner. I have been struggling along on pension payments for some time, looking forward to the day when all the 'red tape' would be finalised and I would be able to collect my lump sum superannuation payment so that my wife, myself and 2 small children could have a bit more comfort in life and my children, aged 13 months and 6 weeks, could have a decent education. How can you educate 2 children on the invalid pension? This superannuation appears at last to be paid in the not too distant future, I hope.

My family and I presently live in a cramped one bedroom house. The majority of my superannuation was to finance a decent home and the rest would educate the children. This super should be approx. $50,000, which, I am sure you will agree, hardly puts me in the super-rich bracket.

Of course, this invalid pensioner will not be affected by the new 30 per cent tax because his lump sum accrued some years ago. But he does not realise that and he is getting worried and upset. Certainly, the matter of public importance brought forward by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle is correct in saying that there is a lot of confusion and distress in the community caused by the Government's ill-explained changes to the lump sum superannuation provisions. If the Government had acted less hastily, some informative literature presumably could have been prepared and people like the gentleman who wrote that letter could have been saved a fair degree of distress. Certainly the Australian Financial Review believes that the Government has been somewhat remiss in not providing lucid information about the matter. In an editorial of 23 May the Australian Financial Review stated:
Unfortunately, the superannuation decision shows all the signs of the haste in which it was taken . . .

It should, incidentally, be noted that the Government has no right to complain about media misinterpretation of any aspect of the statement: It placed great strains on the physical resources of the media by the way in which it made the document available.

The changes in the superannuation taxation regime were not fully explained in the Thursday statement. It is becoming increasingly apparent that that was at least in part because the detail had not been fully thought through.
The Canberra Times, supporting most of that statement, has stated:

The transition from the old to the new arrangements is to be gradual, but by failing to detail the reasons for change and the new arrangements Mr Keating and the Government have provided more questions than answers.

I certainly regret the confusion, concern and distress that has been caused to individuals in the community. I believe that that could have been avoided if the Government had been a little more concerned about providing a reasonable explanation. But I am not personally opposed to the changes proposed by the Government, with just one proviso. The Government's changes, as previous speakers have already said, are aimed at ending the epidemic of double dipping which has been going on in recent years. Recipients of very large superannuation lump sums have put these payments into some sort of non-interest bearing deposit or put them in their children's name and go on to claim the pension. That is hardly the point of the exercise in the first place, as superannuation is meant to be a contribution towards providing for one's own care during old age.

In addition, these changes are intended to end another tax lurk; that is, the situation in which directors of private companies can whip in and out of superannuation schemes, converting the untaxed contributions of both themselves and their employees into 5 per cent tax lump sums. Neither of these things is socially desirable and I for one applaud any action which this Government or any other government takes effectively to prevent them. However, I repeat: There are very real fears in the community relating to the fact that it may no longer be possible in the future for people to take small lump sums which they intend to use for the sorts of measures that I mentioned earlier-paying off a mortgage, buying into a business, travelling and generally enjoying themselves after 30 or 40 or more years of fairly hard work. I hope the Government is prepared to change its mind on this issue and to allow in the future people to take a lump sum of, say, up to $50,000 and to convert the rest to an annuity to provide a guaranteed income for the rest of their lives. This would provide the best of all existing worlds.

I am pleased to see in the Treasurer's statement that the Government will amend the Life Insurance Act to make it possible for life offices and superannuation funds to sell annuities on more attractive terms than at present. I point out to the Senate, though, that until and unless Australia develops a complete national portable contributory superannuation scheme we will be constantly faced with ad hoc changes which, even with the best will in the world, cause distress and confusion in the minds of the general public as well as in the insurance industry itself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a serious matter. The proposal of the Hawke Labor Government to tax savagely lump sum payments from superannuation attacks and does violence to the central fabric of Australian society. Australians have always believed that they had the right during their lifetime to save week by week, to put aside money for their retirement years. They believed they had the right to acquire capital in their retirement years, to pay off mortgages, to help their families, to set themselves up in small businesses or to dispose of that small capital at death. This proposal does violence to that basic principle and in doing so seeks to change the structure of Australian society because its application does not affect just superannuitants. We cannot simply say that we will stop a group of people acquiring capital and let others acquire capital in other ways. Clearly it will spread across the community in a massive attack on the right of Australians to acquire capital.

SPEECH.PARA: We are not talking about wealthy people at this moment; we are talking of 1.8 million Australian employees. To cover that 1.8 million employees, from the wealthiest to the lowest in the tax scale, one would have to take in people on about $180 to $190 a week. We are talking about members of the Federated Ironworkers Association, about people in the lowest grades of the Public Service and something like one million people in private industry, 83 per cent of whom now receive lump sums. So what we are looking at is an attack, and a device to be used is that the Government will make it difficult-well nigh impossible-for people under superannuation funds to hold on to capital at the end of their journey in employment.

The Government will force people into annuities. To force someone into an annuity is to force that person to abandon forever his capital. To give people the choice of doing that is a good idea but the use of force is an abhorrent principle. That force acquires two points. People would be forced to take an income from that annuity, which would be taxed by the Government, and the Government hopes to force them to be ineligible for an age pension. The great confusion of this debate is the confusion of two principles-the right of people to save, however modestly, and also the great responsibility of the people of Australia to ensure that the retired, aged and needy get a fair go. I, for one, must say at the outset that I believe this society has moved to a point where, with 89 per cent of aged people getting an age pension, clearly we have an almost universal pension and there is a need to look at the real requirements of the needy. I point out that the Government's approach is wrong-headed because it destroys the basic fabric of our society. This society will be at its strongest when it is a society of little capitalists, when it allows people the right to invest and to dispose of their capital. What right has any government to say: ' You millions of people have no right to choose the way in which you dispose of your capital; the big insurance companies will do that. We will institutionalise investment in Australia and will not allow it at the other level'. Of course, the Government did that in the mini-Budget when it wiped out the $1,000 concession for dividends. It always attacks anything that is the initiative of the individual.

This matter goes further than that. Clearly, if the situation is left where it is today, tomorrow people will be working on a thousand schemes of avoidance. People do not have to save for their old age by superannuation. Many other schemes, such as fixed trusts and the buying of property, do the same thing. We need to look at where the Government will go from here. I ask the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) to give us an assurance that this is the end of the road, that only superannuants and not others involved in fixed trusts or who have purchased property will be involved. Of course, what will happen is that the very nature of superannuation schemes will be altered. If the employee's share of a superannuation payment is to be tax free, the arrangement, as part of a pay package, will be that the employee will be given more in his wages so that he can pay more of his share, to be tax free in the end, and the employer less. It is fundamental to this debate to reject the nonsense of a $2,000m tax concession. The fact of the matter is that the arbitration system has accepted continually that superannuation payments are a part of wages. Let nobody deny that. I hope the Minister responds to that because if he destroys that concession all that will happen is that another wage package will come up in which the benefits will be altered. There is a need to do some explaining because yesterday the statement of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) widened the fear in the community. He said:

In doing so, the Government has had no intention of varying its decision that, on grounds of equitable treatment of the various groups in the community, there must be a change in the present rules that virtually exempt retirement and kindred lump sums from tax.

It is up to the Government to state quite clearly what it means by 'and kindred lump sums', because that gets to the very heart of any kind of capital accretion which a person may have and which a government may decide is a retirement benefit. Is the acquirement of a property or of a fixed trust as a capital something to be attacked? This is what we call a sleeve trick. Of course, it must be. If the aim of the Government is to force people out of age pensions, it will not stop with superannuitants. For example, it knows that there will be new schemes. It knows that millions of people have other devices for gaining capital . Quite clearly if the Government is intent on stopping capital accretion so that people may gain the age pension, it must be aiming to attack every person who is acquiring capital with low income potential by forcing them to turn that capital into income. Otherwise, what is the purpose of what it is doing?

Of course, it is interesting to recall that Senator Walsh attacked the Fraser Government for removing the property tax and said that that is where the situation really started. I asked him-and I now ask Senator Grimes, because Senator Walsh failed to answer-'Will you give the people of Australia a guarantee that you will not alter that, that you will not reinstitute some kind of property test?' What we need to know now is the width of the Government's assault upon the Australian people. It cannot stop with superannuation; that is quite clear. It must be operating on a wider front. It must be out to tax capital gains over the widest possible area. Will ordinary people who now see superannuation being taxed buy better homes over the years which are beyond their needs but which will provide some money for their children? Can such people rest in safety, or is the family home to be threatened?

What nonsense has been talked! Ministers have said that there is no retrospectivity in this situation. All of the 1.8 million people who went into this scheme over the years, those who have been in it for 30 or 40 years and those who have been in it for one year, did so with one clear understanding-that they were going to get the benefits at the end of their contribution to the scheme and that they would be free to dispose of their assets as they wished. Every person who went into the Australian defence forces knew that, if he came out in his middle years, he would have the right to take a capital sum. Is this the kind of justice that the Government is inflicting upon the community? Is this what it says is not retrospective? In fact the decisions, the planning and the lifestyles of 1.8 million people have been retrospectively altered with violence. We should bear in mind, as so many have said that it is of no good someone saying that he has been in a scheme for 30 years and has only 10 years to go. The fact is that it is the later years of a superannuation scheme in which the real benefit and the real money build; and, of course, it is those latter years that this Government is attacking.

So the Government's scheme is quite violent in its long term approach. It cannot be said to be attacking privileged people. Are 1.8 million people privileged? Are trade unionists privileged people? Are public servants privileged people? In any case, let the Government say that that is where it will stop. Let it say: 'We are going to pick on superannuitants. All who want to save their money and dispose of it in capital growth, low income investments are all right, except superannuitants'. What nonsense! Quite clearly the signifies only one thing-the Government will be out to get such people at the next round. If it is not, what violence it is doing to superannuitants in this community! Are we now to say to people: 'You can go into any scheme of avoidance that you like, other than superannuation, and that will be legal'? Will we have bottom-of -the-harbour situations chasing through this area in the years ahead? People are entitled to know now-not in the future-what they can do legally with their money . People have been misled in their beliefs. Let us put aside all these shibboleths. It is not true that there is a $2 billion concession to the Australian community. The Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission has indicated that superannuation is part of the ordinary wage package. In any case, if it were true that it is a concession, are the other concessions that employees are now getting to be threatened? Are we now to say: 'Anything you are getting as a concession or as a benefit will be threatened in future'? Where does all this start and finish?

Very simply, the situation is that, for quite wrong reasons, this scheme has been invented. It is profoundly important for the Australian community to make sure that those in most need in this community get better help. The Australian community has elected to support a scheme in which 90 per cent of those eligible for the age pension get it. Rightly or wrongly, that is what has happened. It is no solution to try to wind back that situation by picking on some people and destroying the fabric of their lives and their right to save and to invest. Even at the point of death the Government has its hands in the till at this moment. I know of nothing more destructive.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to conclude the debate on this matter of public importance. In doing so I wish merely to make a few remarks about what I consider was the hysterical contribution of Senator Sir John Carrick, who preceded me in the debate. I wish Senator Sir John Carrick would do several things. Firstly, I wish he would read and, if necessary , listen to the tape recording of remarks by the shadow Treasurer and previous Treasurer of this country which have not been in the hysterical tone that Senator Sir John Carrick introduced and which have not raised the spectre of the thin end of the wedge argument raised by Senator Sir John Carrick in the Senate but which looked at the issues that have been presented to the Australian people . Secondly, I think he should look at the article in the Australian Financial Review last Friday by the former Western Australian member of parliament, Mr Hyde, who in very careful measure looked at the proposals of the Government and urged the Opposition not to make the hysterical and scaremongering response that Senator Sir John Carrick has made. Thirdly, he should look at the comments of the people in the insurance and superannuation industry in this country who also by and large are in favour of these changes and who have not indulged in the sort of nonsense that he has gone on with. Finally, I ask him to look at the economic statement put down by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on 19 May and the statement put down yesterday. I will certainly not waste the time of the Senate by reading from the statements in this debate. But the honourable senator will read in them about the pro rata apportionment of the benefits that will be available under the system introduced by the present Government. If he reads pages 60 and 61 of the statement of 19 May he will find a clear definition of ' lump sums and kindred payments'. Were he to read all that, he may not come into this place not knowing what he is talking about and carrying on in the way he did.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has characterised these changes as hasty and ill-explained. It characterised them, in Senator Sir John Carrick's terms, as an attack on the fabric of Australian society. The Senate should remember at all times that there is at present and has been for some time general agreement that the existing arrangements in this area are inequitable and are ineffective in meeting their objective of encouraging people to provide for their income needs after retirement. I heard Senator Watson make the point that the aim of the superannuation scheme is apparently to provide people with capital sums so that they can invest in industries, in real estate and so on. The aim of the superannuation schemes of this country, like those of every other country, and of the tax concessions on superannuation which, whether Senator Sir John Carrick likes it or not, are estimated by the Australian Taxpayers Association and by the Treasurer to cost about $2,000m, is to enable people, quite rightly, to prepare for their retirement and for the provision of an adequate retirement income-not for the other purposes to which Senator Sir John Carrick has referred .

I suggest that the new arrangements, in the words of the Treasurer, will provide a firm basis for the development of a secure system of retirement provision such as aged people deserve. They will mean that no longer will the 42 per cent of the community who, for one reason or another, have access to superannuation schemes be, as far as it can be prevented, subsidised by the 60 per cent who are not in that fortunate position. The problems presented by the existing arrangements are well-known, as indeed they were to the previous Government. On 6 September 1979 Mr Howard, who was then the Treasurer, and Mr Street, who was then the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, issued a statement on occupational superannuation in which they said:
. . . there does seem to be a very wide measure of agreement on one point-namely that the current framework of legislation is in need of considerable reform.

During the succeeding 3 1/2 years the previous Government took no action to introduce that reform, which its two senior Ministers had acknowledged as being necessary. The then Government established in 1979 a task force to consider the role of occupational superannuation, but the task force was limited as to what it could do and report upon by the fact that before the 1980 election the previous Treasurer caved in on the issue of taxing lump sums. The task force was left with no scope for arriving at a rational policy on this subject. Therefore, its report could talk only about less contentious issues such as regulation and provision of annuities.

However, the then Government still recognised that the situation was not right and was marked by inequity because, during the presentation of the 1982 Budget, Senator Chaney, who was then the Minister for Social Security, announced that he and his Government would crack down on income rigging arrangements that were being used to avoid the pensions income test and would partially address the problem of double dipping, which has been talked about in this place by people on both sides almost incessantly since, as Senator Walsh has said, the previous Government introduced, half way through a previous term of office, the income test for pensions, as against the means test. However, even after Senator Chaney made that firm statement as part of the Budget presentation the then Government again backed down. Many questions were asked in this place by Senator Giles and me and others as to when the Government would do what it said it would do in presenting the Budget. The Government took no action and finally backed down. I made the following point at the time:

When the Minister made the announcement following the Budget, the Government did not know what it was going to do or how it was going to do it. The Government announced a serious legislative change and did not have a clue what it was doing. At the time the Government created anxiety and uncertainy in the community.

It continued to create anxiety and uncertainy during that whole period. The present Government has a clear idea of what it is doing in this area. It has moved to stop double dipping where that problem actually arises-in the taxation system, the tax rorts, not the pensions area. It is doing that in consultation with, and with the support of, the bulk of the superannuation industry and of the life insurance industry. The Government's proposals are sensible and moderate. They closely follow the findings of independent experts over the years . The National Superannuation Committee of Inquiry, chaired by Professor Keith Hancock, which had been appointed in 1973 by the previous Labor Government, considered that:
The present treatment of lump sums is an obstacle to other tax reforms affecting superannuation.
The Committee concluded that:

The investigations and discussion underlying this report . . . have made it clear to us that to design a rational and equitable superannuation system embodying lump sums which are nearly tax-free is an impossibility.

That is the point, I believe, of Senator Haines's statement that we will not get anywhere until we get a sensible national superannuation scheme, and we cannot do that while there exists provision for the payment of lump sums almost tax- free.
The Taxation Review Committee chaired by Mr Justice Asprey took a similar view. It said:
If a person is entitled to a lump sum he should be quite free to receive it, but he should not gain an unwarranted tax advantage in doing so.

The Government's arrangement is not radical or wild, nor is it without precedent . It is a reform item that has been on the agenda of major inquiries into taxation and superannuation schemes over a long period. It has been talked about by honourable members and senators on both sides, here and in another place. It has been the subject of addresses that I have made over the years to the Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia. It is not something that has come like a bolt out of the blue. It is not a violent change. The proposals are modest and avoid any suggestion of retrospectivity. I repeat, for it is worth repeating, that only entitlements arising from service after 30 June will be subject to the new arrangements. People who expect to receive a substantial lump sum will not be disadvantaged by the change, except in respect of extra entitlements arising after 30 June. Nor is there any suggestion that double taxation is involved. Tax will be payable only on future lump sums which arise out of a contribution or interest on which tax had not previously been payable. Thus, employee contributions, which are paid out of taxed income in the hands of employees, will not give rise to a taxable lump sum. There will be tax-free lump sums.

The new arrangements are partly designed to end tax avoidance arrangements whereby essentially superannuation has become a form of untaxed deferred pay. They are also designed, by reducing the long term burden on the Budget and the opportunity for double dipping, to reduce the inequity of taxpayers who do not belong to any superannuation scheme subsidising the entitlements of those-mostly higher income earners-who do. It is important to note that they are designed to encourage moves toward a more rational and consistent retirement income system. Australia is almost unique among countries of the Organisation for Economic Co- operation and Development in regard to the extent to which lump sums, instead of superannuation pension, are taken on retirement. It is also unique in regard to the extent to which entitlements may be dissipated, upon changing a job, prior to entitlement. The unfortunate result is that a system that was designed to help people obtain a retirement income results in many people reaching retirement with little guarantee of a regular income beyond their basic age pension.

Under the Government's proposals employees would still be entitled to receive a considerable tax-free lump sum, which would represent the return on their own contributions, in cases where such contributions have not attracted a tax rebate . Under many schemes this will mean that at least a third, and sometimes a greater portion, of the lump sum will be exempt from taxation. Each dollar that the Government forgoes in superannuation tax concessions, which primarily accrue to the better off employee, is a dollar that is not available to improve basic age pension entitlements or to devote to other uses in the community. Those who defend the present concessions should consider the likely impact on the well- being of all aged, or disadvantaged, citizens.

I repeat, these measures are not confined to curtailing unjustified taxation benefits. The objective is to extend, to many who do not now have such an opportunity, access to secure, regular incomes throughout retirement. To do this , we are removing the legislative barriers which have effectively prevented life offices and superannuation funds from selling pensions; reviewing present arrangements under which the return of the capital component of such pensions is taken into account in the age pension income test; and canvassing the possible introduction of new types of securities, including indexed bonds, which could assist life offices and superannuation funds to meet the needs of retired people for secure, regular income. We are exempting from tax entirely-including the existing tax on 5 per cent of the amount-lump sum payments rolled over into new schemes; lump sum superannuation payments which are used to buy pensions, including the existing tax on 5 per cent of the amount; and that part of the lump sum which represents the return of the employee's own contributions, unless they have already attracted a tax rebate or deduction. These measures will enable many Australians to plan for their retirement with far greater confidence than they have at present and will enable, and not inhibit, the development of a national superannuation scheme.

The arrangements were introduced deliberately with some details not made clear because we wished to consult with the unions and with the industry itself. That is what we are doing. We acted speedily and responsibly to bring to an end the sort of speculation that Senator Haines was talking about. Imagine what the speculation would have been if we had consulted with the industry for months before we announced the changes. We have made a clear, unambiguous statement of our intent. The details of the implementation will be resolved in a couple of weeks. If that is hasty and ill-conceived, how does it compare with the previous Government's prevarication from the time the previous Treasurer, in 1979, pointed out the unsatisfactory situation in this area, an announcement which was followed by no legislative change? If that is unsatisfactory and is creating anxiety in the community, what happened when Senator Chaney announced as a result of the 1982 Budget that he was going to attack the double dipping situation and the manner in which people used their lump sums to avoid the income test, and then he did nothing despite frequent questioning in this Parliament for many months until he was forced to admit that he would do nothing ? The MPI is a nonsense.

DEBATE.TITLE: MULTICULTURALISM FOR ALL AUSTRALIANS NATIONAL CONSULTATIONS ON MULTICULTURALISM AND CITIZENSHIP

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the papers.

There are two papers before the Senate. One, produced by the Australian Council on Population and Ethnic Affairs, is entitled 'Multiculturalism for all Australians-Our Developing Nationhood' and the other, produced by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, is entitled 'National Consultations on Multiculturalism and Citizenship'. The first paper is a product of the ethnic affairs policy task force. The Task Force met on 10 occasions and carried out a postal survey of interested and experienced groups. Seminars were held in the capital cities. The Task Force followed a request for advice from the then Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Ian Macphee, to whom I pay a warm tribute for his enterprising and progressive work in this area. The paper argues that to make multiculturalism successful minority non-English speaking groups must not flourish on the margin of Australian society but must be orientated towards Australian society and given the incentive to belong. Secondly, multiculturalism is not the province of ethnic groups but something that concerns the whole society.

Four principles on which multiculturalism is to be based are: Firstly, social cohesion; secondly, freedom to maintain one's own cultural identity; thirdly, equality of opportunity; and, fourthly, equal responsibility for, commitment to, and participation in Australian society. The term 'ethnic affairs' should apply to all intergroup relations. The Council recognised that effective implementation of multiculturalism requires changes in attitudes and institutions. Multicultural education is the first key to these changes. Without information there is ignorance. The Council also suggested the criteria for funding of the various groups.

I now turn to the paper entitled 'National Consultations on Multiculturalism and Citizenship'. The consultations were held between 27 June and 28 July 1982. I observe in passing why it has taken so long for the Senate to be able to debate these very important papers. Seminars were held in capital cities to sell multiculturalism. They confirmed that multiculturalism is the only mechanism to prevent the racial divisions that have occurred in other pluralistic societies. A return to assimilation is not in Australia's best interests as it would deny us the benefits of cultural diversity. During the consultations strong criticisms were made in most States by conservatives, reactionaries, crackpots and fruit cakes. These people were offended by the thought that multiculturalism involves all Australians.

As a summary the paper suggests that multiculturalism is a live issue, cultural differences should be an accepted feature of our society, multiculturalism has to be more than a marginal series of programs for minority groups, and multiculturalism has to be more than a marginal series of programs for minority groups, and multiculturalism is not radical-it is simply a recognition of reality concerning the composition of Australian society. We have a long way towards accepting our multicultural society. In 1981 a national opinion poll showed that 62 per cent of people under 25 years of age favoured cultural diversity. Eighty-eight per cent of people did not regard immigration as a problem to Australia's development.

The two papers are a welcome and excellent contribution to the debate. The person who presented them to the Government, Professor Zubrzycki, has been a pioneer in multiculturalism and, as such, is a great Australian who deserves many plaudits. Praise needs to be given to this Government and previous governments for their appreciation of and the need for multiculturalism. Such a policy is vital to the cohesion of Australian society, as 20 per cent of our population was born overseas. Only Israel has more.

One of the main things coming out of the papers is the desperate need for a national language policy, which policy the Australian Democrats sincerely, enthusiastically and vigorously pursue. In fact, the Democrats go further and say that all children who come from non-English speaking parents should first be educated in their native language before proceeding to another. We commend the work of those involved in these papers which have been presented to the Senate. We hope that meaningful debate will take place, rather than the disgusting, hateful and unhappy sort of comment that comes from some natural born Australians who seem to get a moronic buzz from their sinful and racist views which we detest and deplore.
