DEBATE.TITLE: ACCIDENT TO BEECH SUPER KING AIR 200 AIRCRAFT VH-AAV

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the papers.

I found the report of the Chairman of the Board of Accident Inquiry to be an absorbing account. In fact I could not put it down once I started to read it. Five minutes is a totally inadequate time in which to deal with as voluminous and intensive a report as this one. I apologise to the members of the Committee; I do not mean in any way to treat them with triviality. I intend to discuss this report in much greater detail in a speech during a first reading debate.

I read the report carefully, and there are some questions I would like to ask about the findings. I differ, with respect, from some of the findings of the Board. In a few minutes it is very hard to do this and appear responsible. Briefly, what happened was that a King Air 200 aircraft took off and climbed to about 80 or 100 feet on runway 07/25 at Sydney and then commenced a turn to the left. The aircraft lost power in the port engine and crashed into the sea wall at the end of runway 16/34, which is the runway which goes out into Botany Bay, after a flight time of around two minutes. The point to be appreciated is that the crash occurred when the aircraft was flying away from the runway heading, the runway on which it was apparently the intention of the pilot to land, and that would have required a turn of about 110 to 120 degrees, according to the well-researched map of the flight path which is found in the opening part of the report. The aircraft, in the latter part of its downward leg was below the height of the sea wall, flying in ground effect.

This situation received no comment at all in an otherwise very intensive and exhaustive inquiry. It is a major problem to me that there was an aircraft right down at sea level within a few feet of the sea surface and below the height of the rocks. The assumption that a turn of about 110 degrees in a very short radius with a power impairment was going to be made, is just not logical. But any lay person reading the report would not appreciate that point. At that height that sort of turn is quite impossible. The presumption one must make is that from about the time that the aircraft was established on the downwind leg for runway 34 it was starting to go out of control and by the time it was on the latter half of the downwind leg it was completely uncontrollable. I cannot understand why the pilot did not chop the power and ditch the aircraft into Botany Bay. It was a very hot day; there would have been a lot of boats out there, and the accounts are that the water was as smooth as a millpond. That could have been done with absolute safety.

I think that the report is inadequate, despite its great complexity. I think some of the questions we have to ask the Department of Aviation relate to air traffic control, the airworthiness surveyors and the flying operations business and its legal department. Page 271 of the report dealing with air traffic control misses the point entirely with relation to the approach of the Ansett 727 aircraft. That aircraft should have been cleared from the circuit. The point was not that it cleared the runway by the time VH-AAV reached the threshold of runway 34; the point was that the presence of that aircraft committed the pilot of VH-AAV to flying downwind when he could have turned on to the runway, had he had a clear runway. The performance of the air surveyors is astonishing. They knew that maintenance was inadequate. Furthermore, every aircraft owner in Australia-I have been an aircraft owner for more than 14 years-knows that the New South Wales region is notorious for its laxness in the control of maintenance. On repeated occasions in this company the air surveyors lacked the moral fibre to implement the laws which they knew were being broken.

The report referred to the Examiner of Airmen. There were two consecutive failures to cope with an asymetric power situation on an instrument rating renewal, and nothing was done about it. The legal department did not know that there had been two changes in ownership. Then we come to the business of operations manuals. Where do we stand with operations manuals? It is a fight I have been waging with two Ministers for aviation. Who draws them up? What is their authority? Do these documents protect the pilot or the operator in the face of a breach of air navigation orders? Operations manuals do not, apparently , have to conform with ANOs. Then we come to the company. What was it doing? Was it pushing for profit rather than safety? We now come to the pilot himself. It is very hard to agree with the finding of the Board that he could not be blamed for what happened. Quite simply, that aircraft could have been flown in the circumstances. It was not a superhuman matter. The aircraft was so designed, I believe with the greatest of kindness to the pilot's next of kin, that he should have coped with the situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take up where Senator MacGibbon left off. An opinion at the end of the report of the Chairman of the Board of Accident Inquiry, relating to the causes of the accident, states:

SPEECH.PARA: In the opinion of the Board, these errors were not culpable because of the combination of adverse circumstances which the pilot faced during the emergency and which required a standard of skill beyond that of the average pilot.

That is a most strange form of wording to use in such a finding. The report lists a few things, and Senator MacGibbon has touched on them: The aircraft was overweight; the auto-ignition system was not on; there was water; the interstage turbine temperature was set below that for which the engine was certificated. All these things were mentioned and then the report contained that statement. A lot of people reading this report would get awfully frightened if they had to travel on a twin engined aircraft. On the surface the report says that the average pilot flying a twin engine aircraft is not capable of handling that aircraft in an emergency situation. That, of course, is a lot of nonsense. Our pilots are very well trained. Indeed they do not get their licences unless they are able to handle an aircraft in an engine out situation. I take issue with that point.

I am a little cynical. Recognising that the Department of Aviation has been pressing for two pilot operation on certain commuter operations, it would almost be easy to suggest that that paragraph was put in there at the behest of the Department to give it more leverage when the new two pilot operation is brought in on 1 July. It is interesting that, having gone through all the things that could have been wrong and then adding that paragraph, the first recommendation is on crew complement. I suppose we could all say that two pilots are better than one. Take that to its ultimate conclusion and three are better that two and four are better than three. That has not been borne out by the facts and statistics on aircraft accidents over a long period. A lot of people like to see two pilots operating an aircraft. I do not blame them for that, but there is an economic consideration. Unfortunately, the Department, hiding behind the guise of safety, on many occasions brought in recommendations over which the Minister or the Parliament have no control. Of course it takes a brave Minister and a brave parliament to say to the Department that it cannot do that. The Department would raise the issue of safety and everybody would go to water.

The economic effect of this two pilot operation for which the Department is now using the repent as a crutch will be rather devastating. The airline business world-wide is in a very bad economic state. The commuter airlines in Australia are probably in the worst position, with the current economic downturn, servicing the small ports and the rural areas, particularly of New South Wales, the Northern Territory and Queensland. I think that this will be another impost. A lot of commuters will go out of business. People will not be able to afford the 20 per cent fare increases that this change will bring about. A lot of ports which are now being serviced quite well with the smaller twin engined aircraft with one pilot will no longer receive a service.

I commend the Department-even though as I said I have my reservations about its bringing in the two pilot operation, with the economic impost and the hardship that that will ultimately mean-for taking up some of the factors which the regional airlines have asked it to look at. I understand that the Department has agreed to reduce fuel reserve requirements in some circumstances. It is looking at Special Federal Aviation Regulation No. 41 in the United States which means that the operating weights of some commuter aircraft can be increased. This will help some commuter airlines to carry a bigger payload in some types of aircraft which have two pilots. They might be able to resolve the problem in this way. I hope that the Department of Aviation looks at that SFAR 41 quickly, before many of the commuter airlines opt out of some of the ports at which they call. Obviously, when that happens, they will not return for a very long time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I fully support the comments already made by Senator MacGibbon. There is no question that the report of the Board of Accident Inquiry, which is before us at the moment, is one of the most astonishing that I have seen for a long time. I do not want to cover again the areas that have been covered by Senator MacGibbon and Senator Collard, particularly in view of the Board's recommendation with regard to an increased crew component. I want to concentrate on two other areas resulting both from this report and from the ministerial statement that was brought down as a result .

SPEECH.PARA: As has already been mentioned, the plane crashed within two minutes of take-off . It killed the pilot and 12 passengers. The Minister for Aviation (Mr Beazley) and Senator Collard, the previous speaker in the debate, have made mention of the fact that the area of commuter operations is the fastest growing area in the industry at the moment, carrying upwards of one million people a year. Indeed, on page 56 of the report, under the heading 'Review of Maintenance Procedures' the Board makes this comment:
The deficiencies in the Advance Airlines maintenance documentation for the day of the accident were so numerous that little would be gained by discussing all of them in detail.

TALK.START.PARA: —In February 1983, the Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking constituted by Mr Justice Stewart delivered its report to the governments of the Commonwealth and the States of New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland. In March, His Honour delivered his report to the New Zealand Government which had also given him a Commission under New Zealand law. Both the Australian and the New Zealand reports are being tabled in the parliaments of each country today. Mr Justice Stewart's report will also be tabled in the Victorian Parliament today and in New South Wales and Queensland parliaments when they resume.

SPEECH.PARA: The Letters Patent given by the various governments to His Honour required him to inquire into, and report on, the drug trafficking activities of Terrence Clark and associated matters, including any changes to the law or to administrative procedures which appear necessary. Responding to these terms of reference, the report contains a number of findings essentially relating to criminal activities of Clark to 1979. Activities of some of Clark's associates are also described. The extent of criminality revealed in these findings has caused grave concern to governments, in particular, the importation and trafficking of illicit drugs on a massive scale; laundering of money both in Australia and overseas; and murder and violence associated with these activities .

The report also contains a large number of recommendations for future action. Most of these recommendations are for changes in the law or administrative practices; others are for prosecution action. There have been preliminary consultations among the interested governments on the subject matter of the report and the report has been put to study within the governments.

The Commonwealth Government has decided that: Relevant Commonwealth departments will complete their studies of the report and make recommendations as to action on it within three months; the Government will decide and announce its response generally to the report and in particular to the recommendations contained in it during the Budget sittings; with the agreement of the States of New South Wales and Victoria there will be a committee of Commonwealth, New South Wales and Victorian officials to co-ordinate investigatory and prosecution action in respect of the report.

The Queensland Government does not appear at this time likely to be directly involved in any prosecutions which might spring from the Commonwealth, New South Wales and Victorian investigations to be made consequent upon the report. The Queensland Government has, however, requested that it be informed of the progress of such investigations and has offered to render any necessary assistance which might be requested. Statements to be made by the New South Wales and Victorian governments will indicate the action being taken by those governments to respond to the report.

In considering what portions of the report should be released for general publication, the governments have been very concerned that the report in many places names individuals as associated with Clark or as committing, or possibly committing, offences against the law, some of a very serious nature. This concern was communicated to Mr Justice Stewart who, in reply, indicated that, having reconsidered the question of publication, it remained his view that it would be proper and preferable for the report to be tabled as delivered, except for certain portions marked 'confidential', and subject to the deletion of references to a person who is the subject of current criminal charges.

The report answers the terms of reference given to the Royal Commission by the various governments and, having regard to all these considerations, the Government has concluded that the report should be tabled as delivered, subject only to the exclusion of the matters indicated by Mr Justice Stewart, namely, matters marked 'confidential', and references to a person the subject of current charges. I would emphasise that the Government's decision to so table the report was reached after due consideration of both the need for the public to have knowledge of the findings of the Royal Commission and of the interests of the individuals named in the report.

In tabling the report, the Government wishes to make it clear that, as indicated in the report itself, the naming of a person does not mean that he or she is guilty of any offence or necessarily involved in any criminal activity. Much material which is not admissible in criminal proceedings is put before a royal commission. Guilt can only be established in criminal courts on evidence which is admissible and which establishes guilt beyond a reasonable doubt. The Government hopes that the media, and all other persons, in commenting upon or discussing the report, will respect the fundamental rights and civil liberties of persons who might be named in the report. I should make it clear that the Government's decision in relation to the tabling of the report was made after full consultations between the four Australian governments concerned. This consultation involved the Attorney-General of each Government, and the decision now announced represents the agreed view of the four governments.

The Royal Commissioner in part six of his report, has made a number of recommendations as to the estabishment of a crimes commission. These recommendations will be looked at in the course of the review that the Government is now carrying out of the National Crimes Commission Act 1982. A Green Paper is being prepared and it is anticipated that this will be distributed shortly. A conference will be held in Canberra on 30 July 1983 to which will be specifically invited representatives of State governments, members of the judiciary, commissioners of police, representatives of interested professional bodies and public organisations as well as, of course, Mr Costigan and people associated with existing commissions of inquiry of a relevant kind. At the conclusion of this review the Government will decide what amendments, if any, are required to the National Crimes Commission Act with a view to the introduction and passage of the necessary legislation in the Budget sittings so that the Commission can commence operations in January 1984.

Before I conclude, I should refer to certain criticisms contained in the report in relation to the Attorney-General's Department. My Department has examined these criticisms and yesterday furnished me with a report on them and on the actions that have been taken or are being taken in relation to the matters they raise. The departmental report acknowledges that unacceptable delays did occur in the response to the recommendations of the Commission's interim reports Nos. 3 and 4, and I am satisfied that a number of criticisms made of the Department's performance in this respect have substance, although there were some mitigating factors.

Although an internal disciplinary investigation has resulted in one officer being counselled in respect of his role in this matter, it would appear that the problem within the Attorney-General's Department was less one of individual performance than of managerial systems. In this respect I believe that the matters of concern to the Royal Commissioner, Mr Justice Stewart, will be squarely addressed by the major management review of the Department which I have set in train in the last two months. In particular, it would appear that the establishment of a Commonwealth directorate of public prosecutions, which is proposed for later this year, would meet a substantial part of the Royal Commission's concerns about the conduct of Commonwealth prosecutions.
I move:
That the Senate take note of the statement and the papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —If there is anyone left in Australia who had any doubts about the existence of organised crime in Australia, the serious threat that it represents and the need to take urgent action in respect of it then the tabling of this report of the Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking-it inquired into the Clark syndicate-should completely dispel lingering doubts of that kind. This report is voluminous. Unfortunately, the size of it may in fact deter many people from reading and studying it to the extent which it clearly deserves. I hope that despite the challenge that is presented by the size of the report, and in many cases perhaps the more technical aspects of the subject with which it deals, the challenge will be taken up and a study will be made of the report. I am pleased to note that the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) indicated that a time limit of three months has been placed on a close study of the report by officials. This report clearly deserves the closest study by officials and, as I said, by many other people.

SPEECH.PARA: The origin of the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking is very interesting. In its time it was a unique royal commission. It arose out of difficulties and frustrations which a joint Commonwealth-State police task force had run into in the obtaining evidence in relation to some familiar aspects of organised crime. The Royal Commission was given the very specific mandate-it appears to have achieved its goals-of taking a particular organised crime syndicate, namely the Clark syndicate, studying that in depth and detail and, thereby, describing the way in which a fairly typical organised crime syndicate was set up, the way in which it operated and the people who were associated with it. Then, of course, it was expected that the Commission would make recommendations on the basis of the close study it made of that particular syndicate. The Royal Commission appears to have achieved exactly what it was set up to do.

Another aspect-perhaps this is an even more unique aspect-is that the Commission was set up because of the frustrations and difficulties being experienced by a joint Commonwealth-State police task group as a result of the limitations the law imposes on police investigations.

The Commission was able to achieve its aim. The existence of joint Commonwealth -State police task forces-they had been set up prior to the establishment of the Stewart Royal Commission-is a most important development in the understanding of organised crime and its ramifications in Australia. We have taken the first steps to respond to the problem which was seen to exist but with which our traditional police forces seemed unable to cope.

Organised crime has a national feature. Organised crime does not observe State boundaries and does not worry about the fact that its activities contravene different laws involving police forces in each State. It operates on a national basis. Of course, it owes a great deal of its success to the fragmentation of the laws, the number of different police forces and the prosecuting systems that exist in Australia. It, of course, has been able to exploit the fact that this fragmentation exists. No recognition whatsoever is made of the fact that there are Commonwealth laws and State laws. One operation can breach some Commonwealth laws, some State laws and laws of different States. So it is absolutely vital in this area that there should be co-operation between the Commonwealth and the States in the investigation, the policing and the prosecution of organised crime syndicates.

As a result of the recommendations of the Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs, headed by Mr Justice Williams and the New South Wales Royal Commission into Drug Trafficking, headed by Mr Justice Woodward, the Commonwealth-New South Wales Joint Police Task Force on Drug Trafficking was established as an ongoing body to tackle these problems in the way in which I have said it is imperative to do so. A second joint police task force was then established. It comprised not only the police forces of the Commonwealth and New South Wales but also those of Victoria and Queensland. It was set up as a result of some apparent leaks from the former Narcotics Bureau. This task force identified those leaks.

That group was headed by the Assistant Commissioner of Victoria Police, Mr Hall , who is now I understand, the Deputy Commissioner of Victoria Police. In fact two joint police task forces were working in this area. I recall very clearly that when I was Attorney-General I received a deputation led by Mr Hall. The members of the task force emphasised the very great difficulties they had experienced in the course of their investigations because of the limitation of their powers. They made it very clear that something further was needed. That was a very important step in the decision ultimately taken by the Fraser Government to establish this Royal Commission headed by Mr Justice Stewart. We now have the report before us this afternoon. The setting up of the Royal Commission has been a unique step in the process of studying the ramifications of organised crime. Certainly, as I have said, the work that the Commission has done and the report that it has made have been major steps towards our understanding further the nature of organised crime and its challenge to our society.

I am pleased to say that there has been a very considerable increase in the recognition of this threat, particularly by the police forces in Australia. I believe that, in the last few years-perhaps with the experience gained by these joint police task forces-the police forces in Australia, whether they be State or Commonwealth, certainly have greatly advanced their recognition of the need to work together to overcome this fragmentation. In many cases suspicion and jealousy and so on have played their part as frequently they do where there are different bodies of people. In recent years great advances have been made by police forces meeting and talking together. One of the great achievements has been the establishment of the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence. That was a major step forward, and I give it full recognition. But, of course, a great deal more requires to be done. There will have to be a recognition by governments that many more resources will have to be made available to any bodies of this kind that are set up in the future. Indeed, I fear that more powers will have to be given to the police as well.

The next matter for which there has to be greater recognition than there has been is that the Commonwealth Government simply will have to play a much greater role in these matters than it traditionally has played. Certainly, it became more and more apparent to me in my latter years as Attorney-General that some of the problems we had with organised crime in Australia resulted from the fact that the Commonwealth had left the question of tackling and facing this challenge to the traditional forces, namely those in the States. It also became apparent that there would need to be new institutions, new arrangements and greater resources at the Commonwealth and the State levels. Nothing I am saying should detract from my very firm view that essentially this must be a joint enterprise by the Commonwealth and the States, but there has been a great increase in the breaches of Commonwealth criminal laws. Drug importation itself is a breach of Commonwealth law. Through the experience of the Commonwealth both at the investigative and prosecution levels we have realised that the importance and the threat of organised crime is a matter to be tackled by the Commonwealth and the States.

This issue has got caught up, to some extent, in the problem of Federal-State relations. As I have said, perhaps it goes back to personalities and jealousies that arise between people. It would be unfortunate if the solution to these problems got caught up in the arugments about Federal-State powers. As I have said, the solution to the problem is co-operation, joint exercises and a recognition that the Commonwealth will have to be involved. I think it would be in everybody's interests that the Commonwealth should be involved, and involved more and more. When all is said and done that is where the greater resources will be available; the resources will need to come from the Commonwealth. The more the Commonwealth is involved in these co-operative or joint exercises the more likely it will be that the Commonwealth will make resources available to them.

The other matter that clearly arises in this report is the need to face squarely the question of police powers of investigation and new forms of conducting prosecutions. Again, I believe that we will have to modify our traditional way of approaching both investigation and prosecution in regard to the challenge of organised crime. One of the first problems that has to be clearly established-it is a conceptual problem in many ways-is an adequate definition of organised crime. Having spent a good deal of time last year in thinking about it and studying it, I believe that an acceptable definition can be found. Once we have done that we then have to face fairly and squarely the question of how modifications will need to be made and greater powers of investigation given to whatever institution is established.

This report makes a large number of recommendations, many of which I suppose have been thought about before. But the time has clearly come when the recommendations contained in this report, involving greater police powers of investigation and new forms of prosecution, must certainly be decided. I do not think we can keep postponing these very hard decisions much longer. Of course, one of the decisions that has to be made concerns greater police access to the interception of telephones. That is something that has been recommended by the police for some time. Certainly, the powers to be given and the circumstances in which permission is given would have to be very carefully defined. Mr Justice Stewart's recommendation in this regard will have to be tackled and decided upon .

Another extremely important recommendation is the power to question suspects, pursuant to a magisterial order, and the power to detain people for a certain period in order to make inquiries and ask questions. People should not be forced to answer but the police should have the opportunity of being able to question them. One of the matters that the joint police task force found very difficult was dealing with sophisticated people with access to all the best professional legal and accounting advice. It is very difficult to investigate persons of that sort without additional powers being given to the police. Certainly, those matters have to be fairly and squarely faced and decided upon over the coming months as a result of the recommendations in this report.

Another very important matter in the prosecution process is whether there ought to be-the Attorney-General has mentioned this-the establishment of a directorate of public prosecutions at the Commonwealth level. But there is another matter which perhaps is of even greater importance. It is one of which there has been growing recognition, certainly during the period I was Attorney-General. That is the necessity of granting immunities to people who are involved, perhaps even quite deeply involved, in some of the organised syndicates. Certainly one hopes to be able to get people who are, perhaps, not so deeply involved in matters to assist the police and to give evidence against the principals. There is a long record of granting immunities, but traditionally in Australia there has been great reluctance to grant such immunities. I have shared that reluctance. I am sure that the present Attorney-General will also, if he has not already experienced it, share that reluctance. But it is absolutely imperative that immunities in these cases have to be given. They have been given, and we shall have to make greater use of them in the future.

In the United States of America, where there is the greatest protection to civil liberties under the Bill of Rights, prosecutors have emphasised continually, in discussions I have had with them, the supreme importance of the granting of immunities. I notice that Mr Justice Stewart, Mr Justice Williams and Mr Justice Woodward have all recognised the absolute necessity for the granting of immunities as part of the process of successful investigation and prosecution in cases of organised crime.

In dealing with the prosecution side, I do not have any firm view against the establishment of a Director of Public Prosecutions. Mr Justice Stewart recommends the possibility of investigating a joint Commonwealth-State public prosecutor, and that may fit in very well with the need for co-operative arrangements, which, as I have said, are absolutely necessary, certainly at the police level and between governments in tackling this major problem. Certainly there has to be some new and improved method of conducting prosecutions at the Commonwealth level. At the very least, there would need to be established a major prosecution section in the Attorney-General's Department, with someone at a very senior level being given the role of a chief prosecutor, in much the same way as has traditionally been the case in the States. The time has come when this role does not sit very easily simply within the Commonwealth Crown Solicitor's Division of the Attorney-General's Department.

The demands of organised crime and the extent of breaches of Commonwealth laws are now such, as I have said, that there is a much greater role, and it will have to be a growing role, for the Commonwealth in this area. The organisation of the Attorney-General's Department must recognise that, and changes must be made. Maybe as a result of the study that the Attorney-General has indicated- although he has made no decisions, I understand-a Director of Public Prosecutions is the answer. I would be interested in giving further consideration to the subject. However, I am convinced that some new institution for the prosecution of crime at the Commonwealth level, or new administrative arrangements for it, will have to be made. At the same time, I believe that the political responsibility for this matter ultimately must rest with the Attorney- General, he being responsible to this Parliament for what is done. The traditional approach is not good enough.

Finally, I should like to refer to the need for the National Crimes Commission. I have not had the opportunity of studying properly the recommendations or discussions by Mr Justice Stewart in regard to this matter, but I am familiar with the fact that both he and Mr Costigan have realised that there has to be a really new institutional arrangement in Australia to tackle this problem. There has to be some body, some new institution, which can have as its sole and whole task meeting the challenge of organised crime. The National Crimes Commission which was proposed to this Parliament and approved and passed by the Parliament at the end of last year is the major answer to it. I fully accept that it is desirable, and, in the long run, not only desirable but necessary, that the States should join in it. I do not think that one has to wait until the States come to some co-operative arrangement with the Commonwealth before that body is set up and is under way. It is a pity that it is not under way.

The Government has been approaching this question in a far too leisurely fashion. The legislation was there and ready to be proclaimed and to go into business by now. It is a shame that the Government did not proceed with it. The question of balancing civil liberties and the need for investigation of these crimes, and the increased powers that are needed, were all considered with great thought last year and were fully debated in this Parliament. I do not think that this matter needs this leisurely approach of a Green Paper and another seminar. Goodness knows then how much longer it would be before the legislation is through and the Commission is set up. I should like a firm undertaking from the Government that this National Crimes Commission will be set up by 1 January 1984 .

I note that the Attorney-General seems to be firming up every time he speaks about it-perhaps under the influence of what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said recently about the need to have a Crimes Commission operating at the beginning of 1984. But up until a week or so ago the whole question of whether this Government would set up a Crimes Commission seemed to be very much still in the air. So I want a firm assurance from the Attorney-General that a National Crimes Commission will be set up and will be operating by 1 January 1984. All these other questions can be looked at. Sure, the idea of having a seminar on the subject is a very important and a very good idea. All I am saying is that I do not think that these things should delay the establishment of the National Crimes Commission any longer. If ever a National Crimes Commission were needed, it is clear from this report that it is needed now, and there should be no further delay in having it working.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the report of the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking. The Commission was given relatively narrow terms of reference-to inquire into the activities of a creature called Terrence Clark, associated matters and any changes to the law or administrative procedures which appear necessary. Mr Justice Stewart has documented some horrific happenings that occurred in Australia which hitherto many Australians would have thought would live only in the minds of fiction writers and people who write fairy stories-of people being deliber- ately killed, of collusion between police forces and drug rings, of the amount of heroin estimated to be used in Australia and smuggled in . To the extent to which the report documents evidence or cases against certain individuals, it is a valuable contribution to the debate on this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I am disappointed in the report and will give my reasons in a moment or two. Before I do, let me put the matter in perspective. Australia today does have a massive problem with organised crime. I have been saying that for the last 10 years and as each year goes by the problem gets bigger in geometric and not arithmetic proportions. I am pleased in some way that my contentions are now being supported by people such as Mr Justice Stewart and the Chief Commissioner of Police in Victoria who the other day said something that is almost unbelievable-that 550 crimes of violence, most of them of a serious nature, are committed in Melbourne each day. It is almost incomprehensible that in one city over 500 crimes, mostly of a serious nature, are committed in a day. Dr McCoy, an international expert on the matter, in his book concerning heroin smuggling and drug trafficking, estimates that there are 40,000 drug addicts in Australia.

I have stated at many seminars and before criminologists and other people interested in drug rehabilitation that, in my view, the profits from heroin dealing in Australia today are of the order of $250m a year, that the profits from the importation and illegal sale of cannabis are a similar amount something like $250m a year; and that the profits from illegal gambling, essentially in Sydney, are of the order of $100m to $150m a year. So we are talking about profits of organised crime in Australia of something like $600m to $700m a year. I am not talking about turnover. I am talking about profits. That also borders on the incomprehensible.

I want to ask a rhetorical question. Most politicians, magistrates, judges and policemen would turn in a person who offered them a bribe of some moderate amount. I am firmly of the view that every member of this Parliament, if offered a bribe of a few thousand dollars by someone to do something dishonest, would immediately report that offence to the Australian Federal Police and have that person brought to the bar of the Senate or the House of Representatives. Without wanting to impugn a single person in this place, including myself, I wonder whether we would have a 100 per cent response to that question if the bribe was $250,000 a year for a series of 10 years. I just wonder about that. One has to look at this whole concept of organised crime, when it is earning profits of this magnitude, and ask oneself: Is anybody in public life safe?

TALK.START.PARA: —They can use other techniques too.

—Indeed. I thank Senator Lewis for his valuable interjection. If Senator Lewis and I, as members of the national Parliament, express concern over this matter what sorts of fears must be expressed by ordinary citizens who wonder whether they can any longer trust their elected representatives, the police who protect them, the magistrates and the judges? This sets off ripples throughout the whole of society. This is the magnitude of the problem to which Mr Justice Stewart was asked to address himself.

SPEECH.PARA: I am disappointed in a sense that most of his recommendations, as I have read them in the very small amount of time at my disposal, seem to concentrate on reforming law enforcement procedures. As I understand the former Attorney- General, my friend Senator Peter Durack, most of his remarks were directed along that line as well. It is a very valuable line of debate and a very valuable contribution to make to this debate. But I believe that approach is attacking the problem of organised crime from the wrong direction. In a moment I will quote from Mr Justice Michael Kirby, who says that we ought to be paying attention to the cause of crime and not just the symptoms.

We have to ask ourselves in a non-political party way-we should be able to have a bipartisan attitude without scoring political points off each other-a question such as this: If cannabis is giving organised crime profits of $200m to $250m a year and if Mr Justice Stewart, Mr Justice Williams, Mr Justice Woodward and every other royal commissioner who has inquired into organised crime conclude that we cannot stamp it out, is it not a logical proposition to contemplate at least the placing of cannabis in a situation where crime cannot make a profit out of it, namely, by decriminalising it?

One does not have to advocate the use of cannabis. I state as a personal view that cannabis ought to be decriminalised and legalised. That is not the view of my party because it is a moral question and we believe that it is not proper to bind Australian Democrats members of parliament by party policy on moral questions. I very vigorously hold the view that cannabis ought to be decriminalised and, in fact, legalised. At the same time I would say to any young person or any other person I meet: 'For God's sake, do not use cannabis. It is harmful; it is bad'.

TALK.START.PARA: —You still have huge profits with heroin.

—I will come to heroin in a moment and I will advocate something else that might shock people. I believe that law enforcement procedures have failed and they have been seen to fail. There is no suggestion that they will solve the problem of organised crime, drug abuse and the sale of illicit drugs. I am of the view that if cannabis were legalised, advertising prohibited and the strictest controls concerning quality and places of sale applied, the profits or organised crime of $200m a year could be cut from underneath the people involved . There should also be a concerted and vigorous advertising campaign by government health departments to say to young people: 'For goodness sake, don't be stupid enough to harm your body by using this very harmful substance-cannabis -whether it is in the form of marihuana, hashish or hashish oil'. I hope that in the Green Paper the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) will present that approach to ruining and combating organised crime will at least be discussed on a non-party basis. I hope that the Reverend Fred Nile and his ilk will not dash out tonight and say: 'Don Chipp is permissive: He is advocating legalisation of marihuana'. I hope that none of my political opponents will try to capitalise on this statement. I plead for a reasonable and reasoned debate on this question. An article on this issue which referred to the comments of Mr Justice Kirby, a person for whom I have an unbounded admiration, states:

SPEECH.PARA: A major reason behind the growth of organised crime was the failure of legislatures-
That is, this Parliament-
to reform the system of criminal law, which was based on centuries-old English common law.
The article went on to state:
. . . many people were shocked to find that activities not regarded by the community as wrong were in fact criminal.

He gave as a silly example-he is not silly but this is a silly example-the recent raid by New South Wales police on the Sydney home of a well-known jockey who was arrested. What was he doing? What was his terrible offence? He was charged with playing a game of cards at his home with his friends. If law enforcement agencies are going to act in that sort of pathetic way what sort of respect will people have for the law? The article goes on to report Mr Justice Kirby as stating:

Most members of the Australian community would regard this use of the criminal law, and of police, as surprising, even perhaps wrong. The attempt to use the criminal law to enforce perceptions of morality which are now not held with general community consensus tends to undermine respect for the law.
It bred cynicism among citizens and corruption among officials, and was the fostering-ground of organised crime.

In the distance between what the criminal law says is wrong and what the community regards is wrong lies the opportunity for organsied crime. Here is where prostitution, pornography, gambling, marihuana and so on flourish. Is there one person in this Senate who genuinely and sincerely believes that law enforcement will stamp out the use of marihuana in this country? If so, let him stand up and say so; otherwise, he is a hypocrite. Is there one person in this Senate who believes that law enforcement will stamp out prostitution in this country? If so, let him stand up and say so. But if honourable senators oppose legislation, I appeal to their morality. I do not ask them to condone prostitution or the use of cannabis-I plead with them to condemn the sorts of things that are socially evil-but I ask them to ask themselves whether they are not, by opposing the legislation of these things, giving organised crime an incredible opportunity to make the kinds of profits I mentioned earlier?

It is because of these things I am disappointed that royal commissioners like Mr Justice Stewart and all of those before him have not addressed their minds to stamping out the causes of organised crime rather than the symptoms. I appeared before royal commissioner Stewart. Does he not know that law enforcement will not stamp out the importation of heroin or hashish? Did he not get evidence from law enforcement agencies to the effect that an army of narcotics agents at every wharf and every airport would confiscate only 10 per cent or thereabouts of the drugs smuggled in? That is a world-wide figure, a figure I received from all the narcotics and law enforcement agencies I visited when abroad in 1972 studying this problem as the then Commonwealth Minister for Customs and Excise. It was almost spooky that every police force in the Western world that I visited, when asked what quantity of drugs it could stop, said about 10 per cent. Ninety per cent will always get through because there are thousands of ways in which these kinds of drugs-on which mind-boggling profits can be made because of their illegality, particularly with heroin, can be brought in. While fantastic profits are possible, there will always be enough people who will take the risk of their liberty or their money and try to make those incredible profits. Therefore, I am disappointed that Mr Justice Stewart went so far down the track of improving law enforcement techniques. I agree with most of his recommendations but I believe that he has taken entirely the wrong approach.

Senator Durack interjected a moment ago in regard to heroin. I estimate that the profits from the sale of heroin on the streets of Australia total between $ 200m and $250m. I suppose every member of this Parliament has seen the pathetic, soul-destroying sight of a young person addicted to heroin, prostituting his or her body in Kings Cross, Acland Street in St Kilda or wherever it takes place, knowing that while this is going on syndicates are making millions of dollars profit. Senator Durack by interjection said that following the decriminalisation of cannabis we would still have the heroin problem. I hope that in the Green Paper to be produced by Senator Evans there will also be the 'outrageous' suggestion that we also look at legalising heroin. Before anybody has a heart attack over that proposition, let me say that I am not suggesting for one moment that capsules be on sale at everybody's friendly neighbourhood chemist. I am suggesting that we look at the British experiment under which heroin is prescribed by a qualified medical practitioner for a person who has already been diagnosed as a heroin addict. That might not work in all cases but at least if we can get the addict, this 18, 19 or 20-year-old person who is psychologically disturbed, lonely and who has probably been sexually abused as a baby-I understand that that is the portrait of the heroin addict-under some sort of medical supervision, control and advice, we have a fighting chance of reaching out and touching him or her. At the moment, if they are left to the mercies of those creatures who peddle this killer drug on the streets of Kings Cross or Acland Street, St Kilda, they will go down a one-way street with a certain destination.

TALK.START.PARA: —You would agree that the only cost of that enlightened approach would be increased community use?
—That could be a cost.
—That is the only consequence.

—I thank Senator Baume for his interjection, which is helpful. I concede it is a possible danger. Senator Baume was a party to the very courageous decision of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare, which I understand he chaired, about legalising or decriminalising cannabis. I have said on that matter that if we want to talk about legalising it we have to have a corresponding massive education campaign throughout Australia to say that taking this drug is an evil, stupid and wrong thing to do-as I believe taking cannabis in any form is a stupid an harmful thing to do. I believe that that challenge would have to accompany legalisation. Senator Baume might be right. All I am asking is: Can we not leave political point scoring aside and debate these new concepts on a non-partisan basis? For that reason I compliment Senator Evans on the concept of the Green Paper which is to be brought down.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Evans has baulked at the idea of a crimes commission, which the Liberal Party and Senator Durack strongly advocate. I thoroughly support them but Senator Evans has held back, I suspect because of his innate fear of offence against civil liberties. Notwithstanding one or two aberrations in regard to civil liberties on his part, I do believe he has a genuine concern for them. I do not think anybody can accuse me, over my parliamentary career, of not paying regard to civil liberties of individuals. However, I believe one can carry concern for civil liberties to such ridiculous lengths as to destroy civil liberties in another area. In other words, what is the point of having a totally clean slate in not offending civil liberties in legislation if there is a ballooning problem of narcotics addiction, with thousands of young Australians losing every form of liberty, including civil and health. At the risk of being tedious, I repeat the famous words of George Santayana, who talked about fanatics. We do have fanatics in the area of civil liberties. Honourable senators will recall that his definition of a fanatic is a person who redoubles his efforts long after he has forgotten his aim. There are people who do champion civil liberties against every other consideration. I plead with Senator Evans and the Government to let it all come out in the Green Paper so it can be debated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think it might be difficult for the young to understand an educative process showing how bad marihuana, heroin and everything else is if we say: 'But we will make it legal'?

—I thank Senator Walters for her interjection. It is a valuable interjection and something to be contemplated. She may well have a valid point. That would depend, of course, on the efficacy of the advertisements. Mr Deputy President, I thank you for your indulgence in allowing my friend Senator Walters to interject. For years we were negative about things such as smoking and we said, 'Do not smoke because it will kill you or you will finish up with lung cancer', all of which turned out to be the wrong kind of advertising. Because human nature is perverse-this is what Senator Walters is getting at-if you tell young people not to smoke marijuana because it is bad for them they will probably smoke it; if you tell them not to speed on the roads they will go faster. Senator Peter Baume will correct me if I am wrong, but I pay tribute to the Health Department of New South Wales which tried that exciting social experiment in health advertising in Gosford, I think.
—Lismore and Kempsey.

—It was a positive approach-'Kiss a non-smoker and taste the difference'. I am sure that that appeals to Senator Walters and those of our vintage, but it certainly appeals to the young. The problem is to put this message over in language and in vehicles which the young understand and can embrace. I thank the Senate for its indulgence in giving me the opportunity of speaking to this retort. I hope that there will be an enlightened approach to the question of drug addiction by the Parliament first. If there is a non-party approach to this question, we can look forward to an enlightened public debate on Senator Evans's Green Paper. If party politics are played in this Parliament about it, we can forget an enlightened public debate, no matter how good the Green Paper is.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Lewis) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to establish Anzac Day as a national day of remembrance and to provide for observances in the Australian Capital Territory to mark Anzac Day.
Bill presented by Senator Lewis, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

I am pleased to introduce this Bill into the Senate. Anzac Day, the 25th day of April, being the anniversary of the landing of the Australian and New Zealand forces at Gallipoli, has become the traditional day of remembrance of those who made sacrifices for Australia in armed conflict. The first observance was in 1916 and since then it has become a day of commemoration and public holiday in each State and Territory-truly a national memorial day.

Anzac Day is unique in the world as a national day; it does not commemorate a victory or a defeat or the end of conflict; it does not denigrate a foe or glorify war. Simply it commemorates the sacrifices of the members of the Australian armed forces and their auxilliary services who served Australia in the cause of freedom and who suffered death, injury or loss as a result of their service as members of those forces in the course of armed conflicts in which those forces were engaged. When asked what Anzac Day meant to them, few people would express their feelings in identical terms. For the widows, parents and children of those who have given their lives one element must be public acknowledgement of the debt owed to them. To most their thoughts would be very personal and private, a privacy that should be respected. To those who survive it is an opportunity to remember their fallen comrades and to pay tribute to them. We should ensure that this simple truth and purpose of Anzac Day be neither obscured nor denigrated.

For many the remembrance is of mateship in adversity which made the sacrifices and hardships tolerable, a selflessness which is one of our finest traditions. It is interesting to note the recent finding of three academics from the Australian National University-Dr Hank Nelson, Professor Gavan Daws and Mr Andrew Pike-that mateship was so strong and effective among Austraians that it could be regarded as the prime reason for Australians having the best survival rate in the horror prisoner of war camps of World War II. The classic statement is that no one ever saw an Australian die alone. Today Anzac Day needs protection. Its purpose is in danger of becoming obscured by small minorities who seek to exploit the day to further their own causes. By legislation in the Defence Regulation Act of 1921 the word 'Anzac' is protected and neither it nor any word resembling it may be used as a title or commercially except by permission of the Governor-General. But the Federal Parliament has not yet marked the day as a national day of remembrance. That is the first purpose of this Bill. It is a debt we owe to those who served.

The second purpose is to provide for national commemoration services in the national capital. Since 1916 the Returned Services League has conducted services to commemorate this day throughout the nation. Indeed one of the objectives of the league is to '. . . establish and preserve, . . . the commemoration day known as ''Anzac Day'' '. It seemed to me, therefore, to be appropriate to place the care and conduct of the national services in the hands of the national president of that body. I have discussed this matter with the current national President of the League, Sir William Keys, who approves the concept but wishes to ensure that those who participate do not see their day as having been 'taken over' by the League.

I would not object to the organisation of the national ceremonies being under the control of a committee made up of representatives of the participating bodies. I do not believe however that it is necessary to enshrine such a committee in the Act. Firstly, I point out that the Bill provides for the organisation to be in the hands of the national President, which is a high office in Australia. Probably the national President will establish such a committee to assist him. Secondly, provision is made in the Bill for appeal to the court if a person is aggrieved by a decision of the President. I commend the Bill to the Senate and express the hope that the States and the Northern Territory follow the example.

TAXATION (UNPAID COMPANY TAX) ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT BILL 1983

This Bill, and a further Bill I will introduce shortly, will give effect to this Government's election undertaking to recover personal tax avoided by former owners of companies that were the subject of bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. The Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) legislation was passed by the Parliament last year with the support of the Labor Party in opposition. Indeed, I remind honourable senators that the legislation would not have passed without our support.

Although we supported the legislation, we made it clear that, in government, we would act swiftly to strengthen it in several identified areas and to remove a tax avoidance let-out included by the former Government. Our intention to do this was reaffirmed during the election campaign and the electorate has clearly given us a mandate to proceed with the implementation of these reforms. I turn now to the details of the Bill.
Measures to Recover Personal Tax

By far the greater part of this Bill is related to amendments to give effect to our decision that the restitution expected of those persons who benefited from the sale of shares in companies that were stripped of pre-tax profits should not be limited to the tax that ought to have been paid by the companies concerned. Rather, they should also pay the tax that, as shareholders or other former owners, they escaped through receipt in a non-taxable capital form of accumulated after-tax profits that, if the companies had continued to operate as going concerns, would have been taxable as dividends in their hands. In our view the revenue is just as entitled to have these tax losses made good as it is to have the lost company tax made good. This Government, unlike the former Government, believes, and made it clear last year and during the election campaign, that it sees no distinction in principle between the two.

This Bill will accordingly insert in the recoupment tax law rules to be applied to fix the liability of former owners of a stripped company for personal income tax on accumulatd profits received by them as part of the price received for the sale of their shares. Broadly, these rules will require a former owner of a stripped company to pay income tax on the basis that the company had paid a dividend to the former owner at the time of sale of the shares. The amount of this imputed dividend will be the same proportion of the company's total after- tax accumulated profits as the proportion of the sale consideration received by that owner. The amount of after-tax accumulated profits will be determined after allowance has been made for the unpaid ordinary company tax that is to be recouped under the existing legislation, as proposed to be amended. I observe that personal tax liability under the Bill attaches to profits of stripped companies that have been effectively distributed to former owners, regardless of whether those profits were, in the hands of the company, of a revenue or a capital kind. This rule reflects the clear and long-standing position that a distribution by a company out of any kind of profit is classed as taxable income of the shareholders. But it also does no more than follow the way in which Part IVA of the Income Tax Law-which received the unanimous support of this Parliament when it was introduced in 1981-operates in cases of dividend stripping and similar schemes, including schemes of pre-tax profit stripping. Where Part IVA operates, the shareholders concerned are liable to tax on profits that are stripped from the company under the scheme, and that is so regardless of whether those profits are of a revenue or a capital kind. In other words, we are not by this Bill introducing any new concept of taxation in relation to distributions to shareholders out of capital profits of companies.

The Bill provides that a dividend will be deemed to have been paid in circumstances where the former owner is liable to make good unpaid company tax; that is, where there is a liability for vendors recoupment tax or there would have been such a liability if any payments of company tax made after 25 July 1982 were disregarded. That date is, of course, the date on which the former Government announced its intention to legislate to recover unpaid company tax escaped through bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. This qualification is necessary to ensure that the liability for escaped personal income tax will not be avoided simply by making a payment of the company tax in pursuance of the former Government's announcement or the legislation enacted last year. The requirement that there be or would, but for payments of company tax, be a liability for vendors recoupment tax means that, where the liability for vendors recoupment tax is or would be less than $100 and the Commissioner of Taxation exercises his power under the existing law not to pursue the liability, there will be no liability for the relatively small amounts of personal income tax that would otherwise be liable to be recouped.

Where the former owner concerned is a natural person the imputed dividend is to be included in his or her assessable income. In the case of an entity not itself subject to income tax on the dividend by reason of its tax exempt status or, in certain cases, the inter-company dividend rebate, the imputed amount will of course be treated as tax-free income in the hands of that entity. Where a company, or a person as trustee of a trust, is allocated a dividend that is deemed to have been paid by a stripped company and the owners of that company, or the beneficiaries of that trust, are the same persons as the former owners of the stripped company at the date of its sale, the company or trustee will, in the first instance, be liable to pay dividend recoupment tax on the dividend at the maximum personal rate applicable to the year of income in which the sale of shares occurred.

However, there is to be a right for former owners in this situation to elect to be taxed on amounts equal in total to the amount of the dividend deemed to have been received by the company or trust concerned. If this election is made and the Commissioner is satisfied that the allocation of the deemed dividend among former owners is reasonable and that personal tax, if any, payable by the former owners will, subject to the hardship relief provisions of the income tax law, be paid by them the interposed company or trust will be freed from its liability for dividend recoupment tax. In a similar fashion a stripped company will, where a liability for personal tax or dividend recoupment tax exists, be freed from its liability for undistributed profits tax payable under Division 7, and the former owners will accordingly no longer be liable for vendors recoupment tax on an unpaid Division 7 liability. I mention that a liability for personal tax or dividend recoupment tax will exist even where the only unpaid company tax giving rise to a liability for vendors recoupment tax is a liability for undistributed profits tax under Division 7 of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

As with the existing recoupment tax law, it will be possible under the provisions being inserted by this Bill to trace from the primary level to the next level and, as necessary, successively to further levels where a company or trust has ceased to exist, has different shareholders or beneficiaries as a result of shares or beneficial interests having been sold, or is unlikely to be able to meet a liability for dividend recoupment tax on the dividend which is deemed to have been paid to it. The automatic tracing process applicable in this case will continue until a dividend is deemed to have been paid to a natural person-or tax-free entity referred to earlier-or to a company or trust that still exists if, in the latter situations, the company or trust is one the ownership of which has not changed since the stripped company was sold and has the capacity to meet the dividend recoupment tax payable.

A significant feature of the Bill is the provision of a time-to-pay facility in relation to the personal income tax and dividend recoupment tax liabilities which are to be imposed by this and an associated Bill. This provision is modelled on an existing facility-which is to be retained in a modified form- which permits former owners of companies who are liable to pay a share of unpaid company tax to meet that liability by instalments, typically over twelve months without late payment penalty being charged. Initially, the Government proposed that the existing facility be abolished from a date to be proclaimed. On review, we have accepted that the facility for time to pay should be retained and indeed extended so that a liability for personal tax or dividend recoupment tax may also be paid over 12 months without attracting additional tax for late payment.

The modification of the existing facility I referred to a moment ago is to impose a strict limitation to 12 months as the period for which an arrangement to pay unpaid company tax may be made. Similarly, the proposed facility in relation to personal tax and dividend recoupment tax will require full payment to be made within a period of 12 months if the penalty-free concession is to be attracted. An application for time to pay personal income tax or dividend recoupment tax in respect of a share of a stripped company's accumulated profits will need to be made within 30 days after service of the notice of assessment relating to that liability. Consistent with this it is envisaged that it will generally be necessary that applications for arrangements to pay unpaid company tax by instalments be made within 30 days after the company's tax liability is notified to former owners.
Post-sale avoidance schemes

The recoupment tax legislation contains a let-out provision that operates where the stripped company was the subject of an unsuccessful post-sale scheme to avoid tax. Under this escape clause there is no liability to recoupment tax liability on the people who benefited by non-payment of the company tax. This provision was inserted by the former Government for reasons which are best known to it. In our view it defies logic and it is our announced policy to abolish it. This is to be done by the Bill.
Pre-sale avoidance schemes

Consistently with the removal of the post-sale avoidance scheme provision, this Bill will also ensure that, in ascertaining the potential tax liability of a company for the purposes of determining whether the recoupment tax legislation applies in relation to it, any pre-sale scheme which is ultimately established to be ineffective of its tax avoidance purpose is to be disregarded.

There are several further amendments contained in the Bill designed to improve the administration of the legislation or to correct technical deficiencies. The Bill proposes changes to the cumbersome procedure that requires copies of notices of company assessments to be served on a wide range of former owners. This procedure is very time and resource consuming and is, in our view, quite unnecessary. This Bill provides that in future it will, where only former shareholders are involved, be sufficient if a copy of the company's notice of assessment is served on the principal vendor-shareholder. Otherwise service may be effected on any three representative former owners. This approach is considered to provide an appropriate balance between the requirements of practical administration and perceived fairness to former owners of companies.

It is also proposed by this Bill to remove one of the pre-conditions to liability for recoupment tax-the requirement that the company was by a stripping scheme rendered unable to pay its tax-which was inserted by the previous Government, it seems for presentational purposes. The element that the requirement expresses is, in substance, present in all cases of pre-tax profit stripping to which the legislation applies and a specific reference to it is quite unnecessary. The 'Stripping Scheme Test', and an associated provision requiring full disclosure by the Commissioner of known details of it, is being exploited by some taxpayers as a means of delaying issue of recoupment tax assessments. Because of their availability as a pure delaying tactic, the provisions are having and will, unless removed, continue to have an adverse effect on revenue.

Finally, we propose in this Bill to re-insert in the recoupment tax legislation a provision removed by the previous Government which authorised the Commissioner of Taxation to report to this Parliament the names of persons who fail to meet their liability for vendors or promotors recoupment tax. It is, in our view appropriate that this Parliament, and through it the people of Australia, should know those who remain unrepentant of their attempt to escape their rightful share of the tax burden. The Commissioner is already required to provide in his annual report to Parliament details of breaches or evasions of the taxation laws and it is consistent with that duty that he be authorised, where he considers it appropriate, to report details of failure to pay recoupment tax.

I note that revenue implications of these amendments are significant. The measures contained in this Bill are estimated to yield $570m in total and, subject to what I am about to say, $250m in 1983-84. Payment of personal tax by instalments over a period of 12 months in lieu of payment within 30 days will result in revenue which would have otherwise been collected in 1983-84 not being collected until 1984-85. This is not revenue lost but merely revenue deferred. An accurate estimate of the amount involved has not, in the time available, been possible. Preliminary estimates indicate that a figure of up to $100m could be involved. Studies are currently being made of administrative measures by which this impact on revenue in 1983-84 might be lessened. If the Government had required payment not only of tax owing but also of an additional amount for the period of delay in payment, the total revenue yield would have been $840m.

As usual with amendments of the taxation laws, an explanatory memorandum giving details of the amendments contained in the Bill is being circulated to honourable senators, the main memorandum being complemented by a supplementary memorandum that deals particularly with changes made to the Bill during its consideration by the House of Representatives. It will be clear that while the Government is committed to the principles of the Bill as originally introduced in the other place it has shown a readiness to modify its impact in some areas where we have been persuaded that change is warranted. In that light, I commend the Bill to the Senate.
TAXATION (UNPAID INCOME TAX-DIVIDENDS) BILL 1983

This Bill will formally impose a tax-to be called dividend recoupment tax-on the dividend amount determined in accordance with the rules being inserted in the recoupment tax legislation by the amending Bill I have just introduced.

The underlying purpose of the amendments is to recover personal income tax escaped by individual former owners of stripped companies. That will be done in a direct manner wherever possible. However, in cases where former owners held their shares through interposed companies or trusts recovery may in certain circumstances be by way of imposing on one or more of the interposed companies or trusts a tax equivalent to the maximum personal rate of tax applying in the year of income in which the shares in the stripped company were sold. This Bill will impose that tax. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
