INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT BILL 1983 [No. 2]

This Bill to amend the incomes tax law will give legislative effect to a range of measures that had been announced by the former Government but which it had not implemented by the time the recent election was announced. As mentioned by the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins) in his statement of 30 March 1983, the new Government was confronted with several matters of unfinished taxation legislation, and had to move quickly to determine their future and assign a legislative priority to those that we as a government decided should be put into place. These questions were addressed in his statement of 30 March and this Bill represents the extent to which it has been possible, in the relatively short period that has been available to us, to have the various measures ready for introduction.
Deductions of Tax at Source from Payments for Work and Services

The major proposals which the Bill will implement is the introduction of a system of deductions of tax at source from payments for work and services. Associated with these measures are reporting arrangements for householders who undertake larger domestic building projects and some related amendments to the pay-as-you-earn provisions of the law. This package of amendments was announced by the former Treasurer in the 1982-83 Budget. As the Minister for Finance indicated when he announced on 30 March 1983 the Government's decision to proceed with them, these measures will apply from 1 September 1983.

Mr President, the need for these amendments is clear. Although there is no simple means by which the menace of tax evasion by the non-reporting of income, whether received in cash or otherwise, can be eliminated, the Government is confident that these measures will help in a most significnt way to deal with the problem. The measures involve no new taxes, but only a new system for the collection of tax which is properly payable. Very briefly, they involve the deduction of tax by a person making a payment for contracted work or services and a remittance of amounts deducted to the Commissioner of Taxation on a monthly basis. There will, of course, be an entitlement to a credit in annual assessments for tax deducted from payments.

As previously announced by the Minister for Finance, the intitial operation of the system will, subject to two variations, be confined to payments, to be prescribed by regulation, that are made and received by persons and firms operating within the building and construction, architectural, consultant engineering, surveying and other technical building services, joinery and cabinet making, road transport, motor vehicles repair and cleaning industries.

There are to be some variations of this basic intra-industry approach. These will be in respect of the limited categories of payments from sources outside the building and construction and road transport industries to persons and firms operating within the industries, of which the Minister gave initial details in his statement of 2 May 1983. While the new system will have the scope I have mentioned, the Bill is cast in terms that permit its extension by regulation to payments in other industries as soon as it is practicable to do so.

I stress that under no circumstances will householders be required to make any deduction of tax at source under the proposed measures. However, under associated provisions, a householder who undertakes a private or domestic building project, the cost of which exceeds $10,000, will be required to register with the Commissioner of Taxation and report to him payments made in relation to that project.

The Minister for Finance announced on 2 May 1983 the Government's decision that , except where an exemption or reduced rate certificate has been granted, all payments within the initial scope of the system will be subject to deduction at a single rate of 10 per cent of the gross payment. The Minister also indicated then that, in setting this rate, the Government had to balance the competing considerations of possible cash flow implications for payees if it were too high , and the enforcement benefits of the system that would be lost if it were too low. There is also the fact that, because of the limited initial scope of the system, deduction of tax at this rate will, in many cases, be confined to only a part of a payee's total business receipts.

It is therefore expected that the rate set will in most cases be less than the tax payable on assessment. But for those for whom it might be too high, the Bill makes provision for the Commissioner of Taxation, on the application of a payee, to approve a lesser rate where he is satisfied that that is justified in the particular circumstances.

The new system is primarily one of deduction of tax at source. The measures will, however, permit the Commissioner to issue certificates of exemption which will allow a payee to obtain payment without deduction of tax. Understandably, these certificates will be available only in circumstances where the person concerned has been in business for a significant period and is able to demonstrate that, among other things, a satisfactory taxation record has, in all respects, clearly been maintained.

To repeat what I have already explained, these measures are aimed at eliminating a significant form of tax evasion. Consistently with this objective they contain substantial penalties-court-imposed and statutory-for breaches of obligations under the system.

The Bill will also make amendments to the PAYE provisions of the income tax law to correct technical deficiendies in that area and to clarify the boundary between the PAYE system and the new system of deduction of tax at source. These associated amendments will also ensure that the PAYE provisions do not apply to payments made by householders that are wholly or principally for the labour of a person who is not an employee of the householder within the ordinary meaning of that word.

I come now to a range of industry incentives announced by the former Government that are to be given statutory effect by the Bill. Each of these changes was the subject of modifications outlined by the Minister for Finance in his statement of 30 March 1983, the amendments contained in the Bill give effect to the former Government's announcements. In these circumstances, and as a detailed explanatory memorandum on the provisions of the Bill is being made available to honourable senators, I propose to refer to each matter only in broad terms.
Accelerated Depreciation

The first of the changes is a new system of accelerated depreciation allowances for new and second-hand plant that is acquired by a taxpayer under a contract entered into after 19 July 1982 or that a taxpayer commences to construct after that date. Under the new system, eligible plant will qualify for depreciation on a prime cost basis at a rate of 20 per cent except where, under existing law, eligible plant would attract a rate more than 20 per cent. In those cases a 33 1 /3 per cent rate will apply. The accelerated rates will not apply to motor vehicles-principally cars and station wagons- of a kind at present excluded from the 18 per cent depreciation loading, to structural improvements or, as announced by the Minister in his 30 March statement, to works of art. As part of the package announced by the former Government, the special rate of depreciation applicable to certain primary production plant, including structural improvements for the storage of hay, grain or fodder, is to be increased from 20 per cent to 33 1/3 per cent.

I divert at this point to mention that I will shortly be introducing a further Bill-the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1983. That will, in part, reflect the Government's view that the 33 1/3 per cent rate to apply to primary production plant under the proposals announced by the former Government is excessive. Under amendments proposed by that further Bill, the depreciation rate will revert to 20 per cent, with broad effect from 20 May 1983. In his statement of 30 March the Minister for Finance said that plant that was made the subject of sale and leaseback and similar arrangements would be excluded from the benefits of the new system proposed by this Bill in circumstances where the lessee/end-user would otherwise be depreciating the plant according to previously applicable rates of depreciation. The Bill gives effect to those exclusions.

The Minister also said then that the Government was considering the extent to which plant that comes under new ownership by virtue of mergers and re- organisations of business operations would qualify. It has not proved practicable to incorporate measures dealing with this matter in this Bill. The Minister will however, shortly be announcing details of the Government's proposals that will, as in the case of the sale and leaseback exclusion, have effect from the date of introduction of the concessions.
Depreciation of Non-Residential Buildings

The proposal under this head is a system of income tax deductions for capital expenditure on the construction of new buildings used for the purpose of producing assessable income, otherwise than in providing residential accommodation, where the construction of the building commenced after 19 July 1982. Capital expenditure on building extensions or alterations will similarly qualify. The deduction will be available on the same general basis as the one now available for traveller accommodation buildings, so that fixed annual deductions of 2 1/2 per cent of the construction cost will be allowable over a 40 year period. As announced by the former Government, buildings used in connection with traveller accommodation will continue to qualify for deduction under the existing depreciation arrangements provided for them.
Mining Capital Expenditure

The Bill will amend the arrangements for deducting capital expenditure incurred , after 19 July 1982, in developing a mining property or oil field. Deductions are at present available on a diminishing balance basis calculated by reference to the lesser of 10 years or the estimated life of the mine or oil field. In broad terms, allowable capital expenditure incurred after 19 July 1982 will be allowable by reference to the same maximum life of 10 years, but calculated instead on a straight line basis. The general effect of the new arrangements will be that allowable capital expenditure incurred in a year of income will be deductible in 10 equal instalments in years of income beginning with the year in which the expenditure was incurred. The Bill also corrects some technical defects in earlier provisions.
Investment in Australian Films

The Bill will modify the scheme of tax incentives for investment in the production of qualifying Australian films so that the special 150 per cent deduction that, under the present law, is not available until after the relevant film has been completed and used to produce income, will be allowable in the year in which the eligible expenditure is made. Deduction on the new basis will be conditional on the investor becoming the first owner of an interest in the copyright in the completed film, and using that interest for the purpose of producing assessable income, within two years from the close of the financial year in which moneys are first expended in, or contributed towards, the production of the film. In the event that these conditions are not satisfied any previously allowed deductions will be withdrawn. A further requirement for deduction is that a production agreement securing funds necessary for the production of the film be entered into by the close of the financial year in which moneys are first expended in, or contributed towards, the production of the film. In addition, moneys contributed towards an eligible production are required to be held in a non-interest bearing account opened in relation to the film in the Australian Film Industry Trust Fund. Arrangements for the establishment of that Fund, which is to be administered by the Department of Home Affairs and Environment, are currently being made. In these circumstances, the requirement that contributions be deposited in an account in the fund opened in relation to the film will apply with respect to all contributions made on or after 1 July 1983. The unexpended portion of contributions made before that date will be required to be transferred to the account by 1 July 1983. Payments out of an account opened in the Trust Fund are to be made only for the purpose of expenditure in the production of the film to which the account relates, or by way of refund to contributors.

A system of withholding tax is to apply in relation to amounts withdrawn from the account otherwise than for the purpose of expenditure in the production of the film. Amounts withheld under these arrangements will be applied against tax due on the amended assessment disallowing the 150 per cent deduction claimed by the relevant investor in respect of the amount of his or her contribution not expended in the production of the film. Finally, eligibility for the new deduction arrangements is to be supported by a formal declaration that is required to be lodged by an appropriate person-generally the producer-within one month after the end of the financial year in which contributions towards the production of the film are first made. With the exception of the modifications outlined above, the existing requirements of the concessions will remain unaltered. The year of expenditure basis of deduction will apply to eligible expenditure incurred by an investor under a contract entered into on or after 13 January 1983.
Collection of Tax Payable by Non-Residents

The last of the changes that was foreshadowed by the previous Government is the introduction of special measures to facilitate the collection of tax payable by non-resident beneficiaries of trust estates. This change is connected with steps taken last year to make non-residents ineligible for the zero rate of tax in the personal tax scales. In order to improve Australia's capacity to collect tax payable by trust beneficiaries who do not reside in Australia, this Bill will operate so that the trustee of the relevant trust will be primarily responsible for payment of the tax on income of the trust to which a non-resident beneficiary is presently entitled. The non-resident beneficiary may also be assessed in respect of the trust income, with credit being allowed for the tax paid by the trustee. This change will apply to trust distributions that are made on or after 18 May 1983.

Finally, the Bill also contains amendments to make it clear that interest paid by the Commissioner of Taxation under the proposed Taxation (Interest on Overpayments) Act 1983 will be taxable to the recipient in the income year in which it is paid and to make a technical change in the provisions which limit the cost for depreciation purposes of certain motor vehicles. This later amendment is consequential on a change made in the basis of calculation of the motor vehicle purchase sub-group of the consumer price index, on which annual changes in the limit are based. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
INCOME TAX (RATES) AMENDMENT BILL 1983

This Bill will amend the Income Tax (Rates) Act 1982, which declares the rates of tax for individuals and trustees, who generally pay tax at individual rates. The provisions of this Bill are consequential upon the amendments proposed by the Income Tax Assessment Bill 1983 to strengthen the collection provisions of the income tax law in relation to non-resident beneficiaries of trust estates.

The rate of tax payable by a trustee taxed on behalf of the non-resident company beneficiary is to be the general company rate of 46 per cent and will be declared and imposed by the Income Tax (Companies, Corporate Unit Trusts and Superannuation Funds) Act 1982, which will be amended by a Bill which I will introduce shortly. The present Bill will in these circumstances remove from the scope of the Income Tax (Rates) Act 1982 a trustee who is to be taxed on behalf of a non-resident company beneficiary. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
INCOME TAX (INDIVIDUALS) AMENDMENT BILL 1983

This Bill will amend the Income Tax (Individuals) Act 1982 which formally imposes personal income tax payable for the 1982-83 financial year. The rates imposed by this Act are those declared in the Income Tax (Rates) Act 1982. As I explained in my second reading speech on the Income Tax (Rates) Amendment Bill 1983, a trustee of a trust estate who will be liable to be assessed and to pay tax on behalf of a non-resident company beneficiary of a trust estate is to be taxed at the rate of tax applicable to companies generally and not at individual rates. As a consequence, this Bill will amend the Income Tax (Individuals) Act 1982 so that it does not impose tax on trustees to be taxed in respect of non- resident companies. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
INCOME TAX (COMPANIES, CORPORATE UNIT TRUSTS AND SUPERANNUATION FUNDS) AMENDMENT BILL 1983

This Bill will amend the Income Tax (Companies, Corporate Unit Trusts and Superannuation Funds) Act 1982, which declares and imposes the rates of tax payable for the 1982-83 financial year by companies, trustees of corporate unit trusts and trustees of superannuation funds. As I explained in my accompanying second reading speech on the Income Tax (Rates) Amendment Bill 1983, the amendment proposed by this Bill will extend the operation of the Income Tax ( Companies, Corporate Unit Trusts and Superannuation Funds) Act 1982 so that it also declares and imposes the rate of tax payable-46 per cent-by a trustee of a trust estate who is to be taxed on behalf of a non-resident company beneficiary. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
INCOME TAX (PAYMENTS FOR WORK) CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1983

This Bill is complementary to the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1983 which I introduced earlier. You will recall, Mr President, that in introducing that Bill I outlined for honourable senators features of the proposed system of deductions of tax at source from payments for work and services. The purpose of this Bill is to ensure that a debt payable to the commissioner in respect of such unremitted tax deductions will, in a bankruptcy or liquidation, have the same priority as do unremitted pay-as-you-earn tax deductions. A technical explanation of the Bill is contained in the explanatory memorandum that is to be made available to honourable senators. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

This Bill to amend the income tax law will give effect to some of the taxation proposals announced by the Treasurer on Thursday, 19 May 1983. A further Bill covering the balance of the taxation initiatives announced on 19 May will be introduced in the Budget sittings. Among concessions being terminated by this Bill are the two year write-off for the cost of converting oil-fired plant to an alternative energy source and the 40 per cent conversion allowance for the cost of non-oil-fired plant installed to replace oil-fired plant. As indicated in the Treasurer's statement, neither of these deductions will be available where the expenditure is incurred under contracts entered into after 19 May 1983 or the conversion work is commenced after that date. The special 100 per cent depreciation allowance for petroleum fuel storage facilities will also cease in respect of facilities acquired under a contract entered into after 19 May 1983 and facilities that the taxpayer starts to construct after that date. In a case where fuel storage facilities continue to qualify for the special write-off, an additional eligibility requirement will be that they be in use for the purpose of producing assessable income or installed ready for use for that purpose before 1 July 1984.

As I mentioned in my second reading speech on the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1983 amendments proposed by that Bill will give effect to certain concessions for primary producers announced by the previous Government. By that Bill the special rate of depreciation on a range of primary production plant, including structural improvements for the storage of grain, hay or fodder, is to be increased from 20 per cent to 33 1/3 per cent, broadly with effect from 19 July 1982. The 20 per cent rate will, however, apply only to eligible plant and improvements acquired under a contract entered into after 19 May 1983 or which the taxpayer commenced to construct after that date.

To clear the way for implementation of the Government's Medicare policy, the rebate for basic health insurance contributions is by this Bill to be discontinued in respect of premiums paid to secure cover after 30 June 1983. The earlier-the March 1982-home loan interest rebate will, of course, remain in the law and legislation to modify it as proposed by the Treasurer will be introduced in the Budget sittings.
Interest Withholding Tax

Finally, the Bill also gives effect to the proposal to withdraw the general exemptions from withholding tax in respect of interest on the overseas borrowings of so-called 'Australian entities' and the Australian Industry Development Corporation. The exemption now available in respect of interest on overseas borrowings of Australian resident companies by way of widely distributed bearer debentures issued overseas will not be disturbed and, as I will explain later, new provisions will maintain exemption for government and government authority borrowings affected by the withdrawal of existing exemptions. Withdrawal of the two exemptions will apply to interest on loans raised in pursuance of contractual obligations entered into after 19 May 1983. Interest on existing loans will not be affected. In addition, interest on any loans which are raised in pursuance of contractual obligastions entered into after 19 May 1983, and which meet the requirements of the existing law may continue to be exempt, but only where the interest is paid before the date on which the legislation is enacted and is attributable to that interim period.

Exemption of interest on the overseas borrowings of the States, and of Commonwealth and State authorities, which are raised in pursuance of contractual obligations entered into after 19 May 1983 will be maintained by a new provision . The Bill provides for this procedure to apply also to borrowings of the States, and of Commonwealth and State authorities. The Bill provides, however, that a certificate will not be given if the funds from a particular borrowing will be used by an authority in direct competition with private sector enterprises. A memorandum explaining the technical feature of the Bill will be made available to honourable senators and I think that I do not need to say more at this stage. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Racial Discrimination Act 1975 to remedy a situation which has arisen as a result of a High Court decision which was handed down two weeks ago. The case arose from a complaint made under the racial discrimination provisions of the New South Wales Anti-Discrimination Act. The Court took the view that the Commonwealth's Racial Discrimination Act was intended to cover the whole area of racial discrimination prohibition in Australia, and therefore it was not possible for the State legislation to operate in the same field.

The Government takes the view that constructive developments have taken place in some States in the field of anti-discrimination law and that federal measures should not impinge upon those developments. The High Court decision has meant that the constructive New South Wales racial discrimination provisions are no longer effective.
The New South Wales Government has asked that urgent action be taken to overcome the effect of the court decision, and the Government agrees that it is desirable to do so.

This Bill makes it clear that State and Territory legislation which furthers the objects of the Racial Discrimination Convention can stand along side the Commonwealth legislation. The States of course will need to ensure that their legislation does further those objects and is in a form in which it is able to operate concurrently with the Commonwealth Act.

In New South Wales there were a large number of complaints in various stages of investigation when the Court decision was announced. The Bill has been drafted in such a way as to allow these cases to continue under the State legislation.

As it will be possible in many cases for a person to pursue a remedy under either Commonwealth or State law, provisions have been included to prevent a person from taking action under both laws in respect of the same matter and also to prevent double penalties. I commend this Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AND REPATRIATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Gietzelt) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill gives effect to the Government's proposal, announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in his Economic Statement of 19 May 1983, to introduce an income test on those age and service pensions for persons aged 70 and over which are currently paid free of an income test.
The provisions of the Bill cover both age pensions paid under the Social Security Act 1947 and service pensions paid under the Repatriation Act 1920.

Since November 1978, age and service pensions have been determined free of an income test in respect of persons aged 70 years or more at the May 1978 rates. The single rate is $51.45 a week and the combined married rate is $85.80 a week or $42.90 a week each. However, pensioners have been eligible for a higher indexed rate subject to the normal income test.

The Bill amends these arrangements by introducing an income test which will apply to those pensions which are currently paid free of an income test. Where a single person's income is $200 a week or below, and a married couple's combined income is $333 a week or below, pension will continue to be paid at current rates. However, the rate of pension will be reduced by a dollar for each two dollars of income in excess of those limits.

Pension ceases to be payable to single persons when income reaches $302.90 a week, and in the case of a married couple when combined income reaches $504.60 a week. In the case where a married person is being paid a single rate of pension by reason of seperation due to illness, pension ceases to be payable when combined income reaches $538.80 per week. In any other case where a married person is being paid the single rate of pension, the pension ceases to be payable when combined income reaches $504.60 a week.

In the case of a married pensioner couple, where one is under 70 years and the other is 70 years or over, the rate of pension for the person over 70 years will be calculated in accordance with the new income test, and the rate payable to the person under 70 years will be calculated in accordance with current income test arrangements for persons under 70 years. Blind pensioners will continue to be paid age or service pensions free of any income test.

It is estimated that these changes will bring savings of approximately $167m in 1983-84. This figure is based upon an estimate that about half of some 220,000 current income test free age and service pensioners will have their existing entitlement reduced or terminated. In particular, $7m will be saved in 1983-84 in connection with service pensions where an estimated 6,000 people will be affected by the new arrangements-4,000 will have entitlement reduced and 2,000 will cease to be eligible for pensions.
The proposed amendments will apply on and from the first pension pay day after 1 November 1983, which will be 3 November in the case of age pensions and 10 November in the case of service pensions.
Arrangements are being made to contact all age service pensioners affected by these changes before the amendments take effect in order to ensure as smooth a transition as possible.

Mr President, these measures arise from the Government's commitment to the development of a fair system of retirement incomes based on an awareness of those in greatest need. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the National Service Amendment Bill 1983 be referred to the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs for inquiry and report as soon as possible.

The Senate is being asked to send a reference to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs which is to do with a private member's Bill which I introduced into this chamber some time ago. The Senate gave me leave to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the National Service Act 1951 in respect of persons whose conscientious beliefs do not allow them to engage in military activities. Some may ask why the Committee should accept a reference to do with compulsory military service at a time when it is not a live issue in the Australian community. The larger answer would lie in the remarks I made in my maiden speech on 23 August 1978. That was that as legislators we ought to be reinforcing the individual conscience-an activity which culturally marks us as a free society where the common good cannot be relentlessly pursued by means which destroy the individual's personality. But, more specifically, I believe it is precisely a time when there is none of the hysteria associated with a military campaign that is most suitable for a careful look at the issues involved.

The types of questions of interest to the Committee, and about which we are anxious to receive evidence include the following: The large question is what is to count as a conscientious objection. How does one distinguish a belief binding in conscience from a sincerely held political view? Is there such a distinction? Does a religious, moral or ethical basis to the conscientious objection need to be demonstrated?

Of pressing concern to many of us, particularly after the experience of national service during the Vietnam war, is the fact that, as presently drafted, the Act protects the integrity of the individual who maintains opposition to all military service in any circumstances-the Quaker position or its secular equivalent. But there is a strong tradition in Judaeo-Christian and Western ethics which distinguishes between particular military conflicts and attempts to discern whether a war is 'just' or 'unjust'. A properly informed conscience will rebel at participation in an unjust war, but would be willing to participate in a just war-for example, clear defence of national territory. Again, activities during an otherwise just war, such as the indiscriminate slaughter of civilian populations, can lead to the conclusion that the war has become unjust. The Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee will need to determine whether and how this discrimination between wars can be allowed for.

The Committee will need to take evidence from the Government and defence forces to ascertain the sort of impact which such a wider provision might have on the recruiting program for service in an armed conflict which our democratically elected government has endorsed. Would it render it impossible to raise the forces necessary? How, if at all, could the defence forces deal with changing judgments of the moral propriety of the conflict as it progresses? I can assure you, Mr President, that the Committee will be very aware of these problems.

A third area which the Committee may wish to consider, and in relation to which it would appreciate evidence, is the question of who should determine the validity of the conscientious objection. During the Vietnam war, the task was entrusted to the magistrates court, where it was not always clear that the magistrate confined himself to ascertaining the facts of conscientious objection . Too often the Bench was tempted to find against the applicant on the basis of confused reasoning, or that divergence between principles and practice which afflicts us all. It may be that some other tribunal could be established and the questions it ought to answer could be more clearly defined.

I have indicated some of the matters which the Committee will need to consider. I hope that we will be aided, as quickly and briefly as possible, by individuals or organisations by way of written submission, which may later be supplemented and clarified by public hearings. Advertisements will appear shortly in the national newspapers inviting submissions to the Committee here at Parliament House. I commend the reference to the interest of all Australians.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Ministerial Statement
Debate resumed from 26 May, on motion by Senator Button:
That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight the Senate is debating the economic statement which was put down in the House of Representatives on 19 May. At the request of the Government we are conducting a cognate debate. I mention that now to ensure that that is the basis of this debate. It is a cognate debate on the statement and on the legislation which is presently before the Senate which will put into effect some of the measures which were announced in the mini-Budget. During the debate there will be reference to the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill, the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Social Security and Repatriation Legislation Amendment Bill, all of 1983.

SPEECH.PARA: The economic statement which was made by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on 19 May is of considerable importance to Australia, not least because the statement is the first real indication that we have had of decisions being made by the Government as against its indulgence in rhetoric and public education. The statement is seen by the Government itself as being important. Indeed in the early paragraphs it is made quite clear that whilst the statement covers a limited number of decisions by the Government it is to be taken as indicative of the direction in which the Government will be moving. The Treasurer said:

The decisions . . . should be taken as indicative of the directions in which we will be moving in the months and years ahead and, in particular, in the Budget for 1983-84 to be brought down on 23 August.

We have in this statement something which has an importance quite apart from the actual measures that it proposes and which falls to be implemented during the current sittings of the Parliament. I think it is fair to say that the statement is a great disappointment to all shades of economic opinion. I will summarise during my speech the reasons I say that. Effectively the statement casts aside the basic policy of expansion on which the Government went to the people. The statement on 19 May broke many, if not most, of those Labor promises which still remained to be broken. The statement fails to come to grips with the deficit of which the Government has made so much since the election. The statement was brought down in an economic situation which Labor, under the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, promised to change. Yet it is fairly neutral with any changes being contrary to what was promised the Australian people. In summary, the statement is a nothing. That means that Labor has deserted its fundamental campaign promise to change the Government's economic policy.

In August last year when the previous Government, the Fraser Government, brought down its last Budget the Australian Labor Party's reaction and response to that Budget was recorded. In August last year the then Leader of the Opposition, Mr Hayden, began his speech on the Appropriation Bills by characterising our Budget as 'a betrayal of the Australian people'. His final description of that Budget was that it was destructive. In between that initial comment and his final description was a lot of colourful rhetoric. If honourable senators go through that rhetoric they will find there was only one fundamental criticism of what the Fraser Government was doing last August. That criticism, made by the Labor Party through the mouth of Mr Hayden, was that the Budget was insufficiently expansionary. There were two aspects to that: The deficit was found to be wanting-that is, it was not a sufficiently high deficit for Australia's current circumstances-and the tax cuts which were put forward by the Government were inadequate. It would not be politically realistic to expect the present Government to give us an honest, unbiased assessment of what last year's Budget was really like, but I think in this economic statement we now have an implicit acknowledgment that the former Government's Budget and post-Budget strategies were working. I think we should look at the words used by Mr Keating in his statement. He said:
. . . we expect some improvement in economic activity in the course of 1983-84 with the main impetus coming from:
Then he listed half a dozen reasons. The first reason he mentioned was:

The fiscal stimulus implicit in the Commonwealth Budget for 1982-83 and in prospect from 1983-84; the improvement in the international economy; a marked slowing in stock decumulation so that a greater proportion of increased demand will be met from additional production; the improved prospects for farm production and exports; the pick-up in dwelling construction already under way; and finally, but of fundamental importance, the improved prospects for ongoing moderation of income claims as the prices and incomes accord is implemented.

That statement is something of a landmark because whilst neither the Government nor the Opposition can claim credit for breaking the drought or for the improvement in the international economy, most of the encouraging signs picked up by the Treasurer in the passage I have quoted and eleswhere in the statement flow directly either from the last Budget or from the wages freeze instituted by the previous Government. All too evidently, the Budget of the Fraser Government- the last Budget-was neither a betrayal nor was it destructive. It is evident that Mr Hayden's rhetoric of August 1982 was just a little too colourful, and it is evident too that there has been a change of heart on the part of the Labor Party.

I think we have gone beyond the tacit endorsement of the former Government's policy, ungenerous and limited as it is in this statement. The whole tone of the economic statement suggests nothing less than a complete turnaround on economic policy. In some respects the turnabout is rhetorical because there is little real underpinning of the directions which the statement suggests, but it is meant by Mr Keating to be indicative, and we are presumably meant to take some notice of the rhetoric as well as the actual measures which are proposed. It is important to remember in assessing the statement that what was said by Mr Hayden immediately after the Budget last year was pursued by the Labor Party for the next six months. If one looks at the documents which were put down by Labor before the election one sees a continuation of the sort of themes which were struck after the Budget. Labor's national recovery and reconstruction plan states:
The principal cause of our continually poor economic performance and our current alarming decline has been the constant contraction and eventual collapse of the demand for goods and services.
It said later that the Liberals:
. . . used Australia as a guinea pig in an abortive monetarist experiment. Each year budgets were more contractionary. Each year monetary policy was tightened.
Again, a little later in Labor's economic statement it is stated:
We were told that even last year's deficit was 'still contractionary'.

Labor did not rest on putting forward a criticism of what the then Government was doing. It offered an unmistakably clear alternative and went on offering that alternative right to the day it was elected. I shall quote from that same document, the ALP economic policy, which was produced only a few months ago. That document states:
The principal thrust of Labor's economic strategy will be to reject the policies of contraction and embrace the policies of expansion . . .
Later it states:
. . . the achievement of these aims requires a substantial change in national economic policies to urgently lift demand . . .
Again a little later it states:
Labor will not wait until the 1983-84 Budget to commence this recovery program. Immediate action will be taken to stimulate activity in key sectors.

There is no room for doubt about what Labor was saying was required. There is no room for doubt about what Labor was promising the Australian people. Indeed, some of the machinery was spelt out in detail. I shall quote from the election policy speech which again was given only a matter of a few months ago by Mr Hawke. What were we told by Mr Hawke in that policy speech? We were told this:
There can be no lift in profits or a lift in growth unless there is a lift in demand. And that cannot be done by taking money out of the weekly pay packet or the pensioner's cheque.
Later, he said:
. . . increased growth will be restored by . . . tax reductions for low and middle income earners.

I really do not have to repeat the details of the sorts of tax cuts indicated by Labor. We all remember that six million Australians were to get them. I do need to repeat the Prime Minister's words about promises. He stated:
I offer no fistful of dollars to be snatched back after the election.

We were given to understand before the election that the ALP, if elected, would not only pursue an expansionary policy but also that there would be no ceiling on the expansion. Why else were we told in February that Mr Hawke's idea of an acceptable deficit was four times higher than Mr Hayden's had been in August? Why else were we told by the present Prime Minister to throw away our calculators?

We are entitled to ask whether the party which is led by Mr Hawke, the Labor Government, is the same party which has now produced this economic statement. Three months ago it described the Fraser Government as being obsessed with monetary matters. Now Mr Keating-in this I think he is quite right-is expressing concern that the growth in money supply is off target. With all due caution he does not bother to state a revised target. He is a more careful man than that. Without a single blush he states:
Monetary growth as rapid as the current level of 12 per cent or so is not consistent with this Government's objectives and prompt action is necessary to bring it down.

This statement was made by the leading economic spokesman for the party that talked about the monetarist policies of the previous Government. Now, without a blush, he describes those policies as not having been pursued adequately or effectively. He tries to don the same clothes as the previous Government. Indeed , the central feature in this statement is that he is taking action to bring the money supply under control.

We are entitled to ask whether in this statement we can detect the beginning of a splendid monetarist obsession on the part of the new Labor Government. We can be forgiven for wondering whether this is the same party which, before the election, in the most explicit terms wanted to increase demand by increasing both weekly pay packets and pensioner's cheques. Mr Keating is now expressing his approval that wage increases moderated in the March quarter and that real wages declined slightly. What an extraordinary change! The economic statement put down by Mr Keating expresses approval of the fact that wage increases have moderated in the March quarter. The conversion is not limited to Mr Keating. Many honourable senators will recall the speech made by Senator Walsh in a matter of public importance brought forward by the Opposition on 4 May. On page 177 of Hansard he stated:
I believe, and the Government believes and has made explicit on many occasions, that a fall in real wages is very likely an essential component of a package for economic recovery.
Again, that reflects very clearly what Mr Keating said in another part of the economic statement, in which he talked about the factors that have contributed to our economic malaise. He stated:
. . . realistic expectations, generated for political ends, which had resulted in large increases in real wage levels for some and unemployment for others;

A confused electorate might be entitled to ask: 'Whose rhetoric is this? How can this come from the mouths of those who preached such different policies a matter of a few months ago?' Of course, the economic statement, does not, in a direct sense, come to grips with those problems. Rather than face that reality head on, it takes a number of actions which eat away at the real incomes of ordinary suburban Australians. This Government, through the abolition of the home loan interest rebate, the health insurance rebate and a number of other smaller measures, has whittled away at household incomes, something which a few months ago it would have told us would reduce demand and thereby damage the economy. The tax cuts which were promised to stimulate demand are passed over in silence. It appears, as we claimed before the election, that further tax cuts could not be afforded; or was the demand diagnosis that Labor put forward wrong in the first place?

The Opposition can be forgiven for wondering too-I believe that this sense of wonderment would be shared by the Australian people-whether this is the same party which showed such a cavalier disregard for the size of the deficit. Now Mr Keating tells us that a prospective deficit approaching $10 billion is simply not on. That is, of course, yet another of the road to Damascus conversions with which this Government's short life has been littered. We can welcome those conversions. But once again the Treasurer's response falls short of his Government's new-found rhetoric. He displays, in his analysis of the deficit problem, an astonishing naivety. I quote the Treasurer again. Apparently in all innocence, he said:

We found that a substantial proportion of the costs of tax concessions announced in and immediately prior to the 1982-83 Budget by the former Government-amounting to around $3000m-first come to account next financial year.

The statement by the Treasurer that the Government has discovered what the actual tax promises made by the previous Government were and that they came into effect only since it came into government suggests either that it failed to read the Budget or that it read it but failed to understand it. I believe that either is possible on the performance we have seen over the last month or two.

The Treasurer's response to the allegedly horrendous legacy the Government has received is also astonishing. The new expenditure initiatives announced in this statement will add an estimated $557m to outlays next year. There are savings which are estimated to total $985m but the bottom line comes to net savings of $ 428m. But, of course, the statement does not pick up some of the committed expenditures for next year, principally the proposal for a new compulsory health care system. If those new expenditure proposals of the Government are included, of course, the savings are in fact negligible. The impact on the deficit of the actions taken by the Government and proposed so far is virtually nil. That is why I said earlier in my speech that this mini-Budget is a nothing. It does not come to grips with the deficit which we are being told by the Government over and over again is so important.

It is also true that in the statement Mr Keating has not said what he or the Government now considers to be an acceptable size for the deficit, nor has he had the honesty to admit that as growth estimates are revised upwards, the projected deficit must shrink. Honourable senators will recall the guarded way in which questions on that subject were answered by the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) this morning. It is quite clear to any observer that the $9.6 billion figure which is still being used by the Government whenever it can is a figure which has been greatly reduced by the recent forecasts of growth in the Australian economy. That figure is one on which no reliance can be placed . Yet this statement which was put out on 19 May, on a day when senior Labor advisers were admitting that the growth forecast had been revised, makes reference in the early paragraphs to the 'parlous budgetary situation which we have inherited'. Why was the Government not honest enough to come out with a revised estimate when it has been so critical of the previous Government's failure to put that matter before the people?

This economic statement is, of course, a first attempt by the new Government. In many ways we welcome the apparent conversion to fiscal and monetary rectitude which it represents. But the conversion, as I said earlier, is rhetorical rather than real. In various ways which have already been the subject of debate in this place the measures in this statement are misconceived. We all look forward with enormous interest to seeing what the full Budget will bring in August.

In the time which remains to me I would like to touch on those matters which in fact are left unresolved by this statement. The Treasurer, in the concluding remarks of his statement, touched all too lightly on the central issue of wages. He then skittered off, leaving behind a trail of platitudes. We gather, perhaps wrongly, that the Government cannot bring itself to move towards a wages policy which resembles scenario C of the National Economic Summit Conference. That, we are told by the Government, would be a triumph of hope over experience. I think it is fair to ask: If that is true, if the scenario which promises a reduction in unemployment in Australia is a scenario which could hope for but not achieve, what in the world was the point of the Economic Summit? It would appear that the only point of the Summit was to ratify, before a wider audience, the Australian Labor Party-Australian Council of Trade Unions accord.

The Summit did us the great service of diagnosing the problem. It pointed to the remedy but in the end the Government, indeed many other observers, said that the remedy was too hard. It is simply not attainable; it is not in line with reality. I think that is the tragedy of the situation in which the Government has placed itself in this economic statement. Given the very considerable good will generated before, during and after the Summit, might we not have expected that there could have been some triumph of hope over experience, that the unemployed in Australia could have expected that that reality which stands in the way of their getting jobs might have been overcome? I remind the Government of Mr Hawke's words in the closing stages of the election campaign:
There is a need for a new coalition-not the coalition of fear but the coalition of hope.

I think the most damning thing that could be said about this Government is that it has put the reality squarely before the Australian people in the material that it put down at the Economic Summit and it confessed that it was unable to come to grips with the problem. That inability is in the face of surveys which showed quite clearly that the great bulk of the Australian people would support an extension of the wage freeze in the interests of maintaining and improving the employment situation. That has been written I suppose in every newspaper in the country in letters which are high enough for any Government Minister to read . I quote from one recent headline entitled 'Keep Pay Freeze, Say Most'. The article states:
Most Australians want the wage freeze extended after next month.
And most of these say it should be continued for at least six months.

The sad fact of the matter is, as the Government has conceded, that industrial realities do not permit it to pursue that course which would help the unemployed in Australia. A number of things are made quite clear by this statement. It is clear that the Hawke Government gained office by a massive deception of the electorate. It promised expansion and it is practising contraction. It promised an end to monetarism and an end to calculators and it practises a real concern for monetary supply. It said that the calculators would be thrown away and it talks of nothing but the size of the deficit. It promised to put demand creating dollars into the pockets of pensioners and taxpayers and it has done the reverse . I really wonder which honourable senators on the Government side are able to look their constituents in the eye and truly say: 'We are doing what your elected us to do. We are behaving in the way in which we said we would behave before we were elected'.

In less than three months in government there has been a reversal of form which is borne out, I believe, by the extensive quoting in this place today of what Mr John Hyde had to say. Who would have believed at the time of the election that this Government would be justifying contractionary policies on the basis of arguments in the newspapers put forward by Mr Hyde? I wonder whether the gentleman who took his seat-the new honourable member for Moore (Mr Blanchard)- will have very much trouble explaining to his constituents that their mentor appears to be the former honourable member for Moore who is supporting what is being done. I do not believe that honourable senators opposite can escape the irony of the quoting of those passages in support of the case of the Government today. What I have said about that might indicate support for the package.

I must say that in the pre-election period I confidently predicted that all the promises of the then Opposition, soon to be Government, would be broken. But I wish to stress what I see as the key point of concern for Australia-concern about the question of jobs and the creation of employment. We have a clear demonstration by this Government that its wages policy cannot come to grips with the circumstances which are required to create greater employment in Australia. Reality is too strong for this Government. That reality is the reality of the trade union movement which can hold the line against a clear majority of the public in Australia. Until the Government is able to overbear that reality it seems that the promises it made to the Australian people last March will never be fulfilled.

SPEECH.PARA: The simple fact of the matter of which we have to remind the Opposition over and over again is that we came to power knowing that we had an horrendous unemployment situation, that the level of unemployment was going through the roof and that from May to October last year the trend in unemployment in this country was the complete reverse of what it had been in previous years. In fact, at the same time inflation and interest rates were increasing. That was the situation which faced this Government when it came to power. That situation was only aggravated by the fact that this country, this Government and this Parliament had been misled about the state of the economic situation in relation to the Budget deficit.

We came into power and the first thing we did at the first Cabinet meeting was to announce that we would have the economic summit which had been announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), then the Leader of the Opposition. Incidentally, we announced that we would increase the unemployment benefit for those without dependants, which was also a promise made in the election campaign. Over four days we discussed the sorts of problems which were facing this country and how we might solve them. The result of that Summit was universal praise. The economic commentators and leaders of the business community in this country said that at last people were actually getting together and discussing what was wrong and what might be done.

There was only one jarring note at that time and, of course, that came from the now Leader of the Opposition, Mr Peacock, and the Leader of the National Party, Mr Anthony. But even people in the Opposition such as Mr Macphee and others who take a more reasonable attitude to this matter said that the Summit had been a worthwhile and useful exercise. The Government then looked at the difficult problems which were facing this country-not the least being the horrendous deficit-and brought down an economic statement. It was not a Budget but certainly it was a statement which should be seen in the context that a Budget will be brought down later this year. The Government brought down policies in that statement which, I put to the Senate, have been more than well received by the vast majority of people in this community.

We introduced programs to stimulate the housing industry and the development of housing in the community, the housing industry at present being at its most depressed since 1961. The building industry and the permanent building societies have universally praised the measures put forward by the Government in its economic statement because they are aware that the measures will result in an increase in construction, an increase in the number of houses being built and an increase in stimulation to the housing industry in general. We introduced unpopular measures in some quarters. We had a debate this afternoon about the new arrangements relating to superannuation payments. I point out to the Senate that although there were complaints from some people, particularly people like airline pilots who receive large lump sum payments with very-

TALK.START.PARA: —And all the people in Bruce.

—I will talk about that in a moment too. We will not get away from that. I was referring to airline pilots who receive large lump sum payments and privileged tax provisions. The insurance industry and the superannuation industry-in fact, almost every economic commentator in this country-praised what the Government was doing. I note that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and former Treasurer has not criticised those moves, unlike some churlish senators opposite.
