SPEECH.PARA: I remind the Senate that the key issue upon which this Government was elected- it is a matter we are very much concerned about-is the plight of the unemployed. Unemployment has doubled; it had reached record levels and was continuing to rise inexorably under the previous Government. Therefore in the economic statement and in the policy documents and legislation which came down with it, as the Treasurer (Mr Keating) says:
. . . the objective has been to frame our budgetary policies to contribute both to reducing unemployment and to winding back inflation.

That is why in instituting the community works program, in winding back the deficit, in acting against unemployment to stimulate private industry and in acting to stimulate the building industry we have taken this line in the economic statement-the mini-Budget, if that is what people want to call it. We did it first of all so that we could provide some immediate stimulation for employment through the community works program and through the housing program but at the same time we could prepare the way for the Budget to promote a stimulation of both the public and private sectors in the community. We wanted to stimulate employment directly because it is a real problem. We were concerned also about the unemployed, in particular the single unemployed, who have been deprived of index benefits by the previous Government since 1978. That is why in the first couple of days of government we provided for an increase in the single unemployment benefit rate.

Our aim will be to maintain a policy which is concerned with increasing employment in this community, which reverses the disastrous situation facing the housing industry and the building industry in general in this community, which is responsible and which does not promote the inflationary policies that the previous Government wished quite clearly to promote in its last Budget. At the same time we wish to show concern for those in the community who are disadvantaged. That is why we took the hard decision, realising that until we removed the anomaly which existed in the superannuation system, whereby the 40 per cent who were able to receive lump sums were subsidised by the 60 per cent who were unable to receive lump sums, we would not make the first step towards redistributing the welfare dollar in the community. Those decisions were not popular. One would expect from hearing Senator Chaney, the interjections from Senator Walters, and others in the community that the taking of those unpopular steps, which we had to take, had resulted in the Government becoming enormously unpopular. Yet in the Bruce by-election, sure, by misrepresentation and everything else, one per cent of the people changed their votes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on!

—If that is the result of taking what Senator Chaney described tonight as horrendous economic steps and of doing what Senator Sir John Carrick described this afternoon as striking at the very heart of the Australian way of life and other motherhood statements, we do not mind; we will take such measures . The problem with the previous Government is that it talked about taking measures in the 1982 Budget. Senator Chaney told us that it was going to stop double dipping but six months later had to admit that it could not do so. He really ought to have said that it was not game. The previous Government talked about it when Mr Howard and Mr Street announced in 1979 that something would have to be done about the inequities of the retirement provisions of the superannuation funds in this country. It talked about it for seven years, and during all that time it tried to blame the Whitlam Government which had been in power for only three years and which had had its term of office interrupted by an election.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government is a responsible government. This Government will continue to take responsible decisions, even if they are unpopular, and this Government will take courageous decisions if they are necessary. We quoted Mr Hyde's article not because he necessarily agreed with Labor Party policies, although he agreed with some of the things we had done, but because his article in essence was a call for the Opposition to be responsible and to judge what was done on the good it would do to this country. Yet I am afraid that last week in the Senate we did not get that. What is more, this week in the Senate we are obviously not going to get that. We will get nit-picking; we will get the sort of rhetoric we heard this afternoon from speakers on the matter of public importance; we will get a continuation of the inane interjections that we hear from the female senator from Tasmania. That disappoints me, because we never pretended, and do not pretend now, that we can solve the problems of this country after only three months in government. We are flattered that Senator Chaney tonight upbraided us for not solving the problems in three months. But I am absolutely certain that we can do a very much better job in three years than the previous Government did in seven years. We certainly will not have to go to elections early and make promises which we know we will have to reverse as soon as we get to power, as the previous Government did at the last election, the election before and the election before that. In fact, the people of this country respect the people who make hard, courageous and difficult decisions. They will continue to respect the actions of this Government, as they did after the statement by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on 19 May, and they will continue to do so after the Budget in August this year which will be the completion of that program.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The economic statement was particularly disappointing in its omissions when it purports to be indicative of the direction the Government intends to take. My leader, Senator Chaney, spoke in a general way of its failures but I want to look at one omission. Senator Grimes has called for positive suggestions from the Opposition. I hope I can give him some. They are from a report that was in the hands of the Government at the time of the mini-Budget and upon which the Government should have acted. The omission that I particularly want to look at has been spoken of by the shadow Minister for Science and Technology, Dr Harry Edwards, who condemned the Government for taking no positive action in the mini-Budget to help launch high technology industries.

SPEECH.PARA: We should not be surprised at this omission from the mini-Budget. The inertia against change within the Labor Party had earlier been forecast when the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones), in a speech to the National Science Forum said, in far too dramatic a way for the Government to accept:
. . . our decline in manufacturing employment is not a temporary anomaly to be rectified by tariffs, wage freeze, bounties, quotas and other fiscal measures-or Buy Australia campaigns.
He announced:
I will . . . be presenting a paper to the Economic Summit Meeting in Canberra next week which, as you would expect, puts a very heavy emphasis on science and technology.
Of course, his invitation to speak was withdrawn. It was publicly reported that his speech was too controversial.

There has recently been a growing recognition that the Australian economy is undergoing fundamental change. It is a pity that that fundamental change has not been recognised by the Australian Labor Party. Regrettably, that change has not been planned or guided. It has come about because it is inevitable as enterprise and economies accept the need for efficiency to survive and realise the role that products of the technological revolution can play in that challenge. It is a fundamental and structural change. That was not appreciated by the Labor Party , as is evident from its mini-Budget statement. It is a structural change over and above the current world recession. Although that recession has on the one hand tended to accentuate the pain of change by more rapid dislocation, on the other hand it has sharpened the distinction between those embracing the benefits of change and those who have attempted to reject the inevitability of that change.

Its most marked public posturing has been in its effect upon employment in manufacturing where, despite considerable government protection in many areas, employment in Australia has fallen by over 100,000 people, or 8 per cent, in 12 years to June 1981. The Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Grimes, said a few minutes ago that his Government had come to power for a particular reason-to overcome that shocking unemployment.
The current Minister for Science and Technology, Mr Barry Jones, has, I believe correctly, said:

We do not have an industrial society in decline and needing temporary support to restore but a new kind of society based on a different economic basis ( knowledge and skill rather than on raw materials and muscle power).

Extractive and primary industries, important as they are, will be insufficient to maintain an improving standard of living for Australians, although the enormous natural advantage Australia has in these areas, and with a small basically well educated population and a stable system of government should have provided an excellent launching position. It will be the nations with high skills which produce goods and products which will be strong and wealthy in the future. Look at the tremendous growth rates of countries such as Japan, Taiwan, Singapore and now, South Korea, which evidence the fact that ready availability of natural resources is not essential. Not even the oil price hike slowed Japan. Lest it be said that the Asian nations have started from a lower base, which is of course true, look at Switzerland, Sweden, Denmark and the Netherlands. In Western developed societies the nations with the greatest increases in GNP since 1955 have lacked natural resources and instead have put heavy emphasis on the development of skills.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about arms expenditure? That is a very important factor; the fact that Japan does not spend very much on arms.
—We would all very much like to see a world that spent less on arms . We are most certainly in agreement.
—There would be more money for technological development.

—That is very true, I agree. In fact it might be said that natural wealth has encouraged apathy, whereas those without natural advantage have more readily accepted the challenge of change. It is this challenge of change that the new Labor Government will have to face up to. Change itself is not bad. Those of us who accept the concept of a dynamic economy realise that it will be continually changing and developing desirably for the benefit of all. To adopt the words of the cover story in this week's Time magazine on the subject of the new economy:

SPEECH.PARA: Yet even as the lights are dimming in some old line industries, technology is spawning boundless opportunities in such esoteric fields as micro electronics, lasers, fibre optics and genetic engineering.

It is pity that the draftsmen of the mini-Budget did not bear that fact in mind at the time of drafting. The example was given of the Apple Corporation in the United States of America which, in six years, has evolved from a two-man operation in a garage to a corporation employing more than 4,000 people in permanent jobs, not temporary, part time jobs. On the subject of developing high technology enterprises for Australia, the report of the Espie High Technology Financing Committee was in the hands of the Government at the time of drafting the mini-Budget. It stated:
Major studies in USA have shown that nearly all the net new jobs in the private sector are created by young, high growth companies.

What is of great concern to Australia, as was observed by the report, is that Australia is failing totally to generate new establishments which grow to replace those being lost. I understand that of the 50 largest companies operating in Australia only four, all overseas owned, have been formed since 1936. In Australia the tendency is rather towards consolidation, towards already existing companies, and new industries are being taken up by foreign companies. It is what the Minister for Science and Technology, Mr Barry Jones, has referred to as the corporate profile of an aging country, not a new one. It is a pity that the Government did not bear in mind the very correct words of its relevant Minister in that regard. Indeed, it is stated in the Espie report:
Australia's performance in the high technology sector is being outstripped by many of its developing neighbours in the Asian region.

These are the countries to which we should be exporting technology. What we are looking at is increasingly paying for high technology products from developing countries-not just mass produced items-from our exports of mineral resources and primary production and, therefore, increasingly importing unemployment. That particularly is what this new Labor Government should appreciate. What is happening, as is stated in the report, is that the trend in Australia is to a de -industrialization process rather than the normal progression for a post- industrialised society. The Espie Committee was, of course, an initiative of the Fraser Government, which may soon be forgotten. Its task was to examine problems facing the creation and growth of high technology enterprises in Australia. First, it emphasised the important potential of high technology enterprises in employment and wealth generation in the Australian community which, the report states:

. . . have the potential to create demand not only for highly qualified employees but for a broad cross section of skilled and unskilled employment and recognized a number of obstacles in the development of such industries.

Time does not permit me to detail the obstacles, but they cover areas of lack of management skills and the failure of education in that regard; the need for ever continuing and substantial research and development expenditure because of the high rate of obsolescence of high technology products; deficient effective interaction between high technology enterprises and academic and research institutions; the lack of a well developed industrial technology infrastructure necessary for the supply of specialised components and technical services to its high technology industries; continuing loss to overseas of good, technically qualified people because of a lack of business employment opportunities in Australia; similar loss of Australian inventions; lack of resources and skills to market high technology products; alleged reluctance of the Commonwealth Government to purchase Australian high technology; and a general community attitude unsupportive of entrepreneurship and profit making. In each of these areas of obstacle the Committee proposed solutions. It is these solutions that the Government should have referred to in its mini-Budget. Of course, none of the solutions raised was mentioned.

But above all, the report identified and made recommendations in relation to the financial obstacles inhibiting the development of high technology enterprises in Australia. On one of the financial obstacles the report stated:
High technology entrepreneurs have unreasonable difficulty in raising finance for the start up and early growth phases of their enterprises . . .
The report lists a further five obstacles. To save the time of the Senate tonight I seek leave to have them incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

(b) Equity finance, which is the appropriate funding for the start up and early growth phases, has rarely been available in Australia. Loan finance, when it can be obtained, involves servicing costs which compound cash flow problems.

(c) The Australian finance market has a serious gap, namely the lack of a venture capital market(1) with an established modus operandi, identifiable physical location, specialised skills, entrepreneurial attitude and ongoing multiple sources of funding. This deficiency substantially reduces the prospects for start up and the chances of success for Australian high technology enterprises compared to their counterparts in other countries such as the USA.

(d) The difficulty in trading in shares of private companies in Australia inhibits venture capitalists from taking and reinvesting their gains and is an impediment to the establishment of a venture capital market.

(e) Given the absence of a venture capital market, existing financial institutions such as banks(1) are currently being requested to fulfil an inappropriate role as providers of capital for start up and early growth and have refrained from filling this role. Furthermore, the current restriction on interest rates for small business overdrafts discourages banks from lending to high risk ventures.

(f) While Australia does not have a generally applicable capital gains tax, the Government has been forced to adopt a variety of measures to overcome tax avoidance. Two examples of these, which severely penalise many high technology enterprises and discourage prospective venture capitalists, are undistributed profits tax on private companies and the tax treatment of share issues to key employees.

(1) This is a highly specialised financial service. It requires an ability to assess the commercial implications of specific technologies, the judgment to select high growth ventures where market prospects are uncertain, and the capabilities to provide advice and support to management at critical periods in the development of enterprises. Private venture capitalists also need to develop a well balanced portfolio of equity investments to obtain the rates of return needed to offset the uncertainty of individual ventures. These returns are achieved by overseas venture capitalists primarily through taking gains on the value of shares rather than through dividends.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question that immediately comes to mind is whether the Government need concern itself with more than the macro- economic matters of attempts to lower inflation and interest rates in order to provide an answer to the financial obstacles which have been recognised in the report as necessary to be overcome in the development of high technology in Australia. It is interesting that Espie says on that subject:

SPEECH.PARA: This Committee knows of no country which has succeeded in establishing a climate for investment in high technology enterprises without the Government taking positive action and, at a minimum, adopting a catalytic role.

Espie believed government could take a priority role in overcoming the deficiency that the Australian society has no effective vehicle for marshalling its people's savings towards the equity funding of new industrial enterprises. To the Committee, government incentives were necessary to channel capital into the crucial start-up and early growth phases of enterprises-that is, the phase when the market potential of an enterprise and its products, and the eventual returns to an investor, are most difficult to forecast.

Espie sought the best vehicle or mechanisms for the flow of venture capital to high technology enterprises. In particular, he assessed venture capital companies-that is, small specialised financial organisations which provide 'seed ' start-up and development capital and management guidance to new businesses such as those operating in the United States of America. He also assessed a new government venture capital authority of which there are numerous overseas examples, including the Japanese Development Bank, the British Technology Group and the Irish Industrial Development Authority. A variation in the form of an innovation authority was recommended some years ago in the report of the Crawford Study Group on Structural Adjustment. He also looked at an expaned role for existing government owned financial institutions, particularly the Australian Industry Development Corporation or the Commonwealth Development Bank of Australia. Espie also considered direct incentives, say in the form of a taxation benefit for an investment in new high-tech enterprises with perhaps mandatory management guidance. Further, he assessed incentives directed to large corporations to set aside funds for investment in growth business. He also considered support for innovation centres, being centres typically providing advice and resources to assist in commercialising new technical ideas of which examples exist in the United States, Denmark and the United Kingdom.

The Committee saw greatest merit in venture capital companies. It then looked at the best method of attracting venture capital to such companies and considered the provision of a special tax incentive to equity investors, direct government grants, a government loan, subsidised loan or loan guarantee and methods of government persuasion. It recommended that the Government should take urgent action to encourage the creation of private investment organisations to provide management guidance and equity capital for the start-up and early growth of eligible businesses with high growth potential. That is a recommendation which, with respect, should have been taken up by this Government in its recent mini-Budget.

Investors in what would be called 'growth business investment management companies' should, it is recommended, receive a full tax deduction for equity capital paid to a GBIMC up to an amount approved by a licensing board. A minimum of $200m over five years should be permitted. The cost in terms of gross revenue forgone would be about $20m a year for five years. The cost to government would, therefore, be negligible compared with potential benefits.

The proposal has been applauded by the Liberal shadow Minister, not only because of the low cost involved, but also because there would be no government involvement in the key areas of picking commercial winners and losers.

But the Government failed to so act in last week's mini-Budget. In fact, the disincentive to investment by small investors-the double taxation of dividends- which had been partly relieved by the last Liberal Government, an act which I then applauded, was reinstated. One suspects that if the Labor Government acts at all, it will lean towards government funding through government corporations with government involvement in the decision-making process. It will be adverse to the minimum government interference approach of the Espie committee. I hope that when the matter goes to Cabinet for consideration the Minister will remember what he said on 5 April. He stated:
I am the first to concede that government's have had a poor track record overseas in providing assistance in high technology investment.
On 16 May this year, only a week or so ago, Professor Slatyer, President of the Australian and New Zealand Association for the Advancement of Science Congress, said:
Immediate action must be taken to increase Australia's level of technological innovation if the country is to improve the productivity of existing industry and develop new industries.

He identified, with low levels of participation in education and industrial research and development, a lack of venture capital as a major contributor to Australia's poor technological performance. The Espie committee has set out a well researched and documented recommendation. The Time magazine article stated:
Technology has set off a scramble for jobs, profits and global markets.

Australia must not be left behind. Australian manufacturers must continue to utilise the advances of high technology in a continuing quest for greater efficiency. It must be recognised that innovation can lead to growth and new employment opportunities. The high technology entrepreneur must be supported.

One can comb his speech, which bears a remarkable similarity to the speech delivered here tonight by Senator Chaney, and find it thick on rhetoric and thin on constructive propositions. No alternative package is canvassed by the Leader of the Opposition. Although we might not have much confidence in his economic ability, we expected to see something positive in the contribution to the debate in the House of Representatives by the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard)-to use the words of my colleague Senator Walsh, the discredited former Treasurer of Australia. Nothing in Mr Howard's speech either could be classed in any sense as a constructive proposal. The only proposal, that put forward by Senator Hill tonight, seems to borrow very heavily from the Minister for Science and Technology, Mr Barry Jones.

In terms of there being a credible alternative and meeting the challenge of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to put up or shut up, the Opposition, on its performance, ought to shut up because it has produced nothing that is at all constructive. That is not surprising because, as we saw last week, the Opposition cannot claim credibility for its economic philosophy or economic policies. We saw in the Sydney Morning Herald on 26 May that Mr Macphee, Mr Howard and other members of the Liberal Party are factionalising over what should be the Opposition's wages policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us what yours is.

—Our wages policy ought to be well known to the honourable senator. If it is not, I will send him a copy of the prices and incomes policy. It is a comprehensive wages policy that gives reasonable and rational expectations to the work force and enables there to be an equality of sacrifice across the community. That is opposed directly by the lack of any wages policy by the Opposition. The newspapers report the Opposition's factionalism. It still cannot agree. It was not able to agree in January last year when its present leader, then back bencher Andrew Peacock, claimed that the Fraser Government did not have a coherent wages policy either. The Opposition cannot debate the economic scenario in Australia and not produce a proposal on that front. While it carps and harps and attacks what happens with wages in the real world, the absence of any cohesive view from the Opposition makes all of its criticisms meaningless.
—Are you trying to tell us that it was not Fraser who brought in the wages freeze? Are you really trying to tell us that?

—The honourable senator knows that the wages freeze is not a wages policy. The wages freeze is in fact the negative of a wages policy. It has nothing to do with there being a coherent wages policy. It has to do with reducing wages and trying to pretend that with the consequential reduction in aggregate demand in the economy there will be some form of resurgence of economic growth.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to what I regard as a somewhat remarkable speech-remarkable for its thinness of logic and understanding-by the Leader of the Opposition in this place, Senator Chaney. Senator Chaney, in a speech reminiscent of that delivered by his leader in the other place, tried to make a falsehood stick. He tried to argue that the Labor Government was guilty of broken promises. Of course that is an accusation that comes passing strange from a party whose record of office is to break the promises that it offers to induce electors to vote for it at election time. Nonetheless now being directed against the Labor Government is a continual harping on the slogan 'broken promises' in the fond belief, I believe, that if it is repeated often enough some people might be misled into believing it.

The allegation made by Senator Chaney and his colleagues in the other place does not stick. I remind Senator Chaney, before he bows out of the chamber, and other honourable senators that prior to the election the present Prime Minister and Treasurer made it clear that if on gaining office they found that their understanding of the economic situation had been wrong because the position had been distorted and misrepresented, and it became apparent that the Australian community had been less than well advised by the former Government, and if following the National Economic Summit Conference a different view came forward, they reserved their right to alter the economic direction. That was made crystal clear prior to the election. What did we find? We found that it was indeed a prudent statement because after the election-just a day or so after-on Treasury being consulted, we discovered that the Budget deficit was in fact of the order of $9.6 billion. Prior to the election, the then Treasurer had led the community of Australia to believe that the Budget deficit was to be more like $6 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which year are we talking about?
—We are talking about the Budget deficit as projected by Treasury.
—For which year?
—For the current year. The projected Budget deficit as informed by Treasury to this Government upon its taking office was said to be of the order of $9.6 billion.
—Which financial year?
—The former Treasurer, Mr Howard, was arguing that it was in fact of the order of $6 billion.
—Which year?
—I have answered that interjection. Does the honourable senator want it answered again?
—Which year?
—I have already answered that question.
—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy President. The honourable senator is misleading the Senate. He is certainly misleading this chamber. I ask him to withdraw-
—Order! Senator Walters, that is not a point of order; that is a debating point.

—I turn to another argument that has arisen in this chamber. It resulted from the Opposition taking its place in the Parliament and attacking the significant achievements of the Hawke Government in terms of the National Economic Summit Conference. Most editorialists-in fact all that I have read-and most independent commentators have praised the initiative of the National Economic Summit. Indeed, one of the significant features of it was that for the first time a massive amount of real information about the performance of the economy was made available to the Australian community. What the Opposition in this place and in the other place has tried to do is to attack the achievements of the National Economic Summit. Opposition senators have argued-I think with some justification-that the unemployed were not directly represented at the Summit. However, from that, Opposition senators have gone on to pretend that they can therefore represent the voice of the unemployed.

SPEECH.PARA: At the National Economic Summit Conference the Australian Council of Social Service was represented. It is a body which is better able to articulate the needs and aspirations of the unemployed on an organised basis than almost any other in Australia. Today and last week Opposition senators have criticised the Government's superannuation proposals. I say to them that they cannot have it both ways. They cannot criticise the superannuation proposals of the Government and, at the same time, argue credibly that they somehow or other represent the aspirations of the unemployed. Bruce McKenzie, the official representing ACOSS at the National Economic Summit, articulated the problem in these terms:

Tax concessions for superannuation are valued at around $2 billion a year. They remain the cherished privilege of less than half the workforce, while those without work have to beg for small increases in their income security payments. The freezing of some of these meagre payments, such as those relating to the children of pensioners and beneficiaries, has brought 700,000 children face to face with poverty. It is absurd to suggest that such people can sacrifice more.

If we are talking about the need for a government to obtain revenues to look after the interests of the unemployed and float expensive job creation programs and inject money into housing development, a government inheriting a Treasury as threadbare as the one this Government inherited, needs to address itself to the principle of equality of sacrifice. The argument of the Opposition would be more convincing if it were able to come forward and say what its equality of sacrifice would be.

TALK.START.PARA: —What incredible garbage! What about job creation through investment? Has that occurred to you at all?

—Job creation through investment is the basic engine of economic growth for this Government. This Government is committed to a level of economic growth that, over the next three years, will create half a million jobs. The main device for doing so will be growth in the economy.

SPEECH.PARA: I now turn to the logical, orderly and clear concept of what is needed by this Government to improve the economy. We started out with a prices and incomes policy which was endorsed by the people. We then moved to the National Economic Summit Conference and invited the people of Australia to come together on the basis of real knowledge and information as to what was happening in the economy, and from which Summit a communique was issued that provided a unity of purpose in many key respects. We then moved from that position to give expression to the needs of the Summit and the prices and incomes accord in the May economic statement, and from that we will move to the Budget for next year. We have developed a cohesive and coherent progression. We have a platform endorsed by the people. We have brought this country together. The economic statement has helped us to shake out some of the problems we have inherited and put us in a position for further growth. As to whether we have inherited problems-since that seems to be the main thought entertaining a number of honourable senators opposite-let me quote from the Australian Business magazine of 24 March. Referring to the position of the Australian Labor Party Government, it states:
'The Labor Party was left sitting on the eggs of the serpent.'
With the blessing of hindsight that is how one senior Labor Man of the Scullin Cabinet described what happened when Labor came into power in 1929.

The claim that Stanley Bruce, the outgoing conservative Prime Minister, deliberately lost the election in order to give Labor the responsibility for taking the country into depression is probably no more true than saying much the same about Malcolm Fraser.
But it was true then and it is true now that Labor found itself incubating the eggs of the serpent.
Malcolm Fraser has bequeathed a dangerous legacy to Labor in the form of the 1982-83 Budget and what that means to the Budget to be brought down in 1983-84.

One of the key problems that confronted us as a government in framing the economic statement was the costs imposed on the economy after the election, by virtue of the Budget that was brought down before the election, that transmitted costs up the calendar. There is no doubt that many of the programs announced in the Budget last year by the Fraser Government were designed to try to make that Government appear to the electorate as one that ought to be returned to office. There is no doubt it was a political Budget. There is equally no doubt that it has now imposed upon this Government a series of costs and promises that have added to our deficit and harnessed us with the problem that this May economic statement addresses.

The first point that I think needs to be made about the May economic statement is that, in terms of costs on the consumer price index, it imposes, in a full year, a cost of 0.17 per cent. In terms of pressures on wages that is a negligible cost. If one considers the supplement of Medicare to be introduced from 1 February, one sees that its cost and associated savings in terms of the consumer price index will help redress the ship and bring the economy around much more.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you mean the deck chairs will slide to the other side of the deck, like the Titanic?

—It is better than the Titanic the former Government was in charge of. The other aspect of the mini-Budget is to create employment by establishing a housing program. This will mean that the increase in housing loan approvals that we have seen since the election of the Labor Government will be built upon and that 130 to 135 homes will be built in the second half of 1983-84.

SPEECH.PARA: The economic statement provides in the period 1983-84 for the allocation overall of $733m to job creation initiatives. That is an increase of $383m or, as the statement says, 110 per cent over the 1982-83 period. The economic statement comes hand in glove with legislation that the Government has introduced in the other place to wipe out bottom-of-the-harbour tax avoidance and to improve the situation in an area that the former Government failed to do anything about. It remains a national scandal and a national monument to its inability to manage the economy. It is interesting that honourable senators opposite have been critical of the May statement in the way they have been. But I think that they ought to be reminded that their criticism is not shared by important sectors of the Australian business community. After the economic statement--

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose you will quote another March statement to support your comments on the May statement. That's what you have done so far.

—Senator Rae might be interested to know that I am going to quote the opinion of the Confederation of Australian Industry on the May statement. He may not be interested in what the Confederation of Australian Industry said, simply because it might support our position and make his untenable. That does not in any way prevent me from quoting it and putting it on the record. The Confederation said:

SPEECH.PARA: Although it imposes additional sacrifices on some sections of the private sector, the Confederation of Australian Industry believes that, in broad terms, the Government's Economic Statement is responsible.

An initial assessment suggests that the economic statement is a constructive and genuine attempt to simultaneously fight the twin evils of inflation and unemployment, and contain the increase in the Budget deficit, while also providing some stimulus to economic recovery.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now quote the full statement. Give us the rest of it.
—If the honourable senator wants the rest of it, I will read over the page. It continued:

SPEECH.PARA: It is clear that this strategy can work only if there is a strong and sustained commitment to moderation in claims for higher incomes, particularly wage increases.
The Government's reiteration of its view that there must be a recovery in profits from their present historically low levels to ensure restoration of prosperity is welcomed.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you doing about that?

—We have a wages policy. That wages policy will be presented in due course to a hearing of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. While the honourable senator may not respect that body, it is the body to which the Australian Government goes to put its wages case and where the Confederation of Australian Industry and the unions will go-and the arbitrator's decision will be accepted. In terms of support for what the Government has done, I cannot do better than rely upon the statement of the Confederation of Australian Industry. But it is not alone.
—You just cannot understand the subtleties of the way it expresses itself.

—Senator Rae will get a chance to speak later. He cannot deny that what the Confederation says endorses the proposition. It is not alone, of course . Many other organisations and public figures have joined in the acclaim of the Government's statement. One other organisation that I select to show the breadth of public support is the Council of Social Services of Tasmania. A Mrs Jane Longbottom is reported in the Hobart Mercury of 21 May as having said on that day that the Council 'welcomed the Government's mini-Budget as a first step in achieving the goals of the Economic Summit'. I think that in view of that comment it really ought again to be the considered position of the Opposition to stop carping, to stop its negativity and to stop throwing mud and to look constructively at what can be done to resurrect and reconstruct the economy of Australia. There is no greater task before us. The Opposition, while it might be politically uncomfortable for it, ought to join the multitude, join the consensus, and support the direction of economic management of this Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this cognate debate I wish to refer to the Government's economic statement and also to the National Economic Summit Conference which was held in April, for I consider that these matters are interrelated. A great deal has been said about the Hawke Government's first so- called step towards bringing Australia out of its present economic malaise and back into the realms of prosperity. Indeed, if one job had been created every time the words 'consensus' or 'conciliation' were uttered over the past two months I am sure we would not have an unemployment problem at all. The Summit Conference was designed to bring together all sections of the community which influenced the Australian economy to achieve a consensus approach on the best course of action for Australia's economic recovery.

SPEECH.PARA: I must admit that I would have thought it would be obvious to a student of economics such as the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) assures us he is that what this country needs is not a mini-Budget but a policy of wage restraint, or the wage pause as brought in by our Liberal-National Party Government, combined with an increase in private capital investment, increased Government expenditure on works, less taxation and therefore greater consumer spending. I am only sorry that Senator Cook, who preceded me, just did not realise that he was not speaking to trade unionists in a trade hall debate. As it turned out the Economic Summit did not represent all sections of the community. The Prime Minister, in his election policy speech, said:

No Australian resource is more important than our land. No sector of Australian industry is more important than our great primary industries, which still provide 50 per cent of Australia's export income in normal circumstances.

Yet this so-called most important resource had only one representative at the Economic Summit. The mini-Budget attacks primary industries right, left and centre. Unfortunately, the mini-Budget discriminates against farmers and people living in country areas. The farm sector is being asked to meet a disproportionate share of the cost of stimulating housing and employment. Sadly, rural people will be contributing one third of the total estimated savings of $ 985m outlined in the mini-Budget. Country people now face an increase in petrol prices, telephone charges and aviation fuel prices. They will pay more tax as the result of changes to income averaging provisions and the extended period of depreciation on plant and storage facilities. When one considers that rural people in most of Australia have suffered firstly a terrible drought and now the worst floods for many years this Government's total disdain for country people is very sad to see.

Industries Assistance Commission figures confirm that farm assistance dropped to 8 per cent in 1980-81. This compares with a current rate of assistance to manufacturing industry of 24 per cent-that is, three times the level of assistance to farmers. The other day I received a letter from a lady who lives at Gatton. She said she was stirred about the unfair treatment of farmers in Labor's recent economic package. She said she hoped I would voice my opposition to it, which I am certainly glad to do. She said:

As a mother, I am even more concerned by the apparent serious consideration which the federal government is giving to reducing their payout for family allowances. On a recent 4WK two way radio programme a Social Security Department employee outlined a cut back based on gross income. In each of the past three years an average of 40% of our gross income has been consumed by essential operating costs before we can begin to budget for financial commitments, living expenses, taxation and unavoidable updating of plant and machinery.

I would think a proportion of self-employed parents face an even greater outlay for operating costs. She went on to say that it seemed to her a reasonable assumption that the more money parents have the more they would spend on their children. She said:
Therefore I see the child endowment payments as being a meagre return on the various taxes that swell the national coffers as all parents, regardless of income level, provide for their children.

Parents are involved in loving and caring for the world's greatest resource. Let us not see that task go totally unassisted by Australia's Federal Government. There is a great need to uphold the traditional family. I hope that, at the very least, allowances are left unaltered.

There is no doubt that the decision to cancel the Bicentennial Water Resources Program was short-sighted. Of course, much water has gone to waste in the floods which we have just experienced. That water could have been stored for future use for when we have another dry period. We all know how often such periods occur. On 19 January 1983 the then Minister for National Development and Energy, Senator Sir John Carrick, announced further offers of assistance to Queensland for both ongoing and new projects under the National Water Resources Program. This included $2.7m for the Eton irrigation project near Mackay; $1m to assist stage two of the Leslie Dam near Warwick; and the Herbert River flood mitigation project was to proceed. Altogether Queensland was to share in this National Water Resources Program for 1982-83 to the extent of $9.85m. On 25 January the previous Prime Minister, Mr Malcolm Fraser, said:
Australia ought to be looking at water resource and water conservation programs .

The former Federal Government had planned to spend $640m over the next five years on water resources development projects around the nation. I consider that cancelling such a very important program for our country people was a very short -sighted decision.

Small business, that sector of the business community which employes in excess of 60 per cent of the Australian work force, was not adequately represented at the National Economic Summit Conference. The women of Australia, those of us who make up over half the Australian population, were not invited to contribute in any meaningful or significant way, although the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, Senator Susan Ryan, took her place at the Conference. I wonder whether the fact that we did not have so very many women there indicates what is meant by discrimination against women.The fact that women were omitted from the Summit hardly makes it representative of the Australian community. There has been a great deal of talk and backslapping about the consensus which was achieved at the Summit. Certainly, consensus was achieved because no decisions of substance were made. All that euphoria and good will were not channelled into economic energy and decision-making. The Prime Minister can be well satisfied that an elaborate and costly public relations exercise, televised throughout the nation, conditioned many Australians to accept restraint, particularly if it can be claimed that the sacrifices are borne equally.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. The honourable senator is reading her speech.
—There is no point of order. This matter has been discussed many times. I am sure Senator Bjelke-Petersen is using copious notes.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. I noticed an honourable senator opposite certainly had copious notes as well. The results, I must admit, in the Bruce by-election prove that many people feel that the sacrifices asked for in the mini-Budget are far from equal.
—What was the result in Bruce?

—The result in the Bruce by-election was a substantial win for the Liberal Party. I was very delighted to note that result. The people in that electorate realise that what the present Government has done has certainly meant sacrifices have not been borne equally. The Chinese sage, Confucius, once ob- served: 'It is no use running even harder if you are running on the wrong road'. I think that is a point that we want to remember.

SPEECH.PARA: The Summit showed that there is little difference between big government, big business and big unions. The Summit probably helped to add to the general understanding of the severity of the economic problems that are facing Australia , but it did not actually solve any problems. I wonder what people feel was achieved. Most said that unemployment was the major problem to be tackled. Whilst everyone agreed on that point, nothing seemed to be done about it. I was interested to read in the Australian not so long ago a statement by Dr Klugman who was said to have told Caucus that the Government should get on with the things for which it had been elected. He said:
We were elected to create jobs.
In fact we are trying to stop Tasmanians from working.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not to take away jobs.

—That is exactly what he said. This Government now has to face the formulation of a sound economic policy. Despite the fact that the mini-Budget made $300m available for a community work scheme which will provide some thousands of jobs for about six months-I am glad to know that this has been done-it is certainly nowhere near the 500,000 jobs that were promised in the election speech by the Prime Minister.
—Give us a go.

—Some thousands of jobs. I guess some thousands of people will be happy that they have work for six months. I point out that other decisions by this Government have meant the loss of jobs for people. I refer specifically to the cutting out of work on the Townsville Airport. I also mention the $20m that has been cut out on the Brisbane Airport work. It is a shame that a lot of jobs have been lost there.
—It is very selective.
—That is right. Queensland is being penalised.
—So is Tasmania. We are losing Wynyard.

—Yes. Many jobs are going by the board, including 1,200 jobs that have been lost at the Ben Lomond uranium mine. The Bradfield scheme has been cancelled. That proposition could have produced many jobs in North Queensland. Gold Coast home units were not allowed to proceed. These were all projects that would have allowed good employment opportunities in Queensland. Mr Keating has rightly been called the abominable no-man.
—He was just a union organiser before he came here.

—I do not know about that. I do not think he is doing too good a job as Treasurer. There is no doubt in my mind that the Government has abrogated its responsibilities. This Government was elected to govern. Admittedly, even novices in government need advice, but that advice should come from the right quarters. I do not think that we needed a Summit to tell us that inflation needs to be reduced, that wages should be kept down and that tax reductions should be forthcoming. I am quite sure if Mr Hawke wanted to achieve consensus on anything, he would achieve it on the fact that we need tax reductions. He would have no trouble on that issue at all. I am still convinced that the National Party's proposal for a single rate of tax of 25 per cent has much to recommend it.

SPEECH.PARA: Holiday loading and penalty rates are two other problems that need to be tackled by the Government. The Summit enabled Mr Hawke to abandon many election promises which, in actual fact, were never really on. I would like to know what happened to some of the promises that the Prime Minister made. He promised to provide immediately reductions in income tax; to retain the tax rebate for home loan payments. He also promised to introduce a first home ownership assistance scheme as an alternative to the existing Home Deposit Assistance Scheme, which will be retained. He promised not to increase tax on lump sum superannuation payouts. That promise seemed to go by the board. He also promised not to take money out of weekly pay packets and not to affect pensioners' cheques. I could continue relating the broken promises. But we must not forget that the health insurance rebate was to be retained until the introduction of Medicare.

What did the Summit actually achieve? It came to the conclusion that employers should restrain dividend increases; non-wage incomes, such as doctors' and lawyers' fees, should be controlled voluntarily; taxes may need to be raised; the Industrial Relations Bureau should be abolished; there should be union involvement in the planning and introduction of new technology, which Senator Hill spoke about earlier. These are hardly the sorts of decisions on which economic recoveries are made. Surely the Government could make some decisions to spend less. That is important. The Labor Party faces a fundamental dilemma over its prices and incomes policy. This type of policy, I might add, has been a failure when tried in other countries. The Summit failed to agree on the specific guidelines to be used by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.

One of the main issues which emerged at the end of the Summit was whether union consent to policies of wage restraint to prevent further dismissals was more theoretical than real. The Builders Labourers Federation, the Building Workers Industrial Union, the Transport Workers Union and the Electrical Trades Union of Australia all emerged as unions whose leaders claimed that they were not committed to any policy of wage restraint. Businessmen at the Summit failed to nail down the unions on anything but rhetoric. No vital decision was made to continue the wage pause until the end of the year. That decision is the most important thing that should have been resolved at the Summit Conference.

The first decision made after the Conference was made by the BLF when it decided that it wanted to strike for increased wages. The militant unions have fixed on the differences between the Economic Summit communique and the Australian Council of Trade Unions-ALP prices and incomes accord to justify continuing wage claims. To my way of thinking, it all hinges on the definition of wage restraint. Clearly, on that definition the BLF has differing ideas from those of the rest of the community. I certainly believe, as I said before, that the wage pause should be extended to the end of the year, with future wage movements to be made more on an industry basis in line with productivity. We have seen from the mini-Budget that Mr Hawke is not concerned about pensioners, because the means test on the pensions of the over 70s has been abolished.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which Joh doesn't get.
—He is also not concerned about the middle income earners. Joh has never taken the pension, even though he was entitled to it.
—That is the only Federal money he never took.

—The Federal Government will have to give Queensland plenty of money shortly to help with the floods there. The Government certainly has not worried about the middle income earners because the interest rebate on home loans was removed, nor is it giving a fair go to those who have looked after their future security through superannuation schemes. The Budget is an attack on the thrifty. Those who save their money, invest in their retirement, invest in their health, invest in sending the children to school, invest in the jobs of others by investing in Australian industry as small shareholders and work hard to increase their incomes to save for homes are the ones who are penalised. Queensland families will lose at least $4 a week through the abolition of the tax rebate on health cover and they will face a bill of $120m when Medicare is introduced. I asked a question the other day in which I made the statement that people in Queensland will have to pay for hospital care, which they get for nothing now provided they are willing to go to public hospitals to get their own health care.
—Queenslanders are two-time losers, aren't they?
—That is exactly right; they are in many ways. They have lost in relation to jobs and they are also losing in relation to Medicare.
—And look at the Government they have, too.
—I am talking about the Federal Government. The State Government in Queensland is doing a remarkable job.
—Under extremely difficult conditions.

—Exactly, especially with the present Federal Government . If Mr Hawke actually went into the election without making himself fully aware of the economic situation I think it was irresponsible of him and his party. If he knew the facts then he was dishonest. The National Economic Summit Conference , for all its rhetoric and euphoria, was merely a clever tool for the Labor Government to relinquish its responsibility to uphold its election promises. Now , of course, the Prime Minister can say that it was all done by consensus at the Summit and that all this action is supposedly condoned. I noted with interest in the Governor-General's speech that this Government promised to establish an Economic Planning Advisory Council. I wonder whether somebody from the other side of the chamber would be able to tell me why Ministers in the Government are paid such high wages if they are to require continually summits and committees to tell them what to do. I wonder what their departmental heads are there for. I wonder whether they will ever be able to judge a situation for themselves and act accordingly. It is as obvious as can be that we need a period of serious wage restraint. Somebody said in a speech earlier that he did not get any constructive advice. It is my feeling that the Government needs to make sure that we have a period of serious wage restraint. Members of the public want a wage pause and they want it until the end of the year. They want less government interference in business projects, greater productivity and less tax if we are to get the economy back on the rails. If the unions and the Government do not allow business-I do not just mean big business, I mean small businesses too-to make reasonable profits and investors to get reasonable returns then we will not create a climate which is job generating and inflation reducing. The major constraints to economic recovery are the cost of labour and inadequate profits.
—What do you consider is the minimum wage to live in dignity?

—That is for the Conciliation and Arbitration Commisson to decide-not me. The only hope to sustained growth lies in the significant easing of increases in the cost of labour. Only with sustained growth in the private sector will the unemployment problem be eased. An early lifting of the wages pause or delay in the restoration of profitability will substantially retard economic recovery in Australia. Whilst there are signs of economic recovery, both in the United States of America and elsewhere overseas, we must get our own house in order before we can expect to participate in this recovery.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the economic statement brought down by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on 19 May. It is described-correctly-as a mini-Budget. Let me put it in context. In August last year a Budget was brought down by the Fraser Liberal Government. That Budget conferred upon the Australian community considerable benefits in terms of increases in real purchasing power. It added to the purchasing power of the Australian people, on average, between $17 and $20 a week, free of tax. This en- abled them to have their purchasing power in good order when the wages pause was brought about. Last year the Fraser Government, in conjunction with all six State governments, introduced a wages pause. This was confirmed at a Premiers Conference and by a series of industrial commissions. That was the most significant economic step taken to that point.

SPEECH.PARA: There was an election, and the Australian Labor Party made quite a number of very substantial promises, the primary one being that if it was elected it would lower unemployment by 2 per cent in its first three years in office. That was the key promise made. It also made a string of other promises. The Labor Party came to office, and then it said, 'We cannot discharge any of these promises because we have discovered a Budget deficit of $9.6 billion.' Since then, the whole of the Labor Party's alibi has been built around a figure of $9.6 billion. Labor supporters use that figure when it suits them. They cast it away when it does not suit them. For example, at the National Economic Summit Conference, they used that figure, yet in fact when they put forward their options A, B and C, they did not use it. They adopted option A, which was based on an entirely different figure. It was convenient for them to decide when to use it and when not to use it.

The trouble now is that it has been demolished for them, and they no longer have an alibi, because even in its economic statement the Labor Government admits that the impetus given by the sound Budget policies of the previous Fraser Government was bringing about substantial improvements for the year 1983- 84. Indeed, in citing the six main reasons why 1983-84 would be a better year, it gave not one which emerged from its own policies. Fundamentally, those reasons arose out of Fraser Government actions. Let me quote them from the economic statement. The statement says:

As I noted in my address to the Summit Conference, we expected some improvements in economic activity in the course of 1983-84 with the main impetus coming from the fiscal stimulus implicit in the Commonwealth Budget for 1982-83 and in prospect for 1983-84.
I pause there. It is that Budget, its costs and its program, that the Hawke Government is now trying to destroy with its completely phoney arguments about a $9.6 billion deficit.
The second fundamental argument-it is the final one given, but is of fundamental importance, is-
The improved prospects for ongoing moderation of income claims as the prices and incomes accord is implemented.

Fundamentally, the only aspect of that prices and incomes accord in position is the wages pause that the previous Fraser Government brought in. Indeed, the other claims are: The international economy, a marked slowing down in stock decumulation, the improved prospect for the farms, and the pick-up in dwelling construction. I make it clear that repeatedly tonight a number of Labor senators have said, ' Show us your policies'. Indeed, I do not need to do so.
