DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Mr and Mrs R. Copland-Department of Main Roads Employees, Queensland-Adjournment Debate

PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr and Mrs R. Copland-Department of Main Roads Employees, Queensland-Adjournment Debate

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10 p.m., under sessional order, I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to bring to the attention of the Senate what seems to me to be an outrageous act of ministerial incompetence and insensitivity. The facts of the matter are these: In March 1981 two English people, Mr and Mrs Roy Copland, first applied for permanent residence in Australia as self-supporting retirees under section 5 (ii) of the current ' Migrant Entry Handbook'. Migrants in this category must have reached the Australian retiring age and intend to retire in Australia. They must have substantial assets to bring to Australia and sufficient income to support themselves for the remainder of their lives. Mr and Mrs Copland were able to show that they had sufficient cash assets to transfer to Australia and that they were able to support themselves in Australia for the rest of their lives.

SPEECH.PARA: But their application for permanent residency was initially rejected in September 1982 on the basis that Mr Copland was still in his late fifties-that is, under the normal Australian retiring age. However, the letter which rejected their original application invited them to appeal to the Immigration Review Panel. Mr and Mrs Copland accepted this invitation and an appeal for reconsideration by the Immigration Review Panel was lodged in November 1982. In the application for review the sponsor indicated that although Mr Copland was below the normal retiring age in Australia he was, in fact, fully retired and had no intention or need to work in Australia. This intention was accepted by the Immigration Review Panel and the sponsor was informed on 25 February 1983 that the appeal had been successful.

The sponsor was Mrs Hank, the sister of Mrs Copland, the English migrant. Mrs Hank is a permanent resident in Australia. She was informed that the application of her sister and brother-in-law was now successful subject to the couple meeting the settlement criteria, health and character requirements and provision of evidence of funds to transfer to Australia of at least $300,000 prior to visa issue. The Australian High Commission in London was also informed of the successful application of Mr and Mrs Copland. Acting on this decision, Mr and Mrs Copland sold their home in England to raise the final amount of money required to meet the $300,000 necessary for transfer to Australia. They completed all arrangements and met all criteria required by our authorities. They both enjoyed the very best of health and they had the highest possible character references. In addition, of course, they had a sister already resident in Australia.

On 6 May 1983 Mr and Mrs Copland, therefore, confidently went to Australia House to make the final arrangements and to secure their visas for entry into Australia. They were then informed that a message had been received from the new Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) rescinding the decision of the Review Panel and revoking the approval for their residence in Australia. At that time no public announcement had been made by the new Minister of any intention to change the immigration rules. It was not until two weeks later, on 18 May, that he made the statement, which statement I am about to quote, to the people of Australia in the House of Representatives. He said:

I have removed the concession granted by the previous Government to wealthy people between the ages of 55 and 65 which allowed them to migrate provided they had significant amounts of income or capital.

This announcement was two weeks after he had rejected the application from people long approved and who had made arrangements, including selling their house, in order to come to Australia. The Minister went on to say:
These persons were a potential addition to the labour market.

Surely this is irrelevant in the case I am talking about. Mr Copland had already indicated that he had no intention or need to work. Why not simply mark his visa and entry papers with a 'No work' stamp. The Minister also went on to say:
It could be inferred that it was possible to 'buy'-
Those are his words-
permanent residence.

This is a very strange statement. The wording and extensive scrutiny of entry applications make it impossible for the criminal, the unhealthy and the undesirable to buy their way into Australia. On the other hand, why should it be made to appear criminal to bring considerable resources to Australia to support oneself in retirement in this country? We welcome the tourist dollar-in fact, we hear constantly from the Government how important the tourist dollar is-so why should we not welcome the retirement dollar? With the enormous burden we carry in Australia for social security, we should welcome, within reason and after thorough scrutiny, those who can support themselves in Australia in retirement and old age.

I believe a number of questions require answers from the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in this Copland matter. The first is: Is it proper for a Minister to revoke an approval given under existing rules and policies and at a later date, after he has revoked it, announce to the public the new rules under which the former decision had been revoked? Secondly, why have an Immigration Review Panel if its decision can be accepted at one moment and be revoked without notice at a later date? Thirdly, whilst conceding that the Minister has the right to change policies and rules, does he not agree that these changes should be made only after the date of the public announcement and not before? Fourthly, as I mentioned before, does the Minister not consider it an advantage to Australia, especially-to use his own words-during times of economic recession, to permit permanent residency to those who do not require or want work but who have the capability to support themselves without placing any burden on the already overburdened social security system? Fifthly, has the Minister not persistently stated the strong commitment of the Australian Labor Party to the reunion of close family members? Has he forgotten that Mrs Copland has a sister, Mrs Hank, who is permanently resident in Australia? As I said at the outset, this is an outrageous decision, made by a very unwise Minister, and I think he should look at it again and alter it as soon as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As honourable senators will be well aware, there have recently been extensive flood rains in Queensland. In particular, these rains have resulted in widespread floods in south-west Queensland. Some towns in these areas are still isolated. However, people in these towns are in no immediate danger and both the State Emergency Service and the Australian Defence Force are doing a tremendous job in assisting in flood relief. Unfortunately there has been considerable loss of stock and agricultural crops which, ironically coming on the heels of a drought, will create even more difficulties for people on the land.

SPEECH.PARA: Last weekend I had the opportunity to inspect some of the flood damage and to speak to residents of south-west Queensland. I imagine that many of the immediate problems associated with the floods have been experienced in a similar way before and will be experienced again. I also imagine that some communities in northern New South Wales are experiencing similar problems. However, this evening I intend to inform the Senate of one incident which indicated a total lack of compassion on behalf of the Queensland Government and a country shire council. Honourable senators will be well aware that the south-west area of Queensland has experienced a prolonged drought. However, when the rains came, certain employees of the Department of Main Roads found that for them the rain was not 'liquid gold'-a term used not so long ago by Mr Neville Wran. In short, they were sacked. My information is that the Main Roads Department had about 35 workmen operating on two roads in south-west Queensland, the Augathella to Morven road and the Charleville to Augathella road. These men were permanent employees of the Main Roads Department but when it rained it was decided that they could not be usefully employed and they were thus sacked. They were told that they could have their jobs back when it stopped raining. This was a callous move by the Main Roads Department, a move for which the Minister responsible, Mr Hinze, deserves severe condemnation.

What did these men tell their families when they were sacked? Did their electricity bills suddenly cease because it was raining? Did the kids' shoes not need mending because of the rain? Were doctors 'and dentists' bills a thing of the past because it was raining? No, but it is satisfactory for Mr Hinze and his departmental officers to continue to draw their salaries whilst it is raining. Perhaps Mr Hinze was peeved because racing has been called off in Brisbane with monotonous regularity due to the unseasonal weather. But for people on low wages , some of whose homes were threatened by the floods, to be sacked was a devastating experience. As one of the workers said to me on the weekend: 'It all depends on where you get your corns. Get them on your backside and you keep working. Get them on your hands and you are sacked'.

Today we heard in the Senate that the Queensland Government has requested flood assistance from the Federal Government. I am certain that any requests from the Queensland Government will be considered sympathetically. But if the Queensland Government genuinely could not pay these men when it rained-and I doubt that that would be the case-why did it not approach the Federal Government for aid to keep them on? Surely these men have as much right to be protected during a period of a natural disaster as do others who have received and will receive substantial assistance. Mr Hinze was not alone in his lack of feeling for loyal workers who suddenly had to tell their families that their pay cheques had been stopped. One local council acted similarly and then said that its men had volunteered to take a week off. I understand that the men were faced with a cumpulsory choice. There was nothing voluntary about it. They were told that they could take a week off without pay, take holiday or long service leave, or they could be sacked. When the men chose to take a week off without pay they were hardly volunteers. Yet this is the story that was put by the shire council which gave them this choice.

I understand, and I am sure that all honourable senators understand, the financial problems faced by local councils. But surely they do not have to resort to this kind of action when it rains. After all, how often does it rain in south-west Queensland? It does not rain much. I will give some figures which show that rain in this area is not very usual. Charleville, for example, has an average annual rainfall of 512 millimetres, or about 20 inches; Cunnamulla has 361 millimetres average rainfall, about 14 1/4 inches a year; Roma, closer to the coast but still really part of south-west Queensland, has an annual average rainfall of 592 millimetres, about 23 1/3 inches. To give an indication of how low that rainfall is, these compare with Brisbane's 1,150 millimetres or 45 1/4 inches a year and Innisfail's 3,726 millimetres or 4 yards and 2 inches a year.

If the council did have financial difficulties so it could not keep these people on in that short period when it rained in south-west Queensland, I cannot understand why it did not approach the State Government for assistance. Given the Main Roads action, I doubt that such an approach would have been successful but at least the council could have tried to keep these men on. This is not the way to good industrial relations-to sack loyal workers when it rains, especially when a lot of people in that area would have been getting assistance for the drought and will be getting assistance for the floods. These men should have been kept on. I trust that the next time similar circumstances arise, the Government of Queensland will show more compassion to its loyal hard working work force. Because they get corns on their hands they should be looked after, not dealt a shoddy deal as they were on this occasion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was informed tonight before I came into the Senate for the adjournment debate that Senator Hamer wished to raise a matter concerning immigration. Therefore I came in in an attempt to give Senator Hamer an answer on the assumption that he wanted an answer. It is clear that he really did not want an answer. Despite that fact I will seek from the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) some details on the matter which Senator Hamer raised. I make this comment because in the past in this place senators who have raised matters on the adjournment to which they wished to receive answers have sought answers from the Minister representing the Minister in the other place. They have given the Minister some details about what they were going to talk about so that the Minister could in fact answer in a pertinent way. Senator Hamer could have done this and informed me of his problem just as he informed the Press some time ago when he released to the Press Gallery in this place-embargoed until 10 p.m.-a detailed Press statement giving the gist of the speech he was to make tonight, the attack that he was to make on the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, without giving that Minister a chance to reply.

SPEECH.PARA: Although he may have some concern about the fate of Mr and Mrs Copland, he obviously has more of a concern for and more of an eye to a headline than he has for that matter. When I was an Opposition senator in this place I tried many times over the years to get to this country the relatives of people from England . I was knocked back many times by Ministers for Immigration in the previous Government because those relatives did not have enough money.

On what Senator Hamer has told this place tonight, I accept that there may have been some injustice done to the Coplands and I will seek the facts from the Minister. Senator Hamer's principle seems to be that if one has $300,000 one should be able to buy one's way into this country and, going on the policy of his previous Government, if one does not have any money at all one should not be able to come to this country even if one has relatives here. That is certainly not a principle that I agree with, yet it seems to be Senator Hamer's principle. However, I will do my ministerial duty and seek an answer from the Minister for the honourable senator, whether he really wants me to or not.

As for Senator Colston's remarks, I believe that he has just demonstrated the normal actions of conservative governments in Queensland in their treatment of their workers. I do not think there is very much I can add. If Senator Colston wishes me to seek assistance from one of the Ministers in the Government I will do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak very briefly on the comments of Senator Grimes.
—I thought I was closing the debate.
—Not in the adjournment.
—Why not?
—Not in the adjournment.
—It was impossible while you were in Government to get a speaker up after the Minister had closed the debate.
—I have called Senator Martin.

—I will let others argue that out with Senator Grimes. I cannot respond on behalf of Senator Hamer because I do not know all the details of what Senator Hamer has done although he gave a fair resume tonight, I think, of some of the efforts he had made. I just say to Senator Grimes that he might, as he pours his criticism on to Senator Hamer, also spread a little of it on his fellow Ministers. There was an adjournment debate in the Senate last week in which a number of senators spoke on a variety of matters. The Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) did something quite unprecedented. In replying, after a reply to the issues that had been raised, in the adjournment debate she attacked Senator Peter Baume. Senator Baume was absent. She had not warned him of the subject on which she was going to speak. It is quite unprecedented, in my nine years in the Senate, for a Minister to use an adjournment debate to attack a private member without the subject matter having been raised during the adjournment debate or any indication having been given to that senator that the Minister was going to raise that subject. I sought leave to speak briefly to reply on behalf of Senator Peter Baume since he was not here . The Minister on that occasion denied me leave to defend one of my colleagues on the subject that she had raised during the adjournment debate. So before Senator Grimes gets too carried away by his righteous indignation I suggest he look at his own back yard.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 21 April 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: What would be the annual cost at current prices of disregarding disability pensions payable under the Repatriation Act 1920 for the purposes of the income test for all pensions and benefits payable under the Social Security Act 1947 in (a) 1983; (b) 1985; (c) 1990; (d) 1995; and 2000.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: If Repatriation disability pensions were disregarded for the purposes of income tests under the Social Security Act, it is estimated that the increase in outlays on social security pensions and supporting parents' benefits would be of the order of $25m in a full year.
This cost is based on data held on the computer masterfile as at December 1982. It is not possible to project this cost to the years requested.

The decrease in the cost as compared with the cost shown in the answer to the honourable senator's Question No. 2460 of 25 May 1982 is the result of an increase in the number of pensioners aged 70 years and over with income not stated and the increased free areas of income applying from November 1982. It is not possible to estimate the cost for pensioners whose income details are not known.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 11 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: Is the Minister undertaking a review of the guidelines for the assessment of invalid pensions; if so, when will the result of this review be made public.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: A substantial operations and methods review is being undertaken within the Department into arrangements for processing applications for invalid pensions. The review is still in its early stages.
I would expect that the results of the review will be made available when all stages have been completed.
The review is being undertaken as a matter of high priority, but I cannot at this stage indicate to the honourable senator when it will be completed.
